Prefer a certificate signed by a trusted certificate authority and avoid disabling SSL checks. A proper CA signed certificate saves time and prevents future headaches.

title: Find and edit system, global & local Git config files
description: Locate and edit Git system global and local config files with commands file paths and verification steps for correct user and repo settings
heading: Find and edit system, global & local Git config files
body:
This short guide teaches how to locate and edit system global and local Git config files using simple commands and file paths.

  1. Discover where config values come from
  2. Open the appropriate config file in an editor
  3. Edit settings such as user.name and user.email
  4. Verify that changes take effect

Discover where config values come from Use git config --list --show-origin to display every setting and the file that provided each value. To narrow output show only a specific scope use --system --global or --local.

Open the appropriate config file For system level the path is usually /etc/gitconfig and that file requires elevated permissions to edit. For a user level file open ~/.gitconfig. For a repository specific file open .git/config from the repo root. Replace nano with any preferred editor and remember that system files may need sudo.

Edit settings such as user.name and user.email Add or change lines under a section header for user for example [user] followed by name = Alice and email = alice@example.com. Aliases and core settings live in the same format. Save changes in the editor and close the file.

Verify that changes take effect Use git config --global user.name or replace --global with --local or --system to check a specific scope. Running git config --list --show-origin again shows which file contributed each final value.

This workflow helps avoid confusion when credentials or behavior differ between a machine and a repository. Use system config for machine wide defaults use global for a single developer profile and use local for repository specific overrides. Editing the wrong file is a common source of mystery settings so verify origins after changes.

Tip

When troubleshooting unexpected behavior run git config --list --show-origin first This reveals the exact file that set a value and saves many minutes of blame shifting and guesswork

title: Create an embedded Open Liberty executable JAR for WebSphere
description: Step by step guide to package an embedded Open Liberty executable JAR for WebSphere using Maven with practical configuration and testing tips.
heading: Create an embedded Open Liberty executable JAR for WebSphere
body:
This tutorial shows how to build an embedded Open Liberty executable JAR for use with WebSphere and package a runnable application using Maven.

  1. Add Open Liberty dependencies and Maven plugin
  2. Configure the embedded server
  3. Create a runnable executable JAR
  4. Test locally
  5. Deploy to WebSphere or artifact repository

Add the Open Liberty runtime dependency and the liberty Maven plugin to the project pom.xml so the server classes travel with application code. Add any feature dependencies that the application requires. The goal is a self contained runtime that does not rely on an external installed server.

Configure the embedded server by adding server.xml fragments and plugin configuration in Maven. Point the plugin to the proper server.xml and specify the packaging goal that generates a runnable archive. The configuration tells the embedded server which features to start and which ports to expose.

Build the executable JAR using the Maven package lifecycle phase. Use a command like mvn clean package to produce the artifact. The liberty Maven plugin will copy server artifacts and assemble a bootable jar that contains the Open Liberty runtime and application code.

Test the produced archive by running the jar on a developer machine. Use java -jar target/myapp.jar to start the embedded server and verify endpoints and logs. Local testing prevents surprises during deployment to a production like environment.

Deploy the executable JAR to WebSphere or an artifact repository depending on the target workflow. If WebSphere is the deployment target use the application server deployment tooling or run the jar on infrastructure that supports the Java runtime. Keep configuration overlays and externalized settings ready for different environments.

Recap of the process involves adding dependencies and plugin configuration configuring the embedded server building a runnable jar testing locally and then deploying to the chosen target. This yields a portable artifact that simplifies testing and integrates with existing WebSphere operations.

Tip

Use feature based server.xml fragments to keep the embedded server minimal. Smaller runtime size speeds startup and avoids surprise feature conflicts during deployment.

title: How to change the default Git editor to Notepad++ not Vim
description: Set Notepad++ as the default Git editor on Windows so commit messages open in Notepad++ instead of Vim using a simple Git config command.
heading: How to change the default Git editor to Notepad++ not Vim
body:
This guide shows how to make Notepad++ the default Git text editor on Windows so commit messages open in Notepad++ rather than Vim.

  1. Install Notepad++ or confirm presence of Notepad++ in PATH
  2. Set Git core editor to Notepad++ using Git config
  3. Test by creating a commit message
  4. Fix or revert if the choice is unwanted

Install Notepad++ or confirm presence of Notepad++ in PATH before proceeding. If Notepad++ is not in PATH use the full program path in quotes when running the Git command.

Run the Git configuration command to set the default editor. If a user prefers the Notepad++ GUI over Vim use the following command in a terminal that can run Git commands

git config --global core.editor "notepad++ -multiInst -nosession"

This command tells Git to open Notepad++ for commit messages. The flags help open a fresh Notepad++ window instead of restoring a previous session which keeps commit editing less confusing and less dramatic.

Test the change by making a quick commit that requires a message. Use a standard Git commit command that triggers an editor window such as git commit without the message flag. Git should open Notepad++ for the message editor. If the wrong editor opens confirm PATH settings or adjust the program path in the core.editor setting.

To revert the change use the unset command or set a different editor. For example a user can run git config --global --unset core.editor or set core.editor to another program placed in PATH.

The tutorial covered installing or locating Notepad++, configuring Git to use Notepad++ via a single command, testing by performing a commit and rolling back if needed. The goal is to stop Vim from hijacking commit messages and give the friendly Notepad++ interface back to the user.

Tip

If Notepad++ is not in PATH create a tiny batch file in a folder that is in PATH that launches the correct Notepad++ executable with the desired flags. This avoids drive letter path issues and keeps the Git setting neat.

title: Example of How to Use the Git Reset Hard Command
description: Step by step guide to using git reset hard safely with examples stashing and recovery tips for lost commits
heading: How to Use the Git Reset Hard Command Example
body:
This tutorial gives a clear workflow for using git reset hard to discard local changes move HEAD to a specific commit and recover when necessary.

  1. Inspect the repository state
  2. Choose the target commit
  3. Save any work worth keeping
  4. Perform the hard reset
  5. Verify results and recover if needed

Inspect the repository state. Run git status and git log --oneline to see what is staged what is untracked and where HEAD points. This step avoids surprise erasures and keeps disaster potential lower than expected.

Choose the target commit. Use git log --oneline or git reflog to pick a commit SHA or use relative refs like HEAD~1. Pointing to the wrong commit causes extra awkward moments.

Save any work worth keeping. Stash changes with git stash push -m "save before reset" or create a temporary branch with git branch temp-save and commit there. This avoids relying on memory which is famously unreliable.

Perform the hard reset. Run git reset --hard < commit-sha-or-ref> to move HEAD update the index and overwrite the working tree. That command does exactly what the name promises. Respect the name.

Verify results and recover if needed. Use git status and git log --oneline to confirm the desired state. If a commit was lost use git reflog then git reset --hard < old-sha> to restore the lost commit.

This walkthrough covered checking repo state selecting a commit saving work performing git reset hard and verifying or recovering with reflog so changes do not vanish in a puff of terminal smoke.

Tip

Tip Create a branch before the reset or stash changes. That approach makes recovery trivial and keeps regret levels manageable when aggressiveness meets deadline pressure.

title: Fix jvm.dll missing server JVM error SonarQube
description: Quick tutorial to resolve jvm.dll missing or missing server JVM errors when running SonarQube on Windows by fixing Java installation and paths
heading: Fix jvm.dll missing server JVM error in SonarQube
body:
This tutorial shows how to fix the jvm.dll is missing not found or missing server JVM error when running SonarQube on Windows by adjusting Java installation and SonarQube configuration.

  1. Verify Java architecture
  2. Install matching 64 bit Java
  3. Set JAVA_HOME and PATH
  4. Point SonarQube wrapper to the correct java executable
  5. Restart SonarQube service or run startup script

Step 1 Verify Java architecture

Open a command prompt and run java -version to confirm Java architecture. SonarQube distributed for Windows is usually 64 bit and requires a 64 bit Java runtime. A 32 bit Java will cause the missing jvm.dll or missing server JVM error because the Windows service wrapper cannot load the wrong architecture jvm library.

Step 2 Install matching 64 bit Java

Download and install a 64 bit JDK or JRE that matches SonarQube requirements. Use a vendor supported package and choose the 64 bit installer in order to build a compatible jvm.dll found inside the Java installation.

Step 3 Set JAVA_HOME and PATH

Set an environment variable named JAVA_HOME that points to the Java installation folder. Add %JAVA_HOME%\bin to the PATH so the service or startup batch finds the correct java executable first.

Step 4 Point SonarQube wrapper to the correct java executable

Edit SonarQube configuration under the conf folder and update the wrapper parameter that specifies the Java command to the full path of the 64 bit java executable if the service still uses the wrong one. This removes guesswork for the wrapper when loading jvm DLLs.

Step 5 Restart SonarQube service or run startup script

Stop and start the SonarQube Windows service or run the included batch file from the correct bin\windows-x86-64 folder. The wrapper should now load the proper jvm DLL and SonarQube will boot without the missing server JVM error.

This guide covered how to diagnose an architecture mismatch install a matching Java set environment variables and reconfigure the SonarQube wrapper so the missing jvm.dll error is resolved and SonarQube starts normally.

Tip

Use the same bitness for Java and SonarQube and prefer a JDK over a minimal JRE for easier debugging. Running the startup batch gives console logs that show the exact jvm DLL path when troubleshooting.

title: Jenkins vs. Maven - How Apache Maven and Jenkins CI Compare
description: Compare Maven build and dependency management with Jenkins CI automation. Learn roles differences and how both fit into a DevOps pipeline.
heading: Jenkins vs Maven How Apache Maven and Jenkins CI Compare
body:
The key difference between Maven and Jenkins is that Maven manages project builds and dependencies while Jenkins orchestrates automated build pipelines and integration tasks.

Maven operates as a project build tool that handles compilation testing packaging and dependency resolution. Developers declare project coordinates and lifecycle details inside a pom.xml file and Apache Maven follows that recipe to produce reproducible artifacts.

Jenkins acts as a continuous integration server that triggers jobs runs tests and deploys artifacts across agents. Jenkins integrates with version control systems and calls Maven or other build tools to perform work on demand or on a schedule.

  1. Role Maven handles build logic and dependency graphs while Jenkins handles automation scheduling and orchestration
  2. Configuration Maven uses declarative project files while Jenkins uses jobs or pipeline scripts
  3. Plugins Maven plugins extend build phases while Jenkins plugins add hooks triggers and integrations
  4. Use case Use Maven for deterministic builds and use Jenkins for CI CD delivery

Think of Maven as the recipe and Jenkins as the impatient kitchen manager who refuses to let dinner be late. Both tools pair nicely. Configure a Jenkins pipeline to run Maven goals on agents then archive test reports and deploy artifacts to a repository.

When technology choices cause meetings remember that developers want consistent builds and operations teams want reliable automation. Both goals align when Maven handles artifact creation and Jenkins handles automation flow.

Tip

Call Maven from a Jenkins pipeline with explicit goals and a clean workspace. Cache dependency folders on agents to speed builds and keep pom.xml tidy to avoid mysterious failures during automated runs.

title: Getting started with the Nexus Maven repository manager
description: Quick guide to install configure and use Nexus Repository Manager OSS version 2 for Maven artifacts and proxies.
heading: Getting started with the Nexus Maven repository manager
body:
This tutorial shows how to install configure and use Nexus Repository Manager OSS version 2 for Maven artifacts and proxying external repositories.

  1. Install Nexus
  2. Start the server and access the web console
  3. Create hosted proxy and group repositories
  4. Configure Maven settings to use Nexus
  5. Upload artifacts and manage security

Install Nexus by downloading the OSS version 2 bundle and unpacking on a server that developers can reach. Startup scripts are included so no deep sysadmin magic is required.

Start the server and open the web console on the default port. Use the welcome credentials for the first login and change the admin password to avoid future awkward conversations with security teams.

Create a hosted repository for company builds and a proxy repository for Maven Central. Then create a group repository that combines hosted and proxy targets. Group repositories make dependency resolution simple and reduce configuration in build servers.

Configure Maven settings by adding the group repository URL to the distributionManagement and repositories sections. Place server credentials in the Maven settings file for deployments. This keeps continuous integration servers happy and human error rates lower than average.

Upload artifacts using Maven deploy goals or the web console upload UI if the experimental urge strikes. Use the security model to create roles and users and assign privileges for upload download and repository administration. Schedule cleanup to avoid hoarding obsolete snapshots and wasting disk space.

Nexus OSS version 2 gives a straightforward path from raw Maven builds to a managed artifact lifecycle. Developers get faster dependency downloads and a central place for deployment and proxying. Administrators get control over access and storage without reading a three volume manual.

Tip

Use a group repository URL as the only repository in Maven settings for developers and CI. That reduces configuration sprawl and makes repository changes transparent to builds.

title: Bottom Up SOAP Web Service in Eclipse Example
description: Step by step guide to build a bottom up SOAP web service in Eclipse using Java and Apache CXF with deployment and testing tips.
heading: Bottom Up SOAP Web Service in Eclipse Example Guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to build a bottom up SOAP web service in Eclipse using Java and Apache CXF and how to generate WSDL deploy the service and run basic tests.

  1. Create the POJO service interface and implementation
  2. Add Maven dependencies and CXF plugins
  3. Generate or expose WSDL from the code
  4. Deploy the service to an embedded server or Tomcat
  5. Test the endpoint with SOAP UI or curl

Create a plain old Java object that represents the service contract and a class that implements the contract. Add JAX WS annotations on the interface or class to define operations and parameters. Keep the API clean so the generated WSDL looks sane rather than like a dictionary for the lost.

Add necessary Maven dependencies for Apache CXF including the JAX WS frontend and HTTP transport. Include the CXF Maven plugin when a build time WSDL is desired. Avoid tangled dependency trees by declaring versions in a central place.

Use CXF runtime or the CXF codegen plugin to publish a WSDL from the POJO. For development a simple Endpoint.publish call will expose a WSDL URL. For production generate a WSDL during build to ensure stable contracts for consumers.

Deploy the service using an embedded server for quick testing or package a WAR and deploy to Tomcat for more realistic behavior. Configure web.xml or rely on CXF servlet mapping depending on the chosen approach. Watch classloader quirks because those tend to be dramatic.

Fire up SOAP UI or send SOAP envelopes with curl to the exposed endpoint URL. Verify operations response headers and fault handling. Logging of raw SOAP messages helps when a request and response look like they learned mime arts from a mystery author.

You walked through a POJO first SOAP service creation in Eclipse covering code design dependency setup WSDL exposure deployment and testing. The result is a runnable SOAP endpoint that can be consumed by other services or legacy systems that demand XML drama.

Tip

Enable Apache CXF logging interceptors to capture raw SOAP messages and use the CXF Maven plugin to generate WSDL during the build to avoid surprising differences between development and production.

title: Create a Top Down SOAP Web Services in Eclipse
description: Step by step guide to build a top down SOAP web service in Eclipse using a WSDL first approach and JAX WS code generation for Java developers
heading: Create a Top Down SOAP Web Services in Eclipse
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a top down SOAP web service in Eclipse using a WSDL first approach and JAX WS code generation.

  1. Prepare the WSDL file
  2. Create the Eclipse project
  3. Generate server side code from WSDL
  4. Implement endpoint methods
  5. Deploy to a servlet container
  6. Test with a SOAP client

Prepare the WSDL file by defining service name operations messages port types bindings and target namespace. A clear WSDL acts as the contract that client developers will worship or curse depending on design choices.

Create the Eclipse project as a Dynamic Web Project or a Maven web project. Add JAX WS dependencies through Maven or by dropping jars on the build path. Maven keeps dependency chaos at bay.

Generate server side code using wsimport or Eclipse Web Services tools. Generated artifacts include the service endpoint interface the service class and JAXB data classes. Generated code saves keystrokes and provides a consistent contract mapping.

Implement endpoint methods in the generated skeleton classes. Add business logic perform validation and map domain models to JAXB types. Keep the implementation focused and avoid turning the service into a monolith of clever hacks.

Deploy the project to Tomcat or another servlet container that supports JAX WS. Verify web.xml or programmatic endpoint configuration matches the WSDL service URL and namespace. Pay attention to classpath and dependency versions to avoid mysterious runtime errors.

Test using SOAP UI curl or a simple Java client by hitting the WSDL URL and exercising each operation with sample SOAP envelopes. Check SOAP headers fault handling and data type mapping during testing.

Recap The workflow covers WSDL first design code generation implementation deployment and testing. Following these steps yields a predictable SOAP service that clients can consume with minimal blind luck.

Tip

Keep the WSDL stable and use namespace versioning for breaking changes. Use a JAXB bindings file to control type names and package mapping. Run wsimport with debug verbose flags during development to see how schemas map to Java classes.

title: JFrog artifactory tutorial Download setup and JAR deployment
description: Guide to download setup JFrog Artifactory and deploy JARs with Maven repository setup permissions and verification steps
heading: JFrog Artifactory tutorial Download setup and JAR deployment
body:
This tutorial shows how to download JFrog Artifactory set up a local instance and deploy a JAR to a Maven repository in a few practical steps.

  1. Download and install Artifactory
  2. Start the server and open the web UI
  3. Create a local Maven repository and configure permissions
  4. Configure Maven and perform a JAR deploy
  5. Verify the deployed artifact in the repository

Download and install Artifactory by choosing the OSS or Pro distribution from the JFrog site and follow the platform specific installer. For quick testing a zip or tarball will work on a developer machine.

Start the Artifactory server with the provided startup script or system service. Open the web user interface in a browser and complete the initial admin setup and password change per prompts. The UI is where most configuration tasks become obvious so do not skip this step.

Create a local Maven style repository in the administration repositories section. Name the repository with a clear convention and grant deploy permissions to a service account or user. Good naming and access control prevent repository clutter and accidental overwrites.

Configure Maven to point to the new repository by adding a server entry to settings.xml and a distributionManagement entry to the project pom. Use a deploy command such as mvn deploy -Dfile=target/my.jar -Durl=REPO_URL -DrepositoryId=local to push a single JAR. Replace REPO_URL with the repository path from the Artifactory UI and use the repositoryId that matches settings.xml.

Verify the uploaded JAR by browsing the repository in the web UI. Confirm checksum records and that metadata appears under the expected group and artifact coordinates. If Maven deployment fails inspect logs on the Artifactory server and review user permissions.

The workflow covered downloading installing starting configuring and deploying prepares a developer or admin to manage binary artifacts reliably. Repeat these steps for additional repository types and automate via CI once manual deployment proves stable.

Tip

Use a dedicated service account for CI deployments and set a non expiring API key. That approach avoids personal credentials in build pipelines and makes rotation less painful when access needs change.

title: Fix JFrog Artifactory 2097152KB heap startup error quickly
description: Quick guide to fix the 2097152KB object heap startup error in JFrog Artifactory by adjusting Java heap and startup settings
heading: Fix JFrog Artifactory 2097152KB heap startup error quickly
body:
This guide shows how to fix the JFrog Artifactory 2097152KB object heap startup error quickly by checking Java architecture and adjusting heap settings.

  1. Check Java version and architecture
  2. Locate Artifactory Java options file
  3. Adjust heap values
  4. Restart the Artifactory service and verify

Step one run java -version and confirm a 64 bit JVM is installed. A 32 bit JVM cannot reliably allocate multiple gigabytes of heap. If the server runs a 32 bit runtime then install a 64 bit JDK.

Step two find startup configuration in the Artifactory distribution. Typical places are $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/bin/artifactory.default or a system file like /etc/default/artifactory. The JVM options live in those files or in a wrapper script.

Step three change the memory flags. Reduce or tune -Xms and -Xmx values so the max heap fits physical memory. For example change -Xmx2097152k to -Xmx1536m if the host has limited RAM. If the host can handle two gigabytes then ensure the JVM is 64 bit and swap is not causing failures.

Step four restart the service with systemctl or the provided control script. Then check logs under $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/var/log for any remaining startup errors. If the same object heap complaint persists then recheck the JVM bits and system memory pressure.

Summary of the fix adjust Java environment or heap settings so the requested 2097152KB allocation is valid for the platform. The usual culprits are a 32 bit JVM or too aggressive memory settings on a small host.

Tip

Use a 64 bit JVM and set -Xmx to about 70 to 80 percent of available RAM to avoid out of memory drama. Monitor with a simple tool like top or a JVM profiler to catch creeping memory usage before the next startup tantrum.

title: Not Git, but GitHub Interview Questions
description: Quick guide to common GitHub interview questions with concise answers and practical tips to prepare for developer interviews
heading: Not Git but GitHub Interview Questions Explained
body:
Quick no nonsense guide to common GitHub interview questions and sharp ways to answer during a discussion.

  1. What is GitHub

    GitHub is a web based hosting service for Git repositories that adds collaboration features such as pull requests issues and project boards.

  2. How does GitHub differ from Git

    Git is a distributed version control tool that runs locally while GitHub provides remote hosting collaboration and access controls on top of Git.

  3. What is a pull request

    A pull request is a request to merge changes from one branch or fork into another with a review process for feedback continuous integration and discussion.

  4. Fork versus branch

    A branch lives inside a repository and is great for short lived work. A fork creates a personal copy of a repository and is common for open source contributions.

  5. How to handle merge conflicts

    Fetch latest changes create a local branch merge the target branch resolve conflicts by editing files add and commit then push the resolved branch. Using commands such as git fetch git merge and git add will be handy.

  6. What are issues and project boards

    Issues track bugs features and tasks while project boards provide kanban style organization for planning and prioritization.

  7. How to manage access and permissions

    Use teams and role based permissions on the organization level grant least privilege needed and prefer repository level protected branches for critical workflows.

  8. How to prepare for a live coding or PR review

    Create a small demonstrator repository prepare a clear commit history write a concise pull request description and be ready to explain trade offs behind design choices.

Answer questions with brief definitions followed by a short example or workflow. Interviewers appreciate clarity and practical context more than buzzword salad.

Tip

Bring a tiny demo repository to interviews and walk through a pull request. Showing a quick branch workflow and resolving a mock conflict will impress more than textbook answers.

title: Jenkins Interview Questions
description: Compact guide to common Jenkins interview questions with clear answers and practical tips for CI CD roles and DevOps interviews
heading: Jenkins Interview Questions and Answers for CI CD Roles
body:
Quick guide to common Jenkins interview questions and crisp answers that hiring managers actually want to hear and that keep candidates from rambling.

  1. What is Jenkins Jenkins is an open source automation server used for building testing and deploying software in a continuous integration and continuous delivery pipeline
  2. What is a Jenkinsfile A Jenkinsfile is a text file that defines a pipeline using either declarative or scripted syntax and lives in source control for versioned pipelines
  3. Difference between freestyle job and pipeline job Freestyle jobs are simple GUI driven tasks while pipeline jobs allow complex scripted flows and are better for code driven CI CD
  4. How to secure Jenkins Use authentication and authorization plugins enable agent to controller encryption limit plugin usage and run Jenkins under least privilege
  5. What are agents and executors Agents run build tasks and executors are the parallel worker slots on an agent that perform jobs
  6. How to handle credentials Store secrets in Jenkins credentials store and reference them in pipelines to avoid hard coding in source code
  7. What are common plugins to know Pipeline Git credentials matrix authorization and role based access control plugins are frequently asked about
  8. How to trigger a pipeline Trigger from Git pushes webhooks scheduled builds or manual start using the pipeline syntax
  9. How to debug a failing job Check console logs review agent environment validate workspace files and reproduce step locally if possible
  10. What to expect in architecture questions Be ready to sketch controller agent separation scaling strategies and where pipelines run

Practice concise answers and provide examples from real projects to show practical knowledge. Prepare a short story about a challenging pipeline failure and how that was resolved. Avoid theoretical monologues and stick to outcomes and trade offs.

Tip

Bring a simple Jenkinsfile example to the interview and explain why a declarative pipeline was chosen over a scripted one for that scenario

title: Sample DevOps Interview Questions
description: Compact guide of sample DevOps interview questions with clear answer strategies and prep tips to help you perform better in technical and behavioral rounds
heading: Sample DevOps Interview Questions Guide
body:
A compact field guide to common DevOps interview questions and how to answer them while sounding competent and slightly smug in a good way.

Focus areas that often show up include continuous integration and delivery pipelines cloud platforms configuration management container orchestration monitoring and incident response.

  1. Core concept questions
  2. Hands on tool questions
  3. System design and architecture
  4. Automation and scripting examples
  5. Behavioral scenarios and blameless postmortem discussion

Core concept questions test understanding of why a practice exists and what benefits follow. Answer by naming a goal and linking a concrete outcome. For continuous integration and deployment discuss a typical flow and outcome of faster safe releases.

Hands on tool questions probe experience with Docker Kubernetes Jenkins Terraform Ansible and cloud providers. Give brief context of a past usage example and a metric or result. Use a concrete command example when helpful like git status or a kubectl action.

System design questions want a clear architecture explanation and trade offs. Sketch components service boundaries scaling strategy and how monitoring and alerting tie into the design. Mention failure modes and recovery plans.

Automation questions reward snippets and workflows. Describe an automated pipeline that builds tests packages and deploys. Naming a rollback mechanism and a test gate earns bonus points.

Behavioral questions require real examples of communication incident handling and collaboration. Use the STAR pattern and emphasize learning that improved the delivery process.

Common pitfalls to avoid include vague answers claiming broad experience without examples over reliance on one tool and ignoring observability in designs.

Tip

Prepare two concise stories that show technical depth and cross team impact. Practice explaining one architecture on a whiteboard and one automation flow with a single metric that proved success.

title: Jenkins Artifactory Integration Tutorial Uploading JARs
description: Configure Jenkins to upload JARs to Artifactory using plugin pipelines credentials and simple build steps
heading: Jenkins Artifactory Integration Tutorial Uploading JARs
body:
This tutorial shows how to configure Jenkins to upload JARs to Artifactory using the Artifactory plugin and pipelines.

  1. Install the Artifactory plugin
  2. Configure the Artifactory server and credentials
  3. Create a freestyle job or pipeline
  4. Add an upload step to push JARs to a repository
  5. Verify upload and adjust metadata

Install the Artifactory plugin via the Jenkins plugin manager. The plugin provides build steps and pipeline helpers so the Jenkins server can talk to the repository without resorting to ritual sacrifice.

Configure the Artifactory server using the plugin global settings and add credentials using the Jenkins credentials store. Use username and API key or service account credentials so the build process can authenticate securely.

Create a job or pipeline depending on preference. For pipelines use a Jenkinsfile and the pipeline syntax that the Artifactory plugin exposes. For freestyle jobs add the Artifactory deploy step in the post build actions.

Add the upload step to send JARs to a target repository. A pipeline snippet might use the rtUpload helper or a simple publish step in a freestyle job. Use patterns to select the correct JAR files and define the target repo name so artifacts land where intended.

Verify the upload by checking the repository in Artifactory. Confirm checksums metadata and that the build info shows the correct artifacts. If Maven or Gradle are involved use the Artifactory resolver and publisher to capture full build info for traceability.

This tutorial covered plugin installation configuration of server and credentials job and pipeline creation adding an upload step and verifying that JARs arrive in Artifactory. The steps deliver a repeatable pipeline that keeps binary artifacts under control and traceable to builds.

Tip

Use build info collection so visual traceability exists between commits builds and published JARs. Tag uploads with build numbers and use repository layout rules to avoid naming collisions.

title: Simple Java JDeps Example
description: Quick guide to using jdeps for Java dependency analysis with simple commands and tips for interpreting output
heading: Simple Java JDeps Example Guide for Dependency Analysis
body:
This tutorial shows how to use the jdeps tool to analyze Java class and jar dependencies and produce readable reports.

  1. Pick a target jar or module to inspect
  2. Run a basic jdeps command
  3. Read the summary output
  4. Generate graph files for deeper inspection
  5. Refine with classpath or module options

Step one is about selecting the jar or module that needs dependency insight. Point jdeps at the artifact that causes curiosity and move on.

Step two runs a minimal command to get quick feedback. Try jdeps -s myapp.jar for a compact summary that highlights package level dependencies.

Step three covers how to interpret the summary. Look for unexpected references to platform modules or third party packages. Those lines reveal hidden coupling and potential upgrade traps.

Step four shows how to create graph files for visual tools. Use jdeps -dotoutput graphs myapp.jar to export dot files. Feed the dot files to Graphviz for a visual dependency map that looks fancy in reports.

Step five is about refining results by telling jdeps where to find extra classes. Use jdeps -classpath lib/* myapp.jar when external jars are required. That removes false positives and produces cleaner reports.

Extra tips include running jdeps on individual classes for surgical checks and watching for references to deprecated platform modules that may bite during runtime. The tool does most of the heavy lifting but feeding correct classpath information gives the most accurate diagnosis.

Summary of the tutorial content is that jdeps provides a fast way to find dependency surprises and to generate machine friendly outputs for visualization. Running jdeps with summary and dot output flags covers common needs and reduces guesswork when maintaining or modularizing Java code.

Tip

When chasing strange dependencies run jdeps with the class file for the suspect feature rather than a whole large jar. Narrower scope produces clearer signals and faster feedback.

title: Here are the differences between GitHub and Git
description: Clear differences between Git and GitHub for developers Learn local version control remote hosting workflows commands and when to use each
heading: Here are the differences between GitHub and Git explained
body:
The key difference between GitHub and Git is that Git is a distributed version control system while GitHub is a cloud hosting service that uses Git.

Git manages snapshots of project files on a developer machine. Git records commits branches tags and history and makes local branching cheap and fast. Developers run commands like git init git add git commit and git branch to track changes.

GitHub sits on top of Git and adds collaboration features via a web interface. The platform offers remote repositories pull requests issue trackers webhooks and integrations for continuous integration and deployment. GitHub gives a place for teams to review code merge changes and host documentation.

Key practical differences

  1. Scope Git is the engine for versioning. GitHub is a service that hosts repositories and adds social and automation features.
  2. Where Git operations run on local machines by default. GitHub operations happen on servers and through a browser or APIs.
  3. Collaboration Git supports collaboration through remotes branching and merging. GitHub simplifies collaboration with pull requests code review and access controls.
  4. Dependency Git does not need GitHub to work. GitHub depends on Git to store history.

Common commands to move work between local and remote include git clone git push and git pull. Forking and pull requests are GitHub concepts that help manage external contributions.

Use Git for version control tasks on a local repository. Use GitHub when code hosting collaboration code review or public distribution are needed. That choice keeps workflows clear and avoids confusion when onboarding team members.

Tip

Use the command line for precise Git operations and use the web interface for code review and issue tracking. If a company blocks GitHub consider a self hosted Git server like GitLab or Gitea as an alternative.

title: How to install Git on Windows in 10 simple steps
description: Step by step guide to install Git on Windows fast with recommended options and beginner friendly tips
heading: How to install Git on Windows in 10 simple steps
body:
This guide shows how to install Git on Windows with the official installer and recommended options so Git works from the command line and plays nice with GUI tools.

  1. Download the official Git for Windows installer
  2. Run the installer with administrator privileges
  3. Choose components to install
  4. Select default text editor
  5. Adjust PATH environment option
  6. Choose line ending conversion
  7. Configure credential helper
  8. Set up SSH keys if SSH access is needed
  9. Finish installation and launch Git Bash
  10. Verify installation and set global configuration

Step 1 Download the official Git for Windows installer from the official source using a browser that does not panic.

Step 2 Run the downloaded installer as an administrator so the program can update PATH and other system settings without whining.

Step 3 Choose components such as Git Bash and Git GUI. Picking both is fine unless minimalism is a life goal.

Step 4 Select a default text editor. Choose a familiar editor so commit messages do not become a mystery ritual.

Step 5 Adjust PATH option to allow Git from the command prompt or only from Git Bash. Picking command prompt integration saves keystrokes later.

Step 6 Choose line ending conversion. Use the default recommended option for mixed Windows and Unix environments to avoid weird diffs.

Step 7 Configure the credential helper to cache credentials or use the Windows credential manager for fewer password tantrums.

Step 8 Set up SSH keys if pushing to remote repositories over SSH. Generating a key pair and adding the public key to the remote host is painless once the first attempt is over.

Step 9 Finish the installer and open Git Bash to get a proper Unix like terminal with Git commands ready.

Step 10 Verify the installation by running a version command then set global user name and email so commits carry identity and moral responsibility.

After following these steps the Windows machine will have a working Git installation that integrates with the shell and common tools. Developers should now be able to clone repositories commit changes and push to remotes without invoking ancient rituals.

Tip

Enable the credential manager and use SSH keys for different hosts. This reduces password prompts and prevents accidental use of the wrong account.

title: How to install Apache Tomcat 9 Java web app server on Window
description: Quick guide to install Apache Tomcat 9 on Windows for Java web apps with Java setup Tomcat install service and deploy a WAR fast.
heading: How to install Apache Tomcat 9 Java web app server on Windows
body:
This tutorial shows how to install Apache Tomcat 9 on Windows and get a Java web app running.

  1. Install a compatible Java JDK
  2. Download the Tomcat 9 binary or Windows installer
  3. Set JAVA_HOME and optional CATALINA_HOME
  4. Install or unzip Tomcat and configure the service
  5. Start Tomcat and deploy a WAR to webapps

Install a compatible Java JDK

Tomcat 9 needs Java. Grab a recent JDK matching the Tomcat requirements and install that whole package. Remember a JRE alone may not be enough for development tasks.

Download the Tomcat 9 binary or Windows installer

Choose the Windows service installer for a friendly setup or the zip for manual control. The installer will add a Windows service and basic configuration files. The zip gives full manual power for those who enjoy extra steps.

Set JAVA_HOME and optional CATALINA_HOME

Set a JAVA_HOME system variable to the JDK folder so Tomcat finds the Java runtime. Optionally set CATALINA_HOME to the Tomcat folder when using the zip version for clearer paths.

Install or unzip Tomcat and configure the service

Run the Windows installer or extract the zip into a clean folder. If using the installer use the GUI to select ports and user roles. For manual installs register the service with the provided bat files if a service is desired.

Start Tomcat and deploy a WAR to webapps

Start the Tomcat service or run the startup script from the bin folder. Open a browser and check localhost on port 8080 to see the default page. Drop a WAR into the webapps folder to deploy a Java web application and watch the logs for startup messages.

Summary of actions performed in this tutorial Install a compatible JDK Download Tomcat choose installer or zip Set environment variables Install or extract Tomcat Start the server and deploy a WAR The server should be reachable on localhost port 8080 and logs will confirm successful deployment

Tip

For development use a non default port to avoid conflicts with other services and tail the logs in the logs folder to spot class path or permission issues early.

title: Eclipse and Tomcat integration for Java development
description: Configure Eclipse with Apache Tomcat for Java web development and testing Deploy debug and run web apps from the IDE
heading: Eclipse and Tomcat integration for Java development
body:
This tutorial shows how to connect Eclipse to Apache Tomcat to deploy run and debug Java web applications inside the IDE.

  1. Download and install Apache Tomcat
  2. Install or confirm Eclipse with Web Tools
  3. Add Tomcat as a Server Runtime in Eclipse
  4. Create a Dynamic Web Project or import existing project
  5. Deploy to the Tomcat server and start in Debug mode
  6. Test endpoints and troubleshoot common port conflicts

Download the desired Tomcat release from the official site and unzip to a folder. No magic required except avoiding the temptation to name the folder something dramatic.

Open Eclipse and confirm presence of Web Tools platform. If missing use the Marketplace to add the server adapters. The Marketplace button saves time and occasional regret.

In the Servers view add a new Server and point the runtime to the Tomcat home folder. Choose the matching Tomcat version so the server does not throw a tantrum.

Create a Dynamic Web Project for a clean setup or import an existing WAR based project. Configure the project facets to include the web module and desired Java version.

Right click the server and add the project then start in Debug mode to set breakpoints and step through request handling. Debugging inside the IDE beats guessing logs in the dark.

Open a browser or a REST client and call deployed endpoints. If port 8080 is already in use change the server port in the Servers view or in the Tomcat configuration file to avoid the familiar port clash drama.

The guide covered server installation project setup deployment and debugging so the development loop becomes fast and reproducible.

Tip

Use a dedicated workspace for web projects and point the server to a separate Tomcat installation. That prevents accidental exploded deployment clutter and makes rollbacks less painful.

title: Breastfeeding mother removed from courtroom in Montreal
description: Montreal courtroom removed a breastfeeding mother sparking debate over parental rights courtroom rules and legal accommodations
heading: Breastfeeding mother removed from courtroom in Montreal
body:
A Montreal courtroom removed a breastfeeding mother during a hearing and the episode sparked debate about parental rights courtroom decorum and legal access.

The legal landscape in Canada generally protects the right to breastfeed in public spaces. Judges have authority to manage proceedings and maintain order. Conflict arises when strict courtroom management collides with the practical needs of a nursing parent during a long hearing.

Why the removal matters comes down to equal access to justice and reasonable accommodation. Forcing a parent to leave can silence testimony delay matters and create barriers for those who cannot easily arrange childcare or feeding schedules.

Practical steps that help lawyers parents and court staff reduce friction follow. These steps do not guarantee outcomes but they increase the chance of a fair process.

  1. Notify court staff before the hearing about breastfeeding needs
  2. Request scheduled breaks or a private space for feeding
  3. Bring a support person if allowed by local rules
  4. Ask permission to breastfeed at counsel table to avoid removal
  5. Document the incident and consult counsel about remedies if removal occurs

Notifying staff gives clerks a chance to prepare and reduces surprise. Requesting breaks or a private room offers a practical accommodation that preserves dignity. A support person can handle non legal tasks and help with the child. Asking permission to breastfeed at a counsel table frames the need as a reasonable request rather than a disruption. Documenting any removal creates a record for later review by a judge or tribunal.

Public reaction often mixes principle and emotion. Courts and advocates can work toward clear guidance that balances courtroom order with parental needs and access to justice.

Tip

Tell court staff about breastfeeding needs before the date of a hearing and bring a written request for accommodation. Counsel can file a short notice with the court to make the need part of the official record.

title: Five things you didn't know about JDBC
description: Five surprising JDBC facts every Java developer should know to write safer faster database code and avoid common pitfalls
heading: Five things you didn't know about JDBC explained
body:
JDBC hides several handy features that improve safety performance and debugging for Java database access.

  1. Automatic driver registration

    Since JDBC 4 drivers register themselves via the service provider mechanism. Manual Class.forName calls belong in museums. Modern code just asks for a connection and the driver shows up.

  2. Try with resources closes resources correctly

    Use try with resources to ensure Connection Statement and ResultSet close even when exceptions happen. Less boilerplate and fewer mysterious connection leaks that wreck production.

  3. PreparedStatement is both safer and faster

    PreparedStatement prevents SQL injection and enables driver side optimization when the same SQL runs frequently. Use parameters instead of string concatenation and let the driver handle escaping and plan reuse.

  4. Batch updates are a performance multiplier

    Adding multiple parameter sets to a PreparedStatement and calling executeBatch reduces round trips and often cuts execution time dramatically. Great for imports and bulk changes.

  5. Transaction control goes beyond commit and rollback

    Use setAutoCommit false for grouped operations and consider Savepoint to roll back part of a transaction. Proper transaction boundaries keep data consistent and make error handling predictable.

Also pay attention to ResultSet type and concurrency choices. Forward only streams are cheap while scrollable read only sets cost more resources. Connection pooling remains the single most effective operational improvement for real systems.

A final pragmatic note Developers who treat JDBC as low level plumbing will gain by learning a few advanced features. Those features reduce bugs increase throughput and make debugging less painful.

Tip

Use PreparedStatement with parameters combine that with a proven connection pool and prefer explicit transaction boundaries. That combo prevents SQL injection reduces latency and keeps connections behaving in production.

title: How to install OpenJDK with AdoptOpenJDK Java
description: Step by step guide to install OpenJDK using AdoptOpenJDK on Linux macOS and Windows with commands and verification tips
heading: How to install OpenJDK with AdoptOpenJDK Java
body:
This tutorial teaches how to install OpenJDK from AdoptOpenJDK on Linux macOS and Windows using official binaries and package managers.

  1. Choose JDK or JRE and pick a version
  2. Obtain AdoptOpenJDK via download or package manager
  3. Run the installer or extract the archive
  4. Set the JAVA_HOME environment variable and update the shell path
  5. Verify the installation with the Java tools

Choose JDK or JRE and pick a version The JDK is for development and tools such as javac while the JRE is for running Java applications. For modern development pick an LTS release unless testing a newer feature is required.

Obtain AdoptOpenJDK via download or package manager On Debian and Ubuntu run sudo apt update then sudo apt install openjdk-11-jdk for OpenJDK from distro repos. On macOS use Homebrew with a cask for AdoptOpenJDK or download a DMG from the AdoptOpenJDK distributions page. On Windows download the MSI and run the graphical installer like a responsible desktop user.

Run the installer or extract the archive MSI and DMG installers will handle most details. For tar or zip archives extract into a system JVM folder such as the standard JVM directory for the platform. Use elevated privileges for system locations or place the distribution under a user directory for single user setups.

Set the JAVA_HOME environment variable and update the shell path Point JAVA_HOME to the root of the AdoptOpenJDK folder installed. Add the bin directory from the distribution to the shell path so Java commands are available from any terminal session. Persist these changes in the shell profile or Windows system environment settings so the configuration survives a reboot.

Verify the installation Run java -version and javac -version to confirm the chosen AdoptOpenJDK distribution is active. If the reported vendor and version match expectations then the installation is complete and ready for builds or runtime workloads.

This guide covered choosing the correct package for a role, obtaining AdoptOpenJDK via package manager or download, running an installer or extracting an archive, configuring environment variables and verifying the installation so Java is ready for use.

Tip

Tip Use a version manager such as SDKMAN for Linux and macOS when juggling multiple JDK releases. That avoids manual path juggling and reduces chances of running a test against the wrong JDK.

title: Hibernate vs JPA compared Which one should you choose?
description: Compare Hibernate and JPA differences performance features and use cases to choose the right persistence approach for Java applications
heading: Hibernate vs JPA compared Which one should you choose?
body:
The key difference between Hibernate and JPA is that JPA is a specification and Hibernate is a concrete implementation that extends the specification with extra features and tools.

JPA defines a standard API for object relational mapping in Java. Developers get annotations a standard EntityManager and a clear contract that multiple providers can implement. The main benefit is portability across providers and a common mental model when switching persistence engines.

Hibernate implements the JPA specification and brings additional bells and whistles. Expect a rich query language called HQL advanced caching strategies support for custom types automatic schema tools and integration utilities. Hibernate often gives more power for performance tuning at the cost of some provider specific behavior.

When to choose which

If portability and standards matter pick JPA as the baseline. If advanced features like second level caching custom dialects or vendor specific optimizations are required pick Hibernate. For most Spring based projects the default path is to use JPA APIs with Hibernate as the provider. That provides cleaner code and access to Hibernate extras when necessary.

Quick code hint without drama

EntityManager em = getEntityManager()

Session session = em.unwrap(Session.class)

Those two lines show the relationship between the standard API and the implementation. Use the standard API for everyday CRUD and switch to implementation features for advanced use cases.

Learning curve and community support are not negligible. JPA knowledge transfers across providers. Hibernate knowledge helps when performance tuning or when using features beyond the spec.

Pick JPA for clean standards pick Hibernate when hungry for advanced control. Try both locally and measure before committing to a single path unless a corporate policy demands hero worship for a specific provider.

Tip

Start with JPA and Hibernate as the provider. Use Spring Data JPA for productivity and invoke Hibernate specific APIs only when benchmarking shows a real gain.

title: Best Static Code Analysis Tools for Java Code Quality
description: Compare top static code analysis tools for Java to improve code quality catch bugs early and integrate with CI and IDEs
heading: Best Static Code Analysis Tools for Java Code Quality
body:
Static code analysis finds bugs style violations and security smells before production and saves developer reputations.

Pick a tool based on rule coverage integration speed and team workflow rather than chasing the fanciest dashboard.

  1. SpotBugs A modern successor to FindBugs that spots common Java bug patterns with a low false positive profile
  2. PMD Rule based engine that flags complexity dead code and suspicious constructs useful for maintainability
  3. Checkstyle Focus on coding style and formatting with strong editor plugins for consistent codebases
  4. SonarQube Centralized quality dashboard with rule management security checks and historical tracking for teams
  5. Error Prone Compiler plugin from Google that catches subtle Java mistakes at compile time
  6. SpotBugs with Security Plugin Adds security focused detectors for OWASP style issues

Practical steps to adopt static analysis without blowing up developer morale

Start with a baseline run on the main branch then focus on new code rather than drowning the team in legacy noise

Tune rule sets to match team priorities and assign severity levels so the analyzer stops being a nagging oracle

Integrate the analyzer into the build pipeline and the IDE for fast feedback during development and during continuous integration

Use incremental scans or changed files analysis to keep pipeline time reasonable on larger codebases

Set up a suppression policy for false positives using annotations or comments and document why a suppression exists

Automate ticket creation for triage worthy findings and measure trend lines so the team can show improvement not just pain

Choosing a single tool often misses gaps so combine style linters runtime analyzers and security scanners for comprehensive coverage

Adopting static analysis is more about process than technology. Focus on developer feedback loops and measurable goals and the tools will become helpful allies rather than noise machines.

Tip

Start with a lightweight rule set in the IDE then gate only high severity issues in CI. Track technical debt with a baseline so new analysis results focus on progress rather than punishment.

title: Top Java Test Frameworks
description: Quick guide to top Java test frameworks with pros cons and use cases to help pick the right testing tools for modern Java projects
heading: Top Java Test Frameworks for Modern Development
body:
This article lists popular Java test frameworks with use cases and quick notes.

  1. JUnit 5

    JUnit 5 is the de facto standard for unit testing in Java. Modern JUnit supports nested tests parameterized tests and extensions. Use @Test to mark test methods and add extensions for lifecycle hooks and assertions.

  2. TestNG

    TestNG offers flexible configuration and built in parallel execution for larger suites. Use groups listeners and data providers when test orchestration needs more control than classic unit tests.

  3. Mockito

    Mockito focuses on mocking and stubbing to isolate units under test. Create mocks with readable syntax and verify interactions without drowning in boilerplate.

  4. AssertJ

    AssertJ provides fluent assertions that read like English while giving clearer failure messages. Replace brittle assert statements with chained assertions for better diagnostics.

  5. Spring Test

    Spring Test provides application context loading test slices and MockMvc for web layer tests. Use that framework when dependency injection and Spring features must be exercised in tests.

  6. Cucumber

    Cucumber brings BDD style testing with Gherkin feature files. Use that approach when business stakeholders need readable acceptance criteria turned into automated tests.

  7. Spock

    Spock uses Groovy to deliver expressive specification style tests. Data driven scenarios and clear setup when behavior driven descriptions are preferred.

  8. WireMock

    WireMock simulates HTTP services to isolate external dependencies during integration testing. Use that tool to avoid flaky tests that depend on remote services.

Choosing a stack does not require loyalty to a single name. Start with JUnit 5 for core unit tests add Mockito for mocking and AssertJ for nicer assertions. For Spring projects add Spring Test and MockMvc. For parallel execution or complex suite rules consider TestNG. Use Cucumber for business readable acceptance tests and WireMock for HTTP isolation. Mix and match based on test speed readability and maintenance overhead rather than hype.

Tip

Favor readable fast tests over maximal coverage with slow external calls. Combine a light unit test layer with a few targeted integration tests and use mocks or WireMock to keep the pipeline reliable and quick.

title: Best Java deployment tools
description: Overview of top Java deployment tools and how to pick a pipeline with CI containerization orchestration and packaging options
heading: Best Java deployment tools for production and CI
body:
The key difference between Java deployment tools is the lifecycle stage they handle and how much automation the solution provides.

Pick tools that cover build packaging containerization orchestration and delivery. This guide gives a quick map so the deployment pipeline stops being a mythical beast.

  1. Maven and Gradle Manage dependencies build artifacts and run plugins for packaging. Commands mvn package and gradle build are the basics.
  2. Spring Boot Package applications as executable jars that simplify launch and reduce server config drama.
  3. Docker Containerize applications for consistent runtimes across environments. Use minimal base images to trim size and attack surface.
  4. Kubernetes Orchestrate containers with scaling health checks and rolling updates. Good for production at scale.
  5. CI systems Jenkins GitLab CI and GitHub Actions automate builds tests and deployments so human fingers do less error prone work.
  6. Infrastructure as code Terraform and Ansible provision and configure servers so environments remain reproducible and auditable.
  7. PaaS options Heroku and Elastic Beanstalk remove much ops overhead at the cost of some platform constraints.
  8. GraalVM native images Produce ahead of time compiled binaries for fast startup in latency sensitive services.

Start by choosing a single build tool and a single delivery target. Invest in automated tests CI pipelines and container images. Add orchestration only when load and complexity demand that layer.

Standardize naming conventions artifact coordinates and deployment manifests to avoid the usual chaos where developers swear the same code behaves differently across hosts.

Tip

Automate one deployment path from commit to production. Keep the path small and repeatable. Monitor logs and readiness probes rather than guessing whether a service is healthy.

title: The most important Java CLI tools to know
description: Compact guide to essential Java command line tools with examples and practical tips for java javac jshell jar jlink jmap jstack jstat jdeps javadoc
heading: The most important Java CLI tools to know
body:
Quick hands on guide to the most useful Java command line tools and how to use each.

  1. java java -version
  2. javac javac MyApp.java
  3. jshell jshell
  4. javadoc javadoc MyApp.java
  5. jar jar cfm app.jar Manifest.txt -C classes .
  6. jlink jlink --module-path mods --add-modules my.app
  7. jmap jmap -heap PID
  8. jstack jstack PID
  9. jstat jstat -gc PID 1000
  10. jdeps jdeps -summary my.jar

java runs compiled classes on a chosen Java runtime. Use the version flag to confirm runtime and spot mismatches before blaming the build server.

javac compiles source files to bytecode. Pay attention to module paths and classpath when build errors appear and the editor gets defensive.

jshell offers a REPL for quick experiments and tests. Great for trying API calls without creating an entire project for a five line test case.

javadoc generates API docs from source comments. Good comment hygiene rewards teammates and future versions of the project.

jar packages classes and resources into archives. Remember to include a correct manifest when producing executables and stop guessing why the main class fails.

jlink creates a custom runtime image with only needed modules. Small deployable bundles avoid bloated containers and angry storage bills.

jmap inspects heap details for memory analysis. Use when memory consumption behaves like a toddler who found a candy jar.

jstack prints thread dumps to diagnose deadlocks and stall conditions. Paste the stack into an issue tracker and watch the debugging drama unfold.

jstat monitors JVM statistics to track garbage collector behavior over time. Live metrics beat guessing and prayer for performance tuning.

jdeps analyzes dependencies for module migration and cleanup. Useful when the project has more accidental libraries than conscious design.

Tip

When troubleshooting include runtime version classpath and a minimal reproducer. That trio saves hours and prevents blame from being assigned to the nearest build tool.

title: Git revert vs reset What's the difference?
description: Clear comparison of Git revert and Git reset with examples when to use each and how to recover lost commits.
heading: Git revert vs reset What's the difference?
body:
The key difference between git revert and git reset is that git revert records a new commit that undoes a previous commit while git reset moves the current branch pointer and can change the index and working tree.

Use git revert when the commit history must remain intact on a shared branch. The revert command makes a new commit that applies the inverse of a past commit. That approach keeps history linear and readable for teammates and continuous integration.

Example

git revert commit_hash

Use git reset for local cleanup before pushing. The reset command rewrites branch history and has three common modes. The --soft form moves the branch pointer only. The --mixed form moves the branch pointer and resets the index. The --hard form moves the branch pointer and resets the index and working tree which discards uncommitted changes.

Examples

git reset --soft HEAD~1 git reset --mixed HEAD~1 git reset --hard HEAD~1

Be careful with reset on branches that others use. Resetting public history typically requires a force push which can orphan commits and cause confusion for collaborators. If a mistaken reset occurs the reflog can rescue lost commits with commands such as git reflog followed by git checkout or another reset.

Quick decision guide

Shared branch choose revert for safety and clarity. Local branch choose reset for tidy history before sharing. For surgical history edits consider interactive rebase for multiple commits.

That covers the practical trade offs between these two commands and when to favor one approach over the other without making teammates cry.

Tip

When unsure run commands in a throwaway branch first. Use git reflog as a safety net after a risky reset and prefer revert for any commit that already reached a remote.

title: Here's how to set JAVA_HOME in Windows 7
description: Quick guide to set JAVA_HOME on Windows 7 and add Java to PATH so java commands run from the command prompt
heading: How to set JAVA_HOME in Windows 7 for command line Java use
body:
This short tutorial shows how to set the JAVA_HOME system variable on Windows 7 and add Java to the PATH so java tools run from the command prompt.

  1. Find the Java installation folder
  2. Open System Properties and Environment Variables
  3. Create or edit the JAVA_HOME system variable
  4. Add the Java bin folder to the PATH
  5. Verify from the command prompt

Find the Java installation folder by checking the Program Files folder under the C drive for a folder named Java and then a jdk version folder such as Program Files\Java\jdk1.8.0_xxx. Prefer a JDK folder rather than a JRE folder so developer tools work correctly.

Open Control Panel then System then Advanced system settings and click Environment Variables. This brings up the dialog that controls global and user environment variables.

Create a new system variable named JAVA_HOME and set the value to the full path of the JDK root such as Program Files\Java\jdk1.8.0_xxx. If a JAVA_HOME variable already exists select Edit and correct the path.

Edit the system PATH variable and add %JAVA_HOME%\bin as a new entry or append the entry to the existing string using the standard Windows path separator. Placing the entry at the front ensures this JDK is found first by command line tools.

Open a new command prompt window and run java -version and echo %JAVA_HOME% to confirm that the Java runtime and the environment variable match the intended JDK.

This tutorial walked through locating the Java folder creating or updating the JAVA_HOME system variable adding the bin folder to the PATH and verifying the setup from the command prompt. If command line tools still complain check for multiple Java installations and ensure the command prompt session was restarted after the change.

Tip

If multiple JDKs exist give each JDK a clear folder name and update JAVA_HOME before starting IDEs or build tools. A quick restart of the command prompt often resolves ghost problems caused by stale environment settings.

title: How to deploy Spring Boot microservices to Amazon ECS
description: Deploy Spring Boot microservices to Amazon ECS with Docker ECR task definitions and services for scalable container deployment on AWS
heading: How to deploy Spring Boot microservices to Amazon ECS
body:
This tutorial shows a practical path to deploy Spring Boot microservices to Amazon ECS using Docker and Amazon ECR and how to wire task definitions and services for production like traffic.

  1. Build a Docker image for each Spring Boot service
  2. Push the image to Amazon ECR
  3. Create an ECS task definition
  4. Create an ECS cluster and service
  5. Attach a load balancer and configure environment variables and logs

Build a Docker image Use Maven or Gradle to produce a runnable jar then create a Dockerfile that uses an OpenJDK base and copies the jar into the image. Keep layers minimal and prefer a multi stage build to reduce final image size. Use docker build -t myapp . for a local test.

Push the image to Amazon ECR Create a repository in ECR and authenticate the Docker client with the AWS CLI. Tag the local image using a repository uri and push the image to the registry so the ECS task definition can reference a stable image source.

Create an ECS task definition Define container name image uri CPU and memory settings and port mappings. Add environment variables for configuration and a log driver configuration that sends logs to CloudWatch for easy debugging.

Create an ECS cluster and service Choose Fargate for serverless containers or EC2 launch type for more control. Create a service using the task definition and set a desired count for replicas. Configure health checks so the service replaces unhealthy tasks automatically.

Attach a load balancer and configure runtime details Create an application load balancer with a target group that maps to container ports. Ensure security groups and subnets allow traffic. Use parameter store or secrets manager for sensitive environment values and mount those as environment variables in the task definition.

Deployments converge to a running set of containers that receive traffic from the load balancer and send logs to CloudWatch. Use rolling updates and monitoring to maintain availability and reduce surprises during deploys.

Tip

Automate the whole flow with a pipeline using CodePipeline or GitHub Actions and CloudFormation or Terraform for task definitions. Reproducible infrastructure saves a lot of apologies later.

title: Five different ways to upload JAR files to JFrog Artifactory
description: Learn five practical ways to upload JAR files to JFrog Artifactory using common tools and commands for CI and manual use
heading: Five different ways to upload JAR files to JFrog Artifactory
body:
This tutorial gives a high level view of five practical ways to upload JAR files to JFrog Artifactory using common tools and simple commands

  1. Web UI
  2. Maven deploy plugin
  3. Gradle publish
  4. curl REST API
  5. JFrog CLI

Web UI Use the Artifactory browser to navigate to a target repository and drag and drop the JAR file. This method is great for one off uploads and for those who enjoy graphical clicks more than terminals.

Maven deploy plugin Configure distributionManagement in the project POM and run the standard Maven deploy goal. Maven will calculate coordinates and push the JAR to the configured repository using credentials from the settings file. This works well for build pipelines that already use Maven.

Gradle publish Apply the maven publish plugin and configure a publication and a repository block. Then run gradle publish. Gradle will assemble the JAR and publish the artifact with the specified group and version.

curl REST API Use a simple HTTP PUT against the repository path to upload a JAR from a machine that has network access to Artifactory. An example command looks like curl -u USER -X PUT https//example.com/artifactory/repo/path/app.jar -T build/libs/app.jar. This is handy for scripting and quick debugging from a shell.

JFrog CLI Install the JFrog CLI and configure server credentials once. Then run a single upload command such as jfrog rt u "build/libs/*.jar" repo/path/. The CLI adds checksum optimization and parallel uploads which help in real world pipelines.

Each method has trade offs. Use Web UI for manual checks and small teams. Use Maven or Gradle for integrated builds. Use curl for ad hoc scripts and quick tests. Use JFrog CLI for automation and performance in CI systems.

Tip

For repeatable builds store credentials in a secure config and prefer JFrog CLI or build tool integration. That reduces human error and keeps pipelines fast and predictable

title: Jenkins Git Plugin Tips Tricks and Examples
description: Practical Jenkins Git Plugin tips tricks and examples for pipelines branches credentials polling and faster CI workflows
heading: Jenkins Git Plugin Tips Tricks and Examples for CI
body:
This tutorial demonstrates practical ways to use the Jenkins Git Plugin to manage repositories trigger builds and handle credentials in Pipeline jobs.

  1. Configure plugin and global settings
  2. Target branches and refspecs
  3. Manage credentials and SSH keys
  4. Choose polling or webhooks
  5. Pipeline checkout examples

Configure plugin and global settings

Open Manage Jenkins and verify that the Git plugin is installed along with any Git client plugin that the build server needs. Adjust global tool locations so the job can find a Git binary without poking around like a detective.

Target branches and refspecs

Set branch specifiers to match patterns such as origin/main or origin/feature. Use simple refspecs to limit the fetch range and speed up fetch operations. Branch filtering prevents unnecessary builds and avoids angry notifications.

Manage credentials and SSH keys

Store credentials in Jenkins Credentials with appropriate scopes. Use SSH keys for private repos and prefer credentials binding instead of pasting secrets into job fields. Security teams will send thank you notes or at least fewer angry emails.

Choose polling or webhooks

Polling is simple and sometimes fine for small projects. Webhooks are scalable and immediate and avoid wasting CPU cycles. Use webhooks when a prompt build trigger matters.

Pipeline checkout examples

Prefer the declarative checkout scm for freestyle and Pipeline jobs when the repository layout matches the job. For custom checkout needs use checkout scm along with lightweight fetch strategies to keep builds fast.

This compact guide covered configuration basics branch targeting credential handling trigger choices and Pipeline checkout examples so that the Jenkins Git Plugin behaves like a cooperative tool rather than a temperamental gremlin.

Tip

Enable lightweight checkout for Multibranch Pipeline jobs to fetch only the Jenkinsfile and avoid long clone times for large repositories

title: How to quickly deploy from Spring Boot to a Docker container
description: Step by step guide to build a Spring Boot app and package that app inside a Docker container for fast local testing and simple deployment
heading: How to quickly deploy from Spring Boot to a Docker container
body:
This tutorial shows how to build a Spring Boot application and package that application into a Docker container for fast deployment and testing.

  1. Produce an executable jar from the Spring Boot project
  2. Create a minimal Dockerfile to run the jar
  3. Build a Docker image from the project files
  4. Run a container from the image
  5. Test the running service and optionally push the image to a registry

Step 1 Build the app package. Use the project build tool to create a runnable jar. Example commands include mvn clean package or ./gradlew bootJar. The produced artifact will usually appear in the build output folder.

Step 2 Create a simple Dockerfile. Keep the file minimal. Choose a small Java runtime image as base, copy the jar into the image, and define the command to launch the app using java -jar app.jar. No need for extra layers during first pass.

Step 3 Build the Docker image. From the project root run docker build -t myapp . The tag name helps with local testing and later pushes to registries.

Step 4 Run the container. Start a background container using a command such as docker run -d --name myapp_container myapp Add a port mapping flag to publish host port to container port when exposing the service to external traffic.

Step 5 Test and deliver. Open a browser at localhost on the chosen port or use a command line HTTP tool to call the application endpoint. When satisfied push the image to a registry using the preferred naming convention and registry login flow.

This tutorial covered how to take a Spring Boot project from a built jar to a running Docker container with a few practical commands and a compact Dockerfile. The goal is repeatable local testing and a foundation for CI pipelines.

Tip

Use multi stage builds to keep final image size small and enable faster deployments. Add health checks and a small init process to handle signals for graceful shutdowns.

title: How to use the application.properties file in Spring Boot
description: Guide to using application.properties in Spring Boot with examples on binding profile overrides and external configuration
heading: How to use the application.properties file in Spring Boot
body:
This tutorial shows how to configure Spring Boot using the application.properties file and how to bind and override properties for different environments.

  1. Create the file and place the file on the classpath
  2. Define common properties and simple key value pairs
  3. Bind properties to beans using @Value and @ConfigurationProperties
  4. Use profiles with profile specific files for environment overrides
  5. Externalize configuration and understand Spring Boot precedence rules

Create the file named application.properties and drop the file under src/main/resources for a typical Maven or Gradle project. The Spring Boot auto configuration will pick the file up from the classpath so no magic incantation is required.

Define properties using plain key value lines such as server.port=8081 and app.name=MyApp. Keep values simple and use consistent naming to avoid confusion when properties grow.

Bind properties to beans using @Value for single values and use @ConfigurationProperties for groups of related values. Example of a quick bind with single value is @Value("${app.name}"). For bulk binding create a POJO annotated with @ConfigurationProperties("app") and let Spring populate fields based on matching prefixes.

Profiles allow safe overrides per environment. Create files named application-dev.properties and application-prod.properties then activate a profile with the property spring.profiles.active=dev. The profile specific file will override matching keys from the base file when the profile is active.
