Externalize configuration by placing a properties file outside the packaged jar for runtime changes without rebuilding. Remember Spring Boot follows a clear order of precedence so profiles and command line arguments may override values found in the file on the classpath.

Recap of the tutorial shows that application.properties serves as the central, simple, and powerful place for Spring Boot configuration. Create the file, define clear keys, bind values to beans cleanly, use profiles for environment concerns and externalize when operational flexibility is required.

Tip

Prefer @ConfigurationProperties for groups of related settings to enable validation and cleaner code. Use a consistent prefix and keep sensitive values in environment variables or a secrets manager rather than in plain properties on disk.

title: JDBC vs Hibernate What's the difference with JPA?
description: Compare JDBC Hibernate and JPA to learn which Java persistence approach fits use cases from raw SQL to full ORM.
heading: JDBC vs Hibernate What's the difference with JPA?
body:
The key difference between JDBC Hibernate and JPA is that JDBC is a low level API while JPA is a specification and Hibernate is an ORM implementation of that specification

JDBC exposes Connection PreparedStatement and ResultSet and demands manual SQL writing object mapping resource cleanup and transaction control. This approach gives maximum control and predictable SQL behavior when performance tuning and complex native queries matter most

JPA defines a standard API around an object relational mapping model and lifecycle. Developers use annotations or XML to map domain classes to tables and rely on an EntityManager for CRUD and queries. JPA promotes portability across implementations

Hibernate implements JPA and supplies many extras such as second level cache HQL a rich query API lazy loading dirty checking and extensive mapping features. Hibernate reduces boilerplate and adds production grade capabilities that plain JPA alone may not cover

When to choose which Use JDBC when full SQL control minimal abstraction and raw performance are top priorities. Use JPA when a standardized ORM reduces boilerplate and improves developer productivity. Choose Hibernate when advanced caching custom types and a mature ecosystem matter more than strict portability

Quick examples

Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(url user password)

EntityManager em = entityManagerFactory.createEntityManager()

Summary Choose the right tool based on project goals. If SQL mastery and low level tuning are required pick JDBC. If clean domain models and faster development are desired pick JPA with Hibernate for extra features and optimizations

Tip

Measure common use cases before committing. Prototype a hot query with JDBC and then with Hibernate and compare execution plans memory usage and developer time. Real metrics beat ideology every time

title: How to deploy a WAR file to Tomcat using Maven
description: Step by step Maven guide to build a WAR and deploy that WAR to Tomcat with plugin setup build and common troubleshooting tips.
heading: How to deploy a WAR file to Tomcat using Maven
body:
This tutorial shows how to build a WAR with Maven and deploy that WAR to Apache Tomcat using the Tomcat Maven plugin or by copying the WAR into the Tomcat webapps folder.

  1. Prepare project and pom xml
  2. Add Tomcat Maven plugin and configure credentials
  3. Build the WAR with Maven
  4. Deploy using the plugin
  5. Manual deploy to Tomcat webapps
  6. Verify and troubleshoot deployment

Prepare project and pom xml

Confirm that packaging in pom xml is set to war and that webapp sources live under the standard webapp folder. Add standard web xml and required dependencies for the Java web application.

Add Tomcat Maven plugin and configure credentials

Edit pom xml to include the Tomcat Maven plugin and specify the manager URL and user credentials that have the manager role on the Tomcat server. Store credentials in Maven settings for safety rather than leaving secrets inside pom xml.

Build the WAR with Maven

Run mvn clean package to create the WAR artifact. The target folder will contain the WAR that will be deployed to the servlet container.

Deploy using the plugin

Invoke the plugin deploy goal to push the WAR to the Tomcat manager. If credential or role mismatch happens the manager will reject the upload so double check server and user configuration on the Tomcat side.

Manual deploy to Tomcat webapps

If plugin deployment feels like modern alchemy then copy the WAR file into the Tomcat webapps folder and let the server explode the archive and register the context. Restart Tomcat when necessary.

Verify and troubleshoot deployment

Check Tomcat logs for class loader errors missing dependencies or context path collisions. Common fixes include adding missing libs to the WAR or updating the context path in server configuration.

Recap of the tutorial shows how to prepare a Maven web project configure the Tomcat plugin build the WAR and deploy that WAR either via plugin or manual copy while watching logs for errors.

Tip

Use Maven profiles to separate production and testing deployment settings and keep manager credentials in the Maven settings file with server ids that match entries in pom xml.

title: How to deploy a WAR file to Apache Tomcat using Jenkins CI
description: Step by step guide to build a WAR and deploy to Apache Tomcat using Jenkins CI with pipeline setup credentials and deploy options
heading: How to deploy a WAR file to Apache Tomcat using Jenkins CI
body:
This tutorial teaches how to build a Java project produce a WAR file and deploy the WAR to Apache Tomcat using Jenkins CI.

  1. Set up Tomcat and manager access
  2. Install Jenkins and required plugins
  3. Create credentials and pipeline
  4. Build and archive the WAR
  5. Deploy the WAR to Tomcat

Set up Tomcat and manager access Ensure Tomcat includes the manager application and add a user with the manager role. Host the servlet container on a reachable machine and secure the manager endpoint by network rules.

Install Jenkins and required plugins Provision Jenkins and add the Deploy to container plugin or prepare SSH or REST access to the server. Plugin use is simpler for straightforward uploads.

Create credentials and pipeline Add username and password credentials in Jenkins for the Tomcat manager. Create a freestyle job or a declarative pipeline that checks out source code and runs a build tool to produce the WAR.

Build and archive the WAR Run a command such as mvn clean package to produce the artifact. Add an archive step so Jenkins retains the WAR for later deployment and troubleshooting.

Deploy the WAR to Tomcat Use the Deploy to container post build action or run a script that calls the Tomcat manager deployment endpoint with the stored credentials. The chosen method will upload the WAR and trigger a restart of the web application as required.

The guide covered configuring the servlet container creating a Jenkins job building a WAR artifact and deploying that artifact to Tomcat using either a plugin or a scripted call. Follow the steps and adjust credentials and host settings for the environment and security posture.

Tip

Use a Jenkins pipeline with credentials binding to avoid exposing passwords in logs. Limit manager access by network and use strong unique passwords. For frequent deployments consider automating health checks after deployment to catch regressions quickly.

title: How to install WordPress 5.x on Ubuntu with Bitnami
description: Step by step guide to install WordPress 5.x on Ubuntu using a Bitnami stack with commands and configuration tips for a smooth setup
heading: How to install WordPress 5.x on Ubuntu with Bitnami
body:
This tutorial shows how to install WordPress 5.x on Ubuntu using a Bitnami stack with step by step commands and practical configuration tips for a working site.

  1. Prepare the Ubuntu server
  2. Download the Bitnami WordPress installer
  3. Run the installer with proper permissions
  4. Configure ports and services
  5. Secure credentials and database
  6. Verify access and finalize

Prepare the Ubuntu server by updating packages and installing required system tools. Example commands include updating package lists and installing build tools. Proper time zone and locales help avoid future surprises.

Download the Bitnami WordPress installer to the server using a secure channel from the official source. Save the file in a predictable folder and check the checksum if a checksum is available. The installer file name usually includes WordPress version details for clarity.

Make the installer executable and run the installer as a local administrator. Example commands include chmod +x bitnami-wordpress-5.x.x-linux-x64.run and sudo ./bitnami-wordpress-5.x.x-linux-x64.run. Follow prompts for installation folder, administrator credentials, and optional components. The installer handles Apache and database setup by default so manual wiring is minimal.

Configure ports and services if default ports conflict with other applications. Bitnami uses common ports by default. Adjust Apache port values in the stack configuration files when necessary and use the system service manager to enable automatic start on reboot.

Secure credentials by choosing strong passwords for the WordPress administrator and database users. Restrict SSH access and apply basic firewall rules to permit only required traffic. Consider moving database access to local only when external database access is not required.

Verify access by opening the server address in a browser and logging into the WordPress dashboard. Test sample pages and permalink settings. Apply updates for plugins and themes through the dashboard to avoid compatibility problems with WordPress 5.x.

This tutorial covered preparing an Ubuntu server downloading and running the Bitnami WordPress installer configuring services securing credentials and verifying a working WordPress site. The goal was a clear path from a fresh server to a functioning WordPress dashboard without unnecessary drama.

Tip

Keep a copy of the Bitnami stack installation folder and a database export before major changes. That backup acts as a fast recovery option when updates or plugin experiments go sideways.

title: git stash name example
description: Learn how to name stashes in Git to save and find work in progress with clear commands and quick examples.
heading: git stash name example explained for clear stash management
body:
This tutorial shows how to create named stashes in Git so saving and recovering work in progress becomes less chaotic.

  1. Create a named stash
  2. List stashes to find names
  3. Inspect a stash before applying
  4. Apply or pop a named stash
  5. Create a branch from a stash

Create a named stash Use a message to describe the change so future brain cells can remember purpose. Example command is git stash push -m "wip add login form" which records the working tree and index with a human friendly label.

List stashes to find names Run git stash list to see entries such as stash@{0} On main wip add login form which gives a quick index and the message provided earlier.

Inspect a stash before applying Prefer a peek before merging unknown code into the working tree. Use git stash show -p stash@{0} to see the patch that the stash contains.

Apply or pop a named stash Apply without removing by using git stash apply stash@{0} or apply and remove with git stash pop stash@{0} when sure the change should be reintegrated.

Create a branch from a stash If the change grew into something bigger start a branch straight from the stash with git stash branch feature-login stash@{0} which checks out a new branch and applies the stashed change.

This tutorial covered naming stashes push with a message listing and inspecting stash contents and restoring changes either by applying popping or branching. Using clear messages keeps the stash list readable and saves debugging time later.

Tip

Use a short prefix for context such as feature user or fix and then a concise description. That makes git stash list instantly useful when multiple saved changes compete for attention.

title: What is the Hibernate SessionFactory? How do you build it?
description: Clear definition of Hibernate SessionFactory and practical steps to build one using Configuration and ServiceRegistry in Java
heading: What is the Hibernate SessionFactory How do you build it
body:
A Hibernate SessionFactory is a thread safe factory that stores configuration and produces Session objects for database work.

SessionFactory is the heavy weight bootstrap object for Hibernate. Create one per application or per database schema. Session objects are lightweight and created from the SessionFactory for each unit of work. SessionFactory holds compiled mapping metadata connection pooling settings and cache configuration so startup cost is higher than per operation cost.

Common reasons to understand SessionFactory include lifecycle management resource usage and performance tuning.

  1. Create a Configuration from file or programmatically
  2. Register entity classes and properties
  3. Build a ServiceRegistry from configuration properties
  4. Create the SessionFactory from the Configuration and ServiceRegistry

Step one uses a Configuration object that reads the standard XML file or accepts programmatic settings. Step two binds annotated classes or mapping files so Hibernate knows how to map Java classes to database tables. Step three constructs a StandardServiceRegistry with connection pool settings dialect and other properties. Step four calls the build method that produces the SessionFactory ready for use by application threads.

Example pseudo code without punctuation that breaks Java rules but shows the flow

Configuration cfg = new Configuration().configure() StandardServiceRegistry reg = new StandardServiceRegistryBuilder().applySettings(cfg.getProperties()).build() SessionFactory sessionFactory = cfg.buildSessionFactory(reg)

Remember to close the SessionFactory during application shutdown so connections and caches are released. During runtime open short lived Session objects per request or per transaction. Use transactions for data consistency and avoid sharing a Session across threads.

Tip

Prefer one SessionFactory per database and tune connection pool and second level cache rather than creating multiple SessionFactory instances for performance and resource reasons

title: How to add multiple git worktrees to your repo example
description: Quick guide to add multiple git worktrees so different branches can be worked on at once without checkout conflicts.
heading: How to add multiple git worktrees to your repo example
body:
This tutorial shows how to add multiple git worktrees so different branches can be worked on concurrently and without checkout friction.

  1. Prepare the repository
  2. Create a new worktree for a branch
  3. Work inside the new worktree
  4. Clean up when a worktree is no longer needed

Prepare the repository by making sure the repo has no uncommitted changes and that the desired branch exists or can be created. Use git status to confirm a clean working tree. If a branch must be created first use git branch feature-branch or create on the fly from a commit or remote.

Create a new worktree with the git worktree add command. For example run git worktree add ../feature-branch feature-branch from the main repo folder. That command makes a linked checkout in a sibling folder so both the main repo and the new folder can be used at the same time.

Work inside the new worktree like a normal clone. Files, commits and branch operations behave normally from inside the worktree folder. Use git status and git commit inside the new checkout. The main repo remains unaffected by local checkouts in other worktrees so context switching becomes less painful.

When a worktree is no longer needed remove the linked checkout with git worktree remove ../feature-branch and optionally prune stale links with git worktree prune. Make sure to delete or merge any branches that are no longer required to avoid orphaned references.

Using multiple worktrees speeds up multitasking because developers can run tests build tasks or editors in separate folders without constantly switching branches in the same working tree. This keeps workflows cleaner and reduces accidental commits on the wrong branch.

Tip

If juggling many branches give each worktree a clear folder name that matches the branch. This prevents confusion in shells editors and CI scripts and makes cleanup with git worktree prune less dramatic than a surprise missing folder.

title: A Hibernate 5 SchemaExport example
description: Learn how to programmatically create database tables with Hibernate 5 SchemaExport step by step code and practical tips for schema generation
heading: A Hibernate 5 SchemaExport example for programmatic table creation
body:
This tutorial shows how to use Hibernate 5 SchemaExport to programmatically generate database tables from annotated entity classes and Metadata.

  1. Add Hibernate dependency and configuration to the project
  2. Define entity classes with JPA annotations
  3. Create MetadataSources and build Metadata
  4. Configure and run SchemaExport to execute DDL against the database
  5. Verify tables and adjust mappings as needed

Step 1 Add Hibernate dependency and configuration. Use Maven or Gradle to include hibernate core and the JDBC driver for the target database. Provide connection properties in hibernate cfg or in code based Properties. Confirm database credentials and driver class name are correct before moving on.

Step 2 Define entity classes with JPA annotations. Annotate primary keys and relationships so the mapping represents the desired schema. Use sensible column definitions and lengths to avoid surprises when the database tries to store real data.

Step 3 Create MetadataSources and build Metadata. Boot the ServiceRegistry then feed annotated classes or mapping resources into MetadataSources. Call buildMetadata to produce a Metadata object that represents the full mapping model.

Step 4 Configure and run SchemaExport. Instantiate SchemaExport and set options such as output file format and whether to run DDL against the database. Call create or execute with the Metadata object to produce tables. Running in dry run mode allows previewing SQL before any schema changes occur.

Step 5 Verify tables in the database using a DB client or query tool. Check columns constraints and indexes. If something looks odd update the mapping then repeat the Metadata build and SchemaExport run until the schema matches expectations.

This guide covered preparing a project for SchemaExport defining entities building Metadata running SchemaExport and verifying the generated database schema. The whole point is to let Hibernate produce DDL so manual SQL writing becomes less frequent and less thrilling for those who enjoy debugging missing foreign keys.

Tip

Enable SQL logging and use a script output option on SchemaExport to preview generated DDL before applying changes to a production database. Version control mapping files for safe rollbacks.

title: Hibernate and JPA CRUD example with Hibernate 5.4 and JPA 2.
description: Compact tutorial showing Hibernate 5.4 and JPA 2.2 CRUD setup mapping configuration and DAO patterns for Java persistence
heading: Hibernate and JPA CRUD example with Hibernate 5.4 and JPA 2.2
body:
This tutorial shows how to build a CRUD application using Hibernate 5.4 and JPA 2.2 covering configuration entity mapping and DAO operations.

  1. Add dependencies and persistence configuration
  2. Define a JPA entity
  3. Create an EntityManagerFactory or SessionFactory
  4. Implement DAO CRUD methods
  5. Run tests and verify behavior

Add dependency management with Maven or Gradle and provide a persistence configuration file that declares a persistence unit and provider. The persistence unit ties the application to JDBC and provider settings so the persistence layer can breathe without drama.

Define a simple entity with an @Entity annotation and primary key mapping. The entity represents domain state and must include proper equals and hashCode for reliable behavior when the persistence context is involved.

Create an EntityManagerFactory for JPA use or a SessionFactory when preferring native Hibernate APIs. Use a bootstrap approach that handles lifecycle so the application can open and close resources without leaking memory or database connections.

Implement a DAO with methods for create find update and delete. Typical signatures include save findById findAll update and deleteById. Use transactions per operation and prefer a single transaction per logical unit of work so the database state remains predictable.

Run simple integration tests that bootstrap the persistence unit perform CRUD operations and assert expected results. Use an in memory database during development to get fast feedback and avoid dealing with production schema surprises while learning.

The example shows how configuration mapping and DAO code pieces connect to provide a maintainable persistence layer. The goal is clean separation between domain models and persistence mechanics so future changes to database vendor or schema cause minimal churn.

Summary the walkthrough covers dependency setup entity creation factory bootstrap DAO methods and verification steps needed to implement CRUD with Hibernate 5.4 and JPA 2.2 in a practical Java application.

Tip

Prefer EntityManager for standard JPA portability and use native Hibernate APIs only when needing vendor specific features. Keep transactions small and use integration tests with an in memory database for fast reliable feedback during development.

title: WildFly vs JBoss EAP How Red Hat Java servers compare
description: Compare WildFly and JBoss EAP differences performance support and use cases for Red Hat Java application servers
heading: WildFly vs JBoss EAP How Red Hat Java servers compare
body:
The key difference between WildFly and JBoss EAP is audience and support model

WildFly is the community driven server focused on fast releases modular design and developer agility. JBoss EAP is the commercial product with long term support certification and predictable patching from Red Hat.

Use cases differ. WildFly works well for microservices rapid prototyping and developers who enjoy upgrading often. JBoss EAP suits regulated environments enterprise deployments and teams that prefer vendor backed SLAs and certified stacks.

Performance and features overlap. Both implement Jakarta EE standards offer clustering management and security. Expect WildFly to deliver newer features sooner. Expect JBoss EAP to provide backported stability performance tuning and full lifecycle support.

Licensing and updates also differ. WildFly remains free and open source. JBoss EAP requires a subscription for commercial support and certified builds. That subscription brings access to Red Hat customer portal patches and formal compliance testing.

Migration strategy is simple. Develop against WildFly for speed then validate on JBoss EAP before large scale rollout. Configuration modules and deployment descriptors share much in common so migration often avoids major rewrites.

Quick checklist choose WildFly for experimentation choose JBoss EAP for critical production systems and vendor backed support

Tip

When planning a move to production run a parallel test on the supported EAP distribution to catch API differences and security policy gaps early

title: How to Edit Ubuntu's etc Hosts File by Example
description: Step by step guide to safely edit Ubuntu hosts file for local DNS mapping using terminal editors sudo and simple testing commands
heading: How to Edit Ubuntu's etc Hosts File by Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to edit the Ubuntu etc hosts file to map hostnames to IP addresses for local testing and override DNS responses.

  1. Open a terminal and back up the hosts file
  2. Edit the hosts file with elevated privileges
  3. Add or change hostname to IP mappings
  4. Save changes and reload name resolution if needed
  5. Verify the mapping works from the host

Step 1 Back up the file before making changes because accidental damage is a fast route to regret. Use sudo cp /etc/hosts /etc/hosts.bak to keep a clean fallback.

Step 2 Choose a terminal editor such as nano or vim. Example command sudo nano /etc/hosts. Elevated privileges are required because the file lives in a protected system path.

Step 3 Edit lines using the format IP_address hostname Example entry 127.0.0.1 example.local to point example.local to the loopback address. Place entries on their own lines and avoid duplicate hostnames on different lines.

Step 4 Save the file using editor commands. For nano press Control O then Control X. If the system uses a DNS cache flush for name resolution apply sudo systemd-resolve --flush-caches or restart the network manager with sudo systemctl restart NetworkManager when necessary.

Step 5 Verify the change from the host using ping -c 1 example.local or a browser for HTTP testing. Successful response shows the new mapping in effect. If the new mapping does not appear check for typos and duplicate entries and confirm that a local proxy or DNS service is not overriding the hosts file.

Summary This guide walked through backing up the hosts file editing with sudo adding hostname to IP mappings saving changes and verifying the result. The process is quick and powerful for local development and blocking or rerouting domains.

Tip

When testing use unique domain names that do not conflict with real domains. That avoids accidental routing of production traffic to the local machine and keeps debugging sane.

title: How to install GitLab on Ubuntu 20 without errors
description: Step by step guide to add the GitLab apt repo fix the unable to locate package issue and install GitLab on Ubuntu 20
heading: How to install GitLab on Ubuntu 20 without errors
body:
This guide shows how to add the official GitLab apt repository fix the unable to locate package problem and install GitLab on Ubuntu 20 in a reliable way

  1. Prepare the system and install dependencies
  2. Add the GitLab repository and key
  3. Update package lists
  4. Install the chosen GitLab package
  5. Set external address and run configuration

Prepare the system Install curl required certificates and the GPG tool to authenticate packages before touching the repository.

sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y curl ca-certificates gnupg

Add the GitLab repository Use the official install script to add the correct repositories for Ubuntu 20 and fetch the signing key. This avoids the usual error that signals missing sources.

curl httpspackages.gitlab.com/install/repositories/gitlab/gitlab-ce/script.deb.sh | sudo bash

Update package lists Run the package list refresh so apt knows about the new GitLab packages and their metadata.

sudo apt update

Install GitLab Choose one package name not both. For most users the community edition is fine. If a package still cannot be found check the repository file under /etc/apt and confirm the distribution codename is focal.

sudo apt install -y gitlab-ce

Configure GitLab Set the external address inside the configuration file then run the omnibus configuration to bootstrap services. This step prepares web and background services and can be noisy in a good way.

Open /etc/gitlab/gitlab.rb edit external_url to match the server address then run sudo gitlab-ctl reconfigure

The unable to locate package error usually means the GitLab repo was not added updated or the wrong distro codename was used. Adding the official repository running apt update and installing a single package name resolves most failures while leaving room for quiet celebration

Tip

If a package still looks missing run apt policy gitlab-ce to see available versions and which repository is providing the package. Avoid asking apt to install both gitlab ce and gitlab ee at the same time

title: How to create GitLab projects How to delete GitLab projects
description: Quick guide to create and delete GitLab projects using the web interface with safety steps and access control advice.
heading: How to create and delete GitLab projects
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a new GitLab project and how to remove a project safely using the web interface.

  1. Sign in to GitLab
  2. Create a new project
  3. Initialize repository and set visibility
  4. Manage members and permissions
  5. Delete a project with confirmation

Step 1 Sign in to GitLab

Open the GitLab web interface and authenticate with a user that has permission to create projects. Use a work account for company repositories and a personal account for experiments.

Step 2 Create a new project

Click the New Project button and choose a blank project or import an existing repository. Provide a name and optional description. Pick a namespace that matches the team or personal account.

Step 3 Initialize repository and set visibility

Add a README to seed the repository and choose public or private visibility based on sensitivity. Private is safer for code that should not be public.

Step 4 Manage members and permissions

Invite team members and assign roles such as Guest Reporter Developer Maintainer or Owner. Review access after adding members to avoid accidental broad permissions.

Step 5 Delete a project with confirmation

Go to the project Settings then General and scroll to the Advanced section. Use the Remove project control only after backing up any important data and confirming the project name when prompted.

This tutorial covered creating a GitLab project from the web interface including initialization and visibility choices and managing access and then removing a project with safety steps. Follow the steps to avoid accidental data loss and to keep repository access tidy.

Tip

Enable project export before deletion to preserve repository data and issues. Exports provide a safety copy that can be restored or archived outside of GitLab.

title: GitLab git clone example
description: Step by step guide to clone a GitLab repository to a local machine using git clone with SSH and HTTPS tips for smooth setup
heading: GitLab git clone example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to clone a GitLab repository to a local machine using the git clone command and basic access options.

  1. Locate the repository URL on GitLab
  2. Choose SSH or HTTPS access
  3. Run the clone command
  4. Verify the cloned repository

Locate the repository URL Use the project page on GitLab and open the Clone menu. Copy the URL labeled for the chosen access method. The chosen URL will be used by the clone command so pick carefully unless chaos is desired.

Choose SSH or HTTPS access SSH avoids repeated password prompts when an SSH key is added to the GitLab profile. HTTPS is simpler for one off clones and works with username and personal access token when required.

Run the clone command Open a terminal in the desired parent folder and run the clone command. Example command git clone REPO_URL Replace REPO_URL with the copied URL. If authentication fails follow the error message to fix credentials or key setup.

Verify the cloned repository Change into the new folder and list files to confirm a successful copy. Run basic git commands like git status to confirm branch and remote settings.

The tutorial covered finding the repository URL on GitLab choosing the right access method running the git clone command and checking the resulting local repository. These steps get a repository from remote hosting to a working local copy with minimal drama.

Tip

Prefer SSH for frequent pushes and pulls. Add an SSH key to the GitLab profile and use an SSH agent locally. That avoids typing credentials and looks marginally more professional.

title: GitLab commit push to origin example
description: Step by step GitLab example for committing and pushing to origin with clear commands and common gotchas for new Git users
heading: GitLab commit push to origin example
body:
This tutorial shows how to commit changes and push to origin on a GitLab repository using basic git commands.

  1. Make changes in the working directory
  2. Stage the changes
  3. Create a commit with a message
  4. Push the commit to origin on the target branch
  5. Verify the update on GitLab

Make changes in the working directory Use a favorite editor to modify files in the repository. No ritual required. Save changes and move on when ready.

Stage the changes Use staging to control what goes into the next commit. Common command for quick staging is

git add .

Create a commit with a message A clear message helps future humans and the version control system understand the purpose of the change. Example command

git commit -m 'Describe the change'

Push the commit to origin on the target branch Push sends local commits to the remote named origin. Replace branchname with the active branch name. Example command

git push origin branchname

Verify the update on GitLab Open the project page on GitLab and check commits or the repository tree. If the commit does not appear check remote settings and branch name with

git remote -v

Common gotchas include forgetting to stage files missing a dot in the add command and working on a different branch than expected. Also ensure authentication is configured if prompting appears. A little attention now saves confusing blame later.

Recap of the process shows a simple flow from local edit to remote update using add commit and push commands followed by a quick verification on the GitLab web interface.

Tip

Use git status before committing to see staged files and branch name. This small habit prevents most accidental pushes and avoids the classic blame game.

title: Delete folder in Ubuntu example How to remove a directory
description: Learn how to remove a directory recursively in Ubuntu using rm and safer methods including sudo and trash cli for safer deletion in the terminal
heading: Delete folder in Ubuntu example How to remove a directory
body:
This tutorial shows how to remove a directory recursively from the Ubuntu terminal using the rm command and safer alternatives.

  1. Verify target directory
  2. Run recursive remove command
  3. Use elevated permissions when needed
  4. Use a safe trash method when unsure

Verify target directory Confirm current path with pwd and list contents with ls -la to make sure the correct directory is targeted. Mistakes here become regrets.

Run recursive remove command Use rm -r foldername to remove a directory and all files inside. Add -f for force but know that force suppresses prompts and can remove more than desired.

Use elevated permissions when needed If permission errors occur run sudo rm -r foldername. Root permission bypasses restrictions so double check the path before pressing enter.

Use a safe trash method when unsure Install a trash tool with sudo apt update and sudo apt install trash-cli then move a folder to the trash with trash-put foldername. Another safer option is interactive mode with rm -ri foldername which asks for confirmation for each file.

Summary The steps covered how to confirm the target directory run recursive removal handle permissions and use a trash approach for safety. Follow these steps to avoid accidental deletion and to keep a calm chest while working in the terminal.

Tip

Run ls -R foldername to review the full folder contents before running a removal command and consider taking a quick backup with cp -r foldername foldername_backup for extra peace of mind.

title: Essential Git GitLab commands The 8 you must know
description: Quick guide to the eight essential GitLab command line commands every developer should master with clear examples and practical tips
heading: Essential Git GitLab commands The 8 you must know
body:
This tutorial teaches the eight essential Git and GitLab command line actions every developer should master for daily workflows.

  1. git clone REPO_URL clone a repository
  2. git status see working tree state
  3. git add FILES stage changes
  4. git commit -m "message" record staged changes
  5. git push send commits to remote
  6. git pull fetch and merge from remote
  7. git branch and git checkout create and switch branches
  8. git merge BRANCH bring changes together

git clone copies a remote repository to the local machine. Use a placeholder REPO_URL in examples when not sharing actual addresses. This command gives a working copy without extra ceremony.

git status shows staged and unstaged changes plus the current branch. Run the command before any other action to avoid awkward surprises during a code review.

git add moves changes into the staging area. Stage only the files that belong in the next commit rather than dragging every typo along for the ride.

git commit packages staged changes with a message. Keep messages short and useful because future self will judge past self mercilessly.

git push uploads local commits to the remote repository. Use push after commits to share progress with teammates and continuous integration pipelines.

git pull fetches new remote commits and merges them into the current branch. Use the command often to avoid merge parties that look like disaster recovery drills.

git branch lists or creates branches while git checkout switches context. Prefer descriptive branch names so the story of a feature is obvious without detective work.

git merge combines another branch into the current branch. Resolve conflicts carefully and run tests before pushing merged results upstream.

The steps above form a minimal workflow that keeps work local safe and changes shared in a controlled manner. Mastering these commands removes most friction from daily development and makes collaboration less of a gamble.

Tip

Use frequent commits with focused messages and pull before pushing to reduce conflicts. If unsure about a risky change create a temporary branch and experiment there rather than risking the main branch.

title: How to Write a Git Commit Messages Properly with Examples
description: Clear rules and examples for writing concise Git commit messages that help code review and history reading
heading: How to Write a Git Commit Messages Properly with Examples
body:
This tutorial teaches how to write clear concise Git commit messages that help code review and historical traceability.

  1. Write a short imperative subject line under 50 characters
  2. Separate subject and body with a blank line
  3. Describe why a change was made not only what changed
  4. Wrap body text around 72 characters and use bullets for details
  5. Reference issue numbers and note breaking changes
  6. Keep commits focused and atomic

Short subject line The subject line is the elevator pitch. Use present tense verbs such as Add Fix Update Remove. Example git commit -m "Add user login handler" shows the expected tone and clarity.

Separate subject and body A blank line after the subject keeps message viewers and tools happy. The subject remains a glanceable summary while the body holds the story.

Explain the why Reviewers care about motivation more than a literal diff. A sentence or two explaining why the change was needed prevents future confusion and blame games.

Wrap and structure Wrap body lines near 72 characters so history tools display nicely. Use short bullet lines when listing related changes or consequences.

Reference tracking systems Add a ticket or issue reference when relevant. Use a short phrase like Closes 123 to make automation happy and reduce manual follow up.

Small focused commits One concern per commit makes bisecting and reverting painless. Massive commits filled with unrelated fixes create regret and long nights.

Applying these steps will produce commit messages that help teammates review and future maintainers understand the code history. Consistent style reduces friction during code review and makes automated tools more useful.

Tip

Use a commit message template or a pre commit hook to enforce subject length and require a body when a change touches multiple files. That prevents the tragic one liner that haunts repositories.

title: GitLab branch and branch permissions example
description: Learn how to create protected branches and configure branch permissions in GitLab to control who can push and merge.
heading: GitLab branch and branch permissions example
body:
This tutorial walks through creating protected branches and configuring branch permissions in GitLab so teams can control who can push and who can merge.

  1. Create a feature branch from the main branch
  2. Protect the new branch in project settings
  3. Set push and merge roles for the branch
  4. Test access using different user roles
  5. Use merge requests and required approvals

Step 1 Create a feature branch Create a local branch with a clear name and push to the remote repository. Example command git checkout -b feature/awesome followed by git push -u origin feature/awesome. Branch naming that reflects purpose reduces confusion later.

Step 2 Protect the new branch Open the project settings and go to the repository section. Add the branch under protected branches so that direct pushes can be blocked and only allowed roles can perform merges. Protecting the main line of development prevents accidental chaos.

Step 3 Set push and merge roles Choose which roles can push and which roles can merge. Typical setup allows Maintainers to push and Developers to create merge requests. For stricter control allow only Maintainers to push and require Developer approval for merges where required.

Step 4 Test access using different user roles Use a test account with Developer access and another with Guest access. Attempt a push and observe permission denied messages when the role does not have push rights. Testing confirms that the rules behave as expected before real work depends on those rules.

Step 5 Use merge requests and required approvals Require merge requests for protected branches and enable approval rules. Require a successful pipeline before merging to ensure code quality. Merge requests provide an audit trail and enforce code review workflows.

The guide covered branch creation protection role based push and merge restrictions testing and use of merge requests to enforce review and pipeline checks. Following these steps will give the development team predictable control over the repository and reduce accidental changes to critical branches.

Tip

Use branch name patterns and require pipeline success before merge. That combination prevents broken main and keeps the CI history useful when debugging who introduced a regression.

title: Create a new GitLab branch in BASH example
description: Learn how to create and push a new GitLab branch from BASH using git commands and simple automation steps for a clean developer workflow
heading: Create a new GitLab branch in BASH example
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a new GitLab branch from BASH using standard git commands so a developer can automate branch creation and push a local branch to a remote project.

  1. Prepare environment and authentication
  2. Create a local branch
  3. Push the branch to GitLab and set upstream
  4. Verify branch presence on the remote

Prepare environment and authentication by confirming a valid SSH key or HTTPS credentials are configured for the GitLab project. Store any personal access token in a secure place such as a protected environment variable and avoid pasting tokens into public logs.

Create a local branch with a descriptive name that follows team conventions. Use a command like git checkout -b feature/my-new-feature when starting a new task. Branch naming prevents confusion during reviews and merges.

Push the branch to GitLab and set the upstream branch so future pushes are shorter. Use a command such as git push --set-upstream origin feature/my-new-feature to create the remote branch and link local tracking. This saves time when running plain git push later on.

Verify branch presence on the remote by listing remote branches with git fetch followed by git branch -r or by checking the project web interface. A quick check avoids surprise merge conflicts and wasted review cycles.

Automation can be added by wrapping commands in a short BASH script that validates branch name format checks for uncommitted changes and runs the push sequence. That script brings consistency and less manual fiddling when multiple developers work on the same project.

The walkthrough covered preparing credentials creating a local branch pushing that branch to the remote and verifying presence on GitLab. Use the pattern shown to reduce mistakes and speed up developer workflows while keeping a small amount of discipline around branch names and authentication.

Tip

Use git status --porcelain in a script to detect uncommitted changes before branch creation and refuse to proceed when the working tree is dirty. That prevents accidental inclusion of unrelated changes.

title: GitLab merge request example
description: Quick guide to creating reviewing and merging a GitLab merge request with commands and best practices for a clean workflow
heading: GitLab merge request example step by step guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to create review and merge a GitLab merge request while keeping a clean workflow and passing CI checks.

  1. Create a feature branch
  2. Make commits and push
  3. Open a merge request
  4. Run CI and review
  5. Merge and clean up

Create a feature branch Start from a stable main branch then run git checkout -b feature/name to create the working branch. Pick a descriptive branch name to avoid comments from confused teammates.

Make commits and push Make focused commits with clear messages then push using git push -u origin feature/name. Pushing triggers the GitLab pipeline so tests run automatically.

Open a merge request In GitLab open a new merge request from the feature branch to the target branch. Add a concise title a helpful description and link to the related issue for context.

Run CI and review Fix pipeline failures first then request reviewers. Use code suggestions inline and keep discussions threaded to avoid losing feedback in unrelated chats.

Merge and clean up After approvals and a passing pipeline use the Merge button. Remove the feature branch locally with git branch -d feature/name and remotely with git push origin --delete feature/name to keep the repository tidy.

This guide covered the flow from creating a branch through opening reviewing and merging a GitLab merge request and cleaning up leftover branches for a smoother team workflow.

Tip

Prefer squash merges when a single logical change is desired in history and configure protected branches to block merges when pipelines fail.

title: merge develop into master in GitLab example
description: Merge develop into master using GitLab merge requests with CI checks reviews conflict resolution and release tagging
heading: merge develop into master in GitLab example
body:
This tutorial shows a quick practical workflow to merge a develop branch into master using GitLab merge requests and common command line steps.

  1. Create a merge request from develop into master
  2. Run and check CI pipelines
  3. Request review and obtain approvals
  4. Resolve any merge conflicts
  5. Perform the merge in GitLab or locally
  6. Tag master and push a release

Create a merge request using the GitLab web UI. Choose develop as source and master as target. Add a clear title and a short description of the changes so reviewers do not fall asleep.

Check CI pipelines that run on the merge request. Wait for green status before merging. Use job logs to diagnose failures and re-run failing jobs when needed.

Assign reviewers and request approvals. Keep review comments focused on behavior and tests. Small focused reviews get merged faster and cause fewer arguments.

If merge conflicts occur fetch the latest master and resolve locally by rebasing or merging. Example commands look like git fetch origin git checkout develop git rebase origin/master or git merge origin/master followed by conflict resolution and git push.

Use the merge button in GitLab to perform a fast forward or a merge commit depending on project policy. Alternatively create the merge locally and push the merge commit with commands such as git checkout master git merge develop git push origin master.

Create a release tag on master to mark the new state. Use a tag command like git tag -a v1.2.3 -m 'release' and push with git push origin v1.2.3 or use the GitLab release UI for a nicer page.

This guide walked through creating a merge request from develop into master running CI getting reviews resolving conflicts and merging via the UI or command line then tagging master for release. Following this workflow helps keep master stable and reduces surprise bugs during deployment.

Tip

Enable required approvals and pipeline status checks on protected branches so merges only happen after tests pass and at least one reviewer signs off. Consider using merge trains or pipelines for merge requests to prevent broken builds reaching master.

title: A GitLab merge branch to master example
description: Step by step guide to merging a GitLab branch into master with commands merge request workflow and CI tips
heading: A GitLab merge branch to master example
body:
This tutorial shows how to merge a feature branch into master on GitLab using merge requests and CI checks.

  1. Prepare the branch locally
  2. Push the branch to GitLab
  3. Create a merge request
  4. Run and fix CI pipeline
  5. Merge into master
  6. Cleanup the branch

Prepare the branch locally by keeping the feature branch up to date with the master branch and running tests before any remote push. Use a descriptive commit message and squash if the repository prefers tidy history.

Push the branch to GitLab so that the merge request can be opened. Example commands in a local repository are git push origin feature-branch after confirming the branch contains the desired commits.

Create a merge request through the GitLab UI. Pick target branch master and assign reviewers. Add a clear description of the change and reference any issue numbers. Expect at least one reviewer to request minor edits because code reviews enjoy making lives interesting.

Run and fix the CI pipeline that GitLab triggers on the merge request. Inspect failed jobs and address the exact test errors or linter complaints. Recommit and push the fixes until the pipeline passes and the reviewers are satisfied.

Merge into master using the merge button in GitLab after approvals and green pipeline status. Choose the merge method that matches repository rules. If required perform a fast forward or merge commit locally with commands like git checkout master git pull origin master git merge feature-branch git push origin master.

Cleanup the branch by deleting the remote branch from GitLab after merge and removing the local branch with git branch -d feature-branch. Archive or tag the release if that is part of the workflow.

This guide walked through preparing a branch running CI creating a merge request handling reviews merging into master and cleaning up. The goal is a predictable and reviewable process that avoids surprise regressions and maintains a clean history.

Tip

Require a passing pipeline before merge and add a merge request template that lists checks to run. That reduces back and forth and makes reviewers feel useful without creating chaos.

title: GitLab merge master to branch example
description: Step by step guide to merge master into a branch on GitLab with commands conflict tips and push best practices
heading: GitLab merge master to branch example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to merge master into a feature branch using GitLab and the command line.

  1. Fetch and update local master
  2. Switch to the target branch
  3. Merge master into the target branch
  4. Resolve conflicts if present
  5. Run tests and linters
  6. Push branch and open a merge request

Fetch and update local master Use the local repository to obtain the latest origin master before any merge. Common commands are git checkout master and git pull origin master. Fresh master reduces surprise conflicts and prevents heroic undoing later.

Switch to the target branch Move to the feature branch that needs the updates. Use git checkout feature-branch or git switch feature-branch. Confirm current branch with git status.

Merge master into the target branch Perform the merge with git merge master while on the feature branch. This brings master changes into ongoing work so the branch stays compatible with mainline development.

Resolve conflicts if present Conflicts happen when two changes touch the same code. Open conflicted files edit choices then mark resolution with git add and conclude with git commit. Keep messages clear about conflict resolution to help reviewers.

Run tests and linters Local checks catch regression introduced by the merge. Run unit tests and static analysis before pushing. Fix failures locally to avoid noisy pipelines on GitLab.

Push branch and open a merge request Push merged branch with git push origin feature-branch. Create a merge request on GitLab and describe merge rationale and testing performed. Mention any manual steps reviewers should try.

This tutorial covered updating local master checking out the target branch merging master into that branch resolving conflicts running validation and pushing the merged branch to GitLab for review. Following the steps keeps branches aligned with master and reduces painful surprises during final integration.

Tip

Prefer small frequent merges from master into long lived branches. Smaller merges mean simpler conflicts and faster reviews. Use feature toggles when risky code changes need late integration.

title: GitLab delete branch example
description: Delete branches in GitLab from web UI local and remote with safe steps verification and tips
heading: GitLab delete branch example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to delete branches in GitLab safely from the web interface and from the command line with verification steps.

  1. Delete from the GitLab web interface
  2. Remove the remote branch with a git command
  3. Clean up the local branch
  4. Check protection and verify removal

Delete from the GitLab web interface Navigate to the project Branches page find the branch name and use the Delete option to remove the branch from the remote repository. This method is visual and helpful when cleaning up branches created from merge requests.

Remove the remote branch with a git command Use the following command to remove a branch from the remote named origin.

git push origin --delete feature-branch

This command tells the remote to drop the branch reference so the branch no longer appears for other collaborators.

Clean up the local branch After remote removal delete the local copy to keep the working environment tidy. Preferred safe delete uses a lowercase d which refuses to remove branches with unmerged changes.

git branch -d feature-branch

Use a capital D to force removal when the branch has not been merged and the developer accepts potential data loss.

Check protection and verify removal Protected branches prevent accidental deletion. If a branch is protected unprotect the branch first from the project settings or use project admin access to remove protection before deletion. Verify removal by listing remote branches or checking the Branches page.

Recap follow three simple flows to remove branches safely from GitLab. Use the web interface for quick cleanup use the git push command to remove the remote reference and use git branch commands to clean local copies. Always check branch protection settings before trying a delete operation to avoid surprises.

Tip

Tip Give branch names a clear prefix such as feature slash bugfix slash wip to make bulk cleanup easier and run a dry run by listing remote branches before any destructive command.

title: GitLab delete branch remote example
description: Delete a remote branch in GitLab using git push or the web UI with verification and pruning tips for a clean repo.
heading: GitLab delete branch remote example step by step
body:
This tutorial shows how to delete a remote branch in GitLab from the command line and from the GitLab web UI.

  1. Fetch and list remote branches
  2. Delete the remote branch with git
  3. Delete the branch from the GitLab web UI
  4. Verify removal and prune local references

Start by syncing local refs with the remote. Run git fetch origin --prune and then list remote heads with git branch -r. This avoids surprises from stale names that no longer exist on the server.

To remove a branch from the remote run git push origin --delete BRANCH_NAME. An older alternative that still works is git push origin BRANCH_NAME. The first form reads better at morning stand ups and will make coworkers think there is control here.

To remove a branch via the GitLab web interface navigate to the project repository branches page and click the delete button next to the branch name. This is useful when the environment requires web level review or when a human prefers a button over typing commands.

After deletion confirm absence with git ls-remote --heads origin BRANCH_NAME and run git fetch origin --prune again to clean local references. Also remove any local branch with git branch -d BRANCH_NAME if the branch was merged or git branch -D BRANCH_NAME for forced removal.

Recap of the process Delete remote branch with a push command or use the GitLab web UI then prune and remove local references to keep the repo tidy. This avoids confusion and prevents old branch names from haunting future deploys.

Tip

Protect important branches with branch protection rules in GitLab to prevent accidental deletion and consider naming conventions that make stale branches easy to find.

title: Create a GitLab tag example
description: Quick guide to creating a GitLab tag using the web interface and git CLI for releases and CI deployment
heading: Create a GitLab tag example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a GitLab tag using the web UI and the git CLI for release labeling and CI triggers

  1. Create a tag from the GitLab web interface
  2. Create an annotated tag locally and push
  3. Create a signed tag for verification
  4. Use tags to trigger CI and create releases

Create a tag from the GitLab web interface by opening the repository and choosing Repository then Tags then New tag in a delightful maze of clicks. Pick a tag name such as v1.0 choose a target branch or commit and add a message for humans who prefer context over mystery.

Create an annotated tag locally when command line power is desired. Run git tag -a v1.0 -m 'Release 1.0' to attach a message that shows up in GitLab. Push the single tag with git push origin v1.0 or push multiple tags with git push origin --tags. Annotated tags carry author data and a timestamp that actually helps during audits.

Create a signed tag when security concerns exist. Use GPG signing with the command git tag -s v1.0 -m 'Signed release' and then push the signed tag. Signed tags provide provenance and reassure humans who demand proof that a release came from a trusted source.

Use tags to trigger CI pipelines and to publish a Release in GitLab. Configure GitLab CI rules to run for tags or use the Releases page to attach binaries and change notes. Tags are the bridge between code snapshots and delivery workflows so avoid treating tagging as optional drama.

Recap of the flow Create a tag via web UI for quick edits create annotated tags locally for richer metadata sign tags when verification matters and push tags so CI and release features can pick up the new version

Tip

Prefer annotated tags for public releases and sign tags when security matters. Put changelog highlights in the tag message so future humans do not have to guess why a version existed

title: Why the keyword const in Java is unimplemented explained
description: Why Java never implemented the keyword const and how final and design tradeoffs solved the use cases for safe variable binding
heading: Why the keyword const in Java is unimplemented explained
body:
Java once considered adding the keyword const but never implemented the keyword

The short version is design ambiguity and low incremental value compared with existing features. The Java language faced a question about what const would mean for primitive values references and mutable objects. A single keyword that promised immutability needed a precise semantic for binding versus deep immutability and for behavior with arrays generics and reflection.

The Java Language Specification reserved the word const early on to avoid breaking code but left the feature unimplemented because semantics were messy. Developers already had final for variable binding and for fields. final prevents reassignment of a variable or field but does not freeze the object referenced. Many proposals for const tried to promise deep immutability which adds copying or runtime checks and surprises for library authors.

Consider common use cases. For wanting a variable that cannot be rebound final is sufficient. For wanting an object that cannot change use immutable types such as String or design patterns based on encapsulation. For read only views use wrappers from standard libraries or third party libraries that provide persistent immutable collections.

The decision also reflected backward compatibility and minimalism. Adding a keyword with unclear guarantees risks fragmentation of code and inconsistent expectations across developers and tools. The Java team chose to keep the language simpler and rely on final plus libraries and future features to cover use cases.

That choice led to less confusion at runtime and clearer migration paths. If deep immutability becomes a must have richer language constructs or ergonomics could arrive in a compatible manner.

Tip

Use final for binding guarantees and prefer immutable types for object safety. When deep immutability is required use immutable collections or libraries that enforce structural immutability rather than searching for a phantom const keyword

title: Top Joe Rogan JRE podcasts for programmers and developers

title: The git submodule add example
description: Compact guide to using git submodule add with commands steps and tips for adding and managing nested repositories.
heading: The git submodule add example Guide
body:
This article shows how to use git submodule add to embed one repository inside another for clear dependency management and easier collaboration.

  1. Prepare the parent repository
  2. Add the submodule
  3. Commit the changes
  4. Clone with submodules
  5. Update and manage the submodule

Step 1 Prepare the parent repository

Make sure the parent repository exists and that the working tree is clean. Run git status to verify. Choose a directory path where the nested repository will live and confirm access to the remote repository that will be added.

Step 2 Add the submodule

Run git submodule add REPO_URL PATH where REPO_URL is the remote and PATH is the folder name inside the parent. This creates a .gitmodules file and a link to the nested repository. Yes this creates a mini repository inside a bigger repository like Russian dolls for developers.

Step 3 Commit the changes

Stage the .gitmodules file and the new folder then commit. Example commands are git add .gitmodules PATH and git commit -m "Add submodule". Push the parent repository so teammates can see the new reference.

Step 4 Clone with submodules

When cloning the parent repository use git clone --recurse-submodules REPO to fetch nested repositories automatically. If the clone already happened run git submodule update --init --recursive to pull the submodule content.

Step 5 Update and manage the submodule

To advance the nested repository fetch and checkout inside the submodule folder then commit the new reference in the parent. Commands like cd PATH then git fetch and git checkout BRANCH are typical. Back in the parent run git add PATH and git commit -m "Update submodule".

Recap this guide covered adding a submodule with the add command managing the .gitmodules file cloning with nested content and updating the nested repository reference so the parent stays consistent.

Tip

Prefer --recurse-submodules when cloning to avoid confusion. Treat submodules like separate projects and push changes from inside the nested repository before updating the parent reference.

title: Add git submodules to GitHub example
description: Step by step guide to add git submodules to a GitHub repo and manage updates clones and removal
heading: Add git submodules to GitHub example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to add a git submodule to a GitHub repository and keep subproject references clean.

  1. Prepare main repository and choose a subproject
  2. Add the submodule to the main repository
  3. Commit submodule config and push to remote
  4. Clone or update with submodules on other machines
  5. Update or remove a submodule when needed

Prepare Ensure working tree is clean and pick a subproject repository and a path inside the main repository where the subproject will live.

Add Run a submodule add command with a repository URL placeholder and a path. This creates a .gitmodules file and a pointer inside the repository.

git submodule add REPO_URL PATH

Commit Stage the .gitmodules file and the new path then commit and push so the remote knows about the submodule reference.

git add .gitmodules PATH

git commit -m "Add submodule"

Clone or update When cloning elsewhere use a submodule init and update sequence to fetch the subproject repositories and check out referenced commits.

git clone REPO_URL

git submodule update --init --recursive

Manage updates To change the subproject state enter the submodule folder fetch or checkout a branch then update the main repository pointer by committing the changed submodule path.

cd PATH

git fetch

git checkout BRANCH

cd ..

git add PATH

git commit -m "Update submodule"

Removal Remove entries from .gitmodules remove the cached path and clean leftover git modules then commit the change.

This guide covered adding a submodule creating the .gitmodules file committing changes cloning with submodules and updating or removing a submodule when the architecture changes. The main repository keeps only a pointer to subproject commits so subproject history stays separate and manageable.

Tip

Track a branch inside the submodule with a configuration or script to avoid surprise detached HEADs and always update the main repository after bumping the submodule commit. Trust but verify the referenced commit before pushing to shared remotes.

title: gitlab add submodule example
description: Step by step GitLab submodule tutorial for adding and updating submodules with practical tips and common fixes
heading: gitlab add submodule example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to add a Git submodule to a GitLab repository using the command line and common workflows.

  1. Choose target repository and local path
  2. Add the submodule from the parent repository
  3. Commit and push the parent repository
  4. Clone and populate submodules for other users or CI
  5. Update submodule pointer when the child repository moves forward

Decide which repository will act as the child and pick a path inside the parent repository. The chosen folder becomes the mount point for the child repository so pick a name that humans can tolerate later.

Add the submodule by running git submodule add [repo-url] [path] from the root of the parent repository. This action creates a .gitmodules file and records the exact commit of the child repository that the parent will track.

Stage and commit the new files with commands such as git add .gitmodules [path] and git commit -m Add submodule. Push the commit to the remote on GitLab so teammates do not stare at missing folders and assume sabotage.

When another developer clones the parent repository run git clone [repo-url] then git submodule update --init --recursive to fetch child repositories. This prevents the classic phantom folder problem that ruins a Monday morning.

To move the submodule forward enter the submodule folder and fetch or checkout the desired commit then return to the parent repository and commit the changed submodule pointer. Push both commits so the remote shows the new relationship.

This guide covered choosing the child repository adding the submodule committing and pushing cloning with submodules and updating pointers. Follow these steps for predictable behavior and fewer surprises when managing nested repositories.

Tip

Use relative URLs in the .gitmodules file when parent and child live on the same host so clones and CI runners do not break due to account changes. Also pin submodule commits in CI to keep builds reproducible.

title: How to Use the Git Submodule Init and Update Command by Exam
description: Learn how to initialize and update Git submodules with commands and examples to fetch nested repositories and keep them synced
heading: How to Use Git Submodule Init and Update Commands by Example
body:
This short guide teaches how to initialize and update Git submodules so nested repositories are checked out and kept in sync.

  1. Initialize submodules with git submodule init
  2. Fetch and checkout submodule content with git submodule update
  3. Clone or update with recursion to handle nested submodules

Initialize submodules This step configures local submodule mapping from the superproject configuration file and prepares the working tree for submodule content. Run git submodule init in the superproject to register submodule paths in the local Git config. This does not fetch any data so no surprise network traffic yet.

Fetch and checkout The update command downloads the commits referenced by the superproject and checks out the recorded commit inside the submodule working tree. Use git submodule update to sync submodule versions with the superproject. To combine setup and fetch use git submodule update --init --recursive and handle nested submodules in one go.

Clone and keep recursion When cloning a project with submodules prefer recursion to avoid manual steps. Use git clone --recurse-submodules < repo-url> on first checkout. For an existing clone run git submodule update --init --recursive to pull missing submodule content. Note that submodules record exact commits so branch updates require additional commands such as entering the submodule and fetching branches or using --remote options.

Summary of the tutorial The process covers registering submodules locally initializing data fetching and checking out the recorded states and using recursive options to handle nested submodules. These commands remove most of the mystery and reduce manual fiddling when working with nested repositories.

Tip

Tip Run git submodule status to see which submodules are detached or out of sync and use git submodule update --init --recursive as a one line cure for missing nested content.

title: How to Use the Git Submodule Update Command by Example
description: Learn how to use git submodule update with init recursive and remote flags and fix common detached HEAD and sync problems.
heading: How to Use the Git Submodule Update Command by Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to run and troubleshoot the git submodule update command with practical examples and common flags.

  1. Initialize submodules after clone
  2. Update submodules to recorded commits
  3. Pull newer branch tips from submodule remotes
  4. Recover from detached HEAD states
  5. Run maintenance across all submodules

Initialize submodules

After cloning a repository that uses submodules run git submodule init followed by git submodule update --init --recursive. That registers submodule entries and checks out nested content. This step saves future confusion when directories look empty or contain only metadata.

Update to recorded commits

To move every submodule to the commit recorded by the parent repository use git submodule update. The command ensures each submodule matches the exact SHA expected by the parent repository so builds remain reproducible.

Track branch tips from remotes

When the goal is to follow a branch rather than a fixed commit use git submodule update --remote --merge. That fetches from the submodule remote and merges the tracked branch so submodule stays current with upstream work.

Recover detached HEAD

Sometimes submodule folders end up in detached HEAD state after cloning. Change directory into the submodule and run git checkout main or check out the desired branch. Then run git submodule update --init --recursive again to align the working tree with the parent repository.

Maintenance across all submodules

Use git submodule foreach "git fetch && git checkout main && git pull" to execute commands inside every submodule. This helps keep submodule remotes synchronized and reduces surprises during builds.

Recap of the workflow use initialization for new clones update to recorded SHAs follow remotes when needed and fix detached HEAD situations with a checkout and an update. These steps keep monorepos with nested projects sane and predictable while saving time on manual fixes.

Tip

Declare a branch in .gitmodules with branch = main for submodules that should follow a branch and then use git submodule update --remote to pull those branch updates automatically.

title: How to git submodule tutorial
description: Learn how to add manage and update git submodule with clear steps and examples for reliable nested repositories and cleaner workflows
heading: How to git submodule tutorial guide
body:
This tutorial teaches how to add manage and update git submodule inside a parent repository so nested repositories behave without drama.

  1. Add a submodule
  2. Initialize and fetch submodule data
  3. Clone including submodules
  4. Update and change submodule commits
  5. Remove a submodule cleanly

Add a submodule

Choose a path inside the parent repository and run a command with a remote placeholder. Example command form is shown for clarity.

git submodule add REPO_URL PATH

Initialize and fetch submodule data

After adding or after checking out a branch with submodule references run initialization so the nested repository gets registered and downloaded.

git submodule init

git submodule update

Clone including submodules

When cloning a project with nested repositories include submodule population in one go to avoid surprises during build or test steps.

git clone REPO_URL

git submodule update --init --recursive

Update and change submodule commits

Enter the submodule folder switch to the desired branch pull or checkout a commit then return to the parent repository and stage the change to the recorded submodule commit.

cd PATH

git checkout BRANCH

git pull

cd ..

git add PATH

git commit -m "Update submodule reference"

Remove a submodule cleanly

Remove the directory deinitialize the reference and remove the entry from configuration and from the index to avoid ghost directories.

Summary paragraph that recaps the flow and purpose of this tutorial and why submodule can be useful for shared components while also adding some complexity to dependency management.

Tip

Keep submodule commits pinned to a known good commit and document the workflow in the parent repository to avoid surprises for teammates who prefer fewer surprises.

title: Ubuntu git clone example
description: Quick guide to clone a Git repository on Ubuntu with command line examples SSH and HTTPS tips and basic troubleshooting
heading: Ubuntu git clone example command line guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to clone a Git repository on Ubuntu from the command line and covers installation configuration cloning methods and basic troubleshooting.

  1. Install Git
  2. Configure user identity
  3. Choose a clone URL
  4. Run the git clone command
  5. Set up SSH keys or use HTTPS authentication
  6. Verify repository and troubleshoot

Install Git by refreshing package lists and installing the package. Run sudo apt update then sudo apt install git -y to get the git binary on the machine.

Configure name and email so commits show a recognizable author. Set values with git config --global user.name "Your Name" and git config --global user.email "you@example.com".

Choose between HTTPS and SSH clone URLs. HTTPS uses a web credential method that is familiar to many. SSH uses a key pair and avoids entering a password for every push or pull.

Clone the repository with a simple command. Example for HTTPS use git clone https //github.com/user/repo.git and for SSH use git clone git@github.com user/repo.git. The repository will download into a new folder named after the project by default.

Generate an SSH key pair if preferring SSH based access. Run ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@example.com" and add the public key to the hosting service. For HTTPS consider using a credential helper so authentication is cached securely.

Verify success by changing into the cloned folder and running cd repo and git status. If a permission denied error appears check SSH agent status or use a personal access token for HTTPS authentication on services that deprecated password use.

This guide covered installing Git configuring identity selecting a clone URL running the clone command and basic verification and troubleshooting. Follow these steps and the repository will be ready for development and contribution with minimal fuss and a little less magic than expected.

Tip

Use ed25519 keys for SSH and enable an agent so keys load automatically. For HTTPS use the system credential helper to avoid repeated password prompts while keeping credentials secure.

title: git init bare example
description: Learn how to create a bare Git repository as a central remote using git init --bare and a simple push workflow for sharing code.
heading: git init bare example create a central bare Git repository
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a bare Git repository to serve as a central remote for sharing code.

  1. Create a bare repository directory
  2. Initialize the bare repository with git init --bare
  3. Create a normal working repository
  4. Add the bare repository as a remote and push
  5. Clone or fetch from the bare repository as needed

Step one involves making a dedicated folder that will hold the bare repository. Example commands use a local path so no network drama is required.

mkdir project.git
cd project.git

The second step runs the actual initialization command. This creates a repository without a working tree that is suitable as a central store.

git init --bare

The third step makes a normal project with a working tree that developers will use to make changes. Add files commit changes and get ready to share.

git init myproject
cd myproject
echo Hello README > README.md
git add README.md
git commit -m "initial commit"

The fourth step links the working repository to the bare repository and pushes branches. Using a local path keeps examples simple and usable on any machine.

git remote add origin ../project.git
git push origin master

The fifth step shows how other developers or automation can get a copy of the central repository. Clones will provide a normal working tree ready for changes.

git clone ../project.git cloned
