This walkthrough covered making a bare repository with git init --bare adding a remote from a normal repository pushing the initial branch and cloning from the bare repository for sharing code. The process gives a simple central remote without a working tree for safe multi user collaboration.

Tip

Use a bare repository for a shared central store and avoid accidental working tree overwrites. Keep branch protections or hooks on the server side for safer pushes.

title: How the Git Init Bare and Clone Commands Work
description: Quick guide to how git init git init --bare and git clone create repositories clones and a central bare repo for team workflows
heading: How the Git Init Bare and Clone Commands Work for Repositories
body:
This tutorial explains how git init git init --bare and git clone create and connect repositories and clones for local and remote workflows.

  1. Initialize a local repository
  2. Create a bare repository to act as a central server
  3. Clone the bare repository to get a working copy and share changes

Initialize a local repository

Run git init inside a project folder to create a regular repository. That command creates a .git directory that stores history and configuration. The working tree remains the files a developer edits.

Create a bare repository

Run git init --bare repo.git on a server or shared filesystem to create a bare repository. A bare repository contains only the Git database and refs and does not include a working tree. That layout makes the repository suitable as a central place for pushes and pulls.

Clone from the bare repository

Use git clone /srv/git/repo.git or a filesystem path to copy the bare repository into a new working repository. The clone produces a full working tree plus a local .git folder that references the original bare repository as origin. Developers then use normal commands like git add git commit git push and git pull to exchange changes with the bare repository.

Why choose a bare repository over a regular one for central hosting The lack of a working tree prevents accidental checkouts on the server and avoids merge conflicts on the host side. Think of the bare repository as a mailbox for patches rather than a workstation for editing files.

Quick recap The flow is initialize a local repo for development create a bare repo to act as a shared remote then clone that bare repo for team members to work and synchronize changes.

Tip

Use descriptive repository names that end with .git for bare repositories and use SSH keys for authentication. That combination makes collaboration smoother and less annoying than typing a password for every push.

title: How to create a bare git repo with init and update example
description: Create a bare Git repo using git init and update refs and server info. Quick commands and practical tips for server side repositories and sharing.
heading: How to create a bare git repo with init and update example
body:
This tutorial covers creating a bare Git repository on a server using git init and how to update refs and server info for sharing repositories with other developers.

  1. Create a bare repository on the server
  2. Set permissions and optional hooks
  3. Push from a local clone
  4. Update refs manually if needed
  5. Run update server info for dumb http

Step 1 Create a bare repository on the server with a command like git init --bare /srv/git/project.git. A bare repository stores history without a working tree so the repository can act as a central server without accidental file changes.

Step 2 Set appropriate file system permissions so collaborators can push and pull. Configure a shared group or use a deployment user. Add server side hooks in /srv/git/project.git/hooks to enforce policies or trigger deployments when a push arrives.

Step 3 On a developer machine clone the new repository with git clone user@server /srv/git/project.git. Make changes locally and push back to the bare repository with git push origin main or the branch name used by the team.

Step 4 Sometimes manual ref work helps. Use git update-ref refs/heads/branch-name to set a branch pointer directly. Manual ref updates are powerful and slightly dangerous so double check the target hash before applying changes.

Step 5 If the repository will be served over plain http without smart HTTP support run git update-server-info inside the bare repository. This generates auxiliary files that allow dumb http clients to fetch objects and refs.

This tutorial showed how to initialize a server side bare repository and how to keep references and server info up to date for sharing. Follow safe permission practices and prefer standard pushes over manual ref updates unless a clear reason exists.

Tip

Use receive hooks to validate incoming pushes and to update an index or deployment target. That approach avoids manual ref surgery and keeps the server side repository healthy while enforcing team rules.

title: git clone branch example
description: Learn how to clone a specific Git branch and set up local tracking with clear commands and quick verification steps for a tidy workflow.
heading: git clone branch example guide
body:
This short guide shows how to clone a specific Git branch and set up a local tracking branch for a smooth workflow.

  1. Prepare repository URL and branch name
  2. Clone the branch directly
  3. Verify the checked out branch
  4. Set or confirm upstream tracking
  5. Work and sync changes

Prepare repository URL and branch name Gather the repository address and the exact branch name. Use a placeholder like REPO_URL and BRANCH_NAME when testing commands locally.

Clone the branch directly Use a focused clone to avoid downloading every branch. Example command

git clone --branch BRANCH_NAME --single-branch REPO_URL

This command checks out the chosen branch as the active branch in the new local copy. The single branch option keeps the size small and the history focused.

Verify the checked out branch After cloning run

git branch

The output shows the current local branch with an asterisk. Use git status for a quick health check of the working tree.

Set or confirm upstream tracking A direct clone typically sets origin as the remote and links the local branch to the remote branch. If upstream is missing create tracking with

git branch --set-upstream-to=origin/BRANCH_NAME BRANCH_NAME

Tracking helps with simple pulls and pushes without typing full remote refs.

Work and sync changes Commit locally then push using

git push

Pull updates with

git pull

Those commands use upstream info so no extra arguments are needed once tracking is set.

This guide covered cloning a specific branch, checking which branch is active, ensuring upstream tracking, and the basic push and pull flow for ongoing work. Follow these steps for a lightweight clone and predictable branch behavior without downloading unrelated branches.

Tip

When experimenting use a shallow clone by adding --depth 1 to the clone command to save time and disk space. Remove depth for full history when deep debugging or bisecting is required.

title: How to Git Clone to a Specific Directory with GitHub
description: Quick guide to clone a GitHub repo into a specific local folder using git clone with a target folder name and basic tips.
heading: How to Git Clone to a Specific Directory with GitHub
body:
This short tutorial shows how to clone a GitHub repository into a specific local folder using the git clone command and a target folder name.

  1. Copy the repo clone URL from GitHub
  2. Pick or create a local target folder
  3. Run the git clone command with the target folder
  4. Check that the files landed where expected

Step one means opening the project page on GitHub and copying the clone URL that looks like a web or SSH address. Use the HTTPS option when not set up for SSH keys.

Step two is about naming. Choose a folder name that makes sense for the project. Use an empty folder or let git create a new folder by passing a new name in the command.

Step three is the exciting bit. Run this command in a terminal to clone into a specific folder

git clone < repo-url> < target-folder>

To clone directly into the current working folder use this command

git clone < repo-url> .

If the chosen folder already exists and contains files then git will refuse to overwrite. Choose an empty folder or a new folder name to avoid that drama.

Step four means listing files and checking branches with common commands such as ls and git status to confirm that the desired project is in place.

Recap the process by remembering these three actions copy the URL pick a folder run git clone and then verify that the project landed in the right spot with minimal fuss and maximum control.

Tip

Use a shallow clone to save time and bandwidth on large histories with the following form

git clone --depth 1 < repo-url> < target-folder>

title: git clone a tag example
description: Quick guide to clone a specific Git tag and check out the tagged snapshot with commands and tips for avoiding a detached HEAD.
heading: git clone a tag example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to clone a specific tag from a Git repository and check out the tagged snapshot.

  1. List tags to pick a tag name
  2. Clone the repository using the tag name
  3. Create a branch at the tag to avoid detached HEAD
  4. Use a shallow clone when only the tagged snapshot is needed

Step one get a list of available tags by querying the remote repository. Use the command git ls-remote --tags REPO_URL to view remote tags without cloning the entire history. After cloning the repository run git tag -l to list local tags.

Step two clone using the chosen tag. The simplest approach is git clone --branch TAG_NAME --depth 1 REPO_URL. This fetches the snapshot for the specified tag while keeping the download small when full history is not required.

Step three avoid a detached HEAD when planning to work on the tagged snapshot. After cloning run git checkout -b new-branch TAG_NAME to create a branch at the tag reference. This creates a movable branch named new-branch that starts from the tag snapshot and allows commits on top of that version.

Step four perform a shallow clone when only the tagged snapshot matters. The --depth 1 flag reduces bandwidth and disk usage by grabbing a single commit history depth. Use this approach for CI jobs or quick inspections of a release snapshot.

Common alternative workflows include cloning full repository and then fetching tags with git fetch --tags followed by git checkout tags/TAG_NAME -b new-branch. That approach suits situations where a full local copy of the repository is already required.

The walkthrough covered how to discover tags clone a specific tag and create a branch at the tag to permit ongoing development from a release snapshot. Commands shown allow either a lightweight snapshot clone or a fuller workflow that preserves history.

Tip

Prefer creating a branch at a tag when commits are planned. Using a branch prevents the awkward detached HEAD state and makes future pushes simple and predictable.

title: shallow git clone example
description: Quick guide to perform a shallow git clone and cut cloning time and bandwidth when working with large repositories.
heading: shallow git clone example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to perform a shallow git clone to save time and bandwidth when cloning large repositories.

  1. Decide desired history depth
  2. Run a shallow clone command
  3. Expand history when more commits are required
  4. Handle submodules in a shallow context

Step one means choosing how much commit history is required for the task. A depth of one gives the latest snapshot and nothing more. That choice can shave minutes off a clone of a huge repository and spare storage on local machines.

Step two shows the basic command to fetch limited history. Use a command line like git clone --depth 1 < repo-url> to pull only the most recent commit. Adding --branch < branch-name> narrows the fetch to a single branch and stops unnecessary branches from tagging along.

Step three covers expanding history after a shallow clone. If deeper history becomes necessary run git fetch --depth N to get more commits or git fetch --unshallow to convert the repository into a full clone. That allows debugging old regressions or bisecting without recloning from scratch.

Step four addresses submodules. Submodule defaults can pull full history and ruin the whole bandwidth saving plan. Use git submodule update --init --depth 1 to keep submodules shallow as well. Otherwise expect surprise downloads when building.

The process described helps developers grab a working copy fast and keep disk and network usage low while still allowing a path to full history when work requires deeper context.

Tip

When needing tags include a fetch of tags explicitly because shallow clones may skip tag history. Run git fetch --tags --depth N or convert to a full clone before relying on annotated tags for releases.

title: git clone depth 1 example
description: Learn how to use git clone depth 1 to create a shallow clone that saves time and bandwidth when full history is not needed
heading: git clone depth 1 example explained
body:
This tutorial shows how to use the git clone --depth 1 option to create a shallow clone that downloads only the latest commit history and speeds up cloning.

  1. Run a shallow clone command
  2. Verify the clone and check history
  3. Fetch more history when needed
  4. Clone a single branch shallowly
  5. Convert a shallow clone to a full clone

Run a shallow clone command

Execute a minimal clone using a placeholder for the repository address. Example command in plain form is shown below to avoid accidental pasting of an address in public logs.

git clone --depth 1 REPO_URL

Verify the clone and check history

Confirm that the checkout contains a small commit history. Use a compact log view to inspect recent commits and confirm that only the top of the tree arrived.

git log --oneline

Fetch more history when needed

If deeper history becomes necessary fetch additional commits or remove the shallow boundary. The repository can receive full history without recloning in most cases.

git fetch --unshallow

Clone a single branch shallowly

When only one branch matters supply branch and single branch flags to avoid bringing other branch heads into local storage.

git clone --branch BRANCH --single-branch --depth 1 REPO_URL

Convert a shallow clone to a full clone

When development requires full history run a fetch command that removes the shallow restriction and brings the rest of the timeline down.

git fetch --unshallow

This article covered how to run a shallow clone with depth 1 how to inspect the limited history how to extend history when needed and how to target a single branch for reduced transfer and storage

Tip

Use shallow clones for CI pipelines and quick experiments to save bandwidth and disk but switch to a full clone before doing deep history rewrites or detailed bisecting

title: git log one line example (oneline)
description: Quick guide to using git log oneline for compact commit history examples commands and a handy alias
heading: git log one line example oneline usage guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to use git log with the oneline option to view a compact commit history.

  1. Run the basic oneline command
  2. Add a visual graph and decorations
  3. Limit and filter commits
  4. Create an alias for daily use

Run the basic command to see abbreviated SHAs and messages in a single column. Example

git log --oneline

Add a simple ASCII graph and branch labels for context. This helps when scanning merges and branch tips quickly. Example

git log --oneline --graph --decorate --all

Limit results when looking for recent work or narrow down by author or keyword. Use a count flag or grep for messages. Examples

git log --oneline -n 10

git log --oneline --grep="bugfix"

Create a short alias to avoid typing the full command every time. An alias saves time and keeps workflow tidy. Example

git config --global alias.lg "log --oneline --graph --decorate --all"

Using the alias yields the same compact, informative view with a single short command. Example

git lg

The examples shown cover core use cases for fast commit browsing and basic filtering. The repository history becomes readable without scrolling through verbose records. Apply the alias on any machine to keep the same quick view across projects.

Tip

Combine the oneline view with a pager that supports color to preserve branch colors when scrolling. Add an alias and commit harvesting becomes pleasantly fast and slightly smug.

title: How to Use the Git Log Graph Command by Example
description: Learn git log --graph with practical examples to visualize commit history and branch structure using concise flags for clearer CLI graphs
heading: How to Use the Git Log Graph Command by Example
body:
This tutorial teaches how to use git log --graph to visualize commit history and understand branch relationships with a few handy flags.

  1. Run a basic graph
  2. Show concise commits and branch names
  3. Include all branches in the view
  4. Filter history to a file or path
  5. Tweak output for readability

Run a basic graph

Open a terminal in a repository and run git log --graph. The command draws an ASCII tree next to full commit messages. This is the raw map for branches and merges without any cosmetic trimming.

Show concise commits and branch names

Use git log --graph --oneline --decorate for a compact map. Short commit ids and branch tags appear next to messages so scanning through history becomes less painful.

Include all branches in the view

Add --all to the previous command to include every local ref. That reveals where branches diverge and where merges land. Consider this for debugging merge confusion or impressing coworkers.

Filter history to a file or path

Append a path to limit output to commits that touched a given file. Example git log --graph --oneline --decorate -- path/to/file. This helps when investigating when a line of code first appeared without drowning in unrelated noise.

Tweak output for readability

Combine --graph --oneline --decorate --all --date=short for a neat timeline that fits in a terminal. Color and date formats help when scanning for recent work or spotting ancient crimes.

This tutorial covered how to draw a commit graph from a basic run to an annotated view that includes all branches and file scoped history. Use these command combos to move from bewildered to mildly competent when exploring repository history.

Tip

When sharing history in a code review paste the output of git log --graph --oneline --decorate --all --date=short for a compact snapshot that shows context without requiring a lecture.

title: git log pretty examples
description: Quick guide to make git log output readable with oneline graph decorate and custom format commands for clearer commit history
heading: git log pretty examples for readable commit history
body:
This tutorial shows how to format git log output for clearer commit history.

  1. Show compact commits with oneline
  2. Add an ASCII graph for branch structure
  3. Decorate output with branch and tag names
  4. Create a custom format for exact fields
  5. Save a friendly alias for daily use

Show compact history by running git log --pretty=oneline to collapse each commit onto a single line. That command helps scan commit messages when detail is not required.

Add branch context with git log --graph --oneline to draw a text graph of branches and merges. The ASCII lines make branching and merging obvious without squinting at hex references.

Add names for refs with git log --graph --decorate --oneline so branch and tag labels appear next to commits. That helps identify which commits belong to which branch.

Control exact fields with custom format using git log --pretty=format='%h %ad %an %s' --date=short to display short hash date author and subject. Replace placeholders to show author email body or full hash depending on preferences.

Create a readable alias using global config so the preferred view becomes a single short command. Example alias command is git config --global alias.lg "log --graph --decorate --pretty=format '%C(yellow)%h%Creset %Cgreen%ad%Creset %C(cyan)%an%Creset %s' --date=short" which produces colored compact history for daily inspection.

The goal here is to pick one or two formats that answer common questions about history and make those formats easy to run.

Tip

Keep one alias for fast reviews and a different alias for deep audits. The fast alias uses oneline graph and decorate. The audit alias uses full format with body and raw dates.

title: git log command in terminal examples
description: Compact guide to using git log in the terminal with practical examples for filtering formatting and reading project history
heading: Git Log Command in Terminal Examples
body:
This tutorial shows how to use the git log command in the terminal with practical examples for exploring repository history and finding commits fast.

  1. View basic history
  2. Condense output
  3. Visualize branches
  4. Filter by author date or message
  5. Inspect changes and stats

View basic history using the simplest form of the command. Run git log to see commits in chronological order. The log output includes commit id author date and the commit message so reading context becomes easier than guessing which commit broke tests.

Condense output when the full detail is too much. Use git log --oneline for one line per commit. That creates a readable timeline when reviewing many commits at once.

Visualize branches with an ASCII graph plus labels. Use git log --graph --decorate --oneline to see branching structure commit references and brief messages. Developers who like neat diagrams will feel superior while browsing history.

Filter by author date or message to narrow focus. Try git log --author="Alice" or git log --since=2.weeks or git log --grep="fix" to find contributions by person recent work or commits mentioning a keyword. Combining flags produces useful drills for debugging or release notes.

Inspect changes and stats when context matters. Use git log -p to show patch diffs per commit or git log --stat to see file change summaries. Add -n 5 to limit output to the most recent five commits when the repository prefers restraint.

This collection of commands covers common workflows for reading history finding specific commits and reviewing changes before a merge or release. The commands encourage exploration and reduce guessing when tracking down code changes.

Tip

Combine flags to get what is needed quickly. For example run git log --graph --decorate --oneline -n 10 --since=1.month to get a compact visual of the last month of activity. Aliases in the git config make frequent combos a single word to type.

title: How to set a sudo alias
description: Quick guide to add a sudo alias for faster command use with elevated privileges on Linux and macOS shells.
heading: How to set a sudo alias for faster root commands
body:
This short guide shows how to create a sudo alias so common commands run with elevated privileges without repeated typing.

  1. Edit the shell config file
  2. Add the sudo alias line
  3. Reload the shell configuration
  4. Test the alias and use safely

Edit the shell config file

Open the personal shell configuration file for the current shell. For bash use the file at ~/.bashrc. For zsh use ~/.zshrc. Any terminal editor will do like nano or vim.

Add the sudo alias line

Insert the alias that enables alias expansion after the sudo token. Add this exact line to the config file

alias sudo='sudo '

The trailing space is the magic. That space tells the shell to expand an alias that follows the sudo token. Without the space the shell treats the next word as a plain command and skips user aliases.

Reload the shell configuration

Apply changes by sourcing the file or opening a new terminal session. Use a command like

source ~/.bashrc

Test the alias and use safely

Create a regular alias first to test expansion. For example

alias ll='ls -la'

Then run sudo ll and watch the user alias expand under sudo. Expect the normal password prompt from the privilege system. Avoid relying on this trick in scripts that run in non interactive environments.

This tutorial covered adding a sudo alias to allow alias expansion after the sudo token why the trailing space matters how to apply the change and how to test the result.

Tip

For reliable automation prefer explicit commands or shell functions instead of user aliases. Aliases are handy in interactive shells but can surprise in scripts or when using different shells or remote sessions.

title: delete a GitHub repository example
description: Step by step guide to delete a GitHub repository from the web interface with safety checks and confirmation steps.
heading: Delete a GitHub repository example guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to permanently delete a GitHub repository from a GitHub account using the GitHub web interface.

  1. Sign in to GitHub
  2. Open the repository Settings
  3. Scroll to Danger Zone
  4. Click Delete this repository
  5. Type the repository name to confirm
  6. Authenticate and finalize deletion

Sign in using the account that owns the repository. Two factor authentication may be required and that is a good thing for security.

From the repository main page click Settings in the top menu. Settings holds administrative controls such as access and webhooks.

Scroll down to the Danger Zone near the bottom of the Settings page. The Danger Zone groups destructive actions so users do not stumble into them by accident.

Click the Delete this repository button. A confirmation dialog will appear that requests explicit confirmation before any permanent action proceeds.

Type the full repository name exactly as shown in the confirmation field. This step forces deliberate intent and reduces accidental loss when multiple similar repositories exist.

If prompted provide a password or complete two factor verification. After successful confirmation the repository will be permanently removed from the account and from public view unless a backup exists elsewhere.

This guide covered signing in navigating to repository settings using the Danger Zone typing the repository name and authenticating to delete a repository. Remember to check organization ownership forks and team permissions before removing a repository to avoid surprising coworkers.

Tip

Create a local clone or a compressed archive of the repository before deletion and consider transferring the repository to an archive organization for long term retention rather than permanent removal.

title: How to rename a GitHub repository in Git
description: Step by step guide to rename a GitHub repository and update local clones and remotes so pushes and pulls keep working.
heading: How to rename a GitHub repository in Git
body:
This tutorial shows how to rename a GitHub repository and update the local repository so the new name is used for future pushes and pulls.

  1. Rename the repository on GitHub
  2. Check redirection and locate the new clone URL
  3. Update the local remote URL
  4. Verify and update other clones and services

Rename the repository on GitHub by visiting the repository settings and changing the name field. GitHub will update the repository name while keeping a redirect from the old address for most requests.

Check redirection by viewing the repository page after the rename and by copying the clone URL shown on GitHub. Use the HTTPS or SSH clone option on the GitHub page and paste the value into the next command placeholder.

Update the local remote URL in each clone. Run git remote -v to see current remotes. Then run git remote set-url origin < new-remote-url> where the placeholder is the clone URL copied from the GitHub page. This command tells the local repository where to push and pull from now.

Verify the change with git remote -v again and perform a quick fetch with git fetch origin to confirm permissions and connectivity. Update any other clones on other machines the same way.

Remember to update external references such as continuous integration settings, webhooks, and documentation to point to the new repository name. GitHub redirects help for a period but external services are better served by direct links to the new name.

The steps covered a rename on the GitHub website followed by updating the local remote URL and verifying connectivity and external references. Follow these steps to avoid broken pipelines and confused collaborators and enjoy the tiny thrill of a cleaner repository name.

Tip

When copying the new clone URL paste the exact value into the set URL command to avoid typos. Consider running a test push from a throwaway branch to confirm permissions before relying on production pipelines.

title: How to Revert a Git Commit
description: Learn how to undo Git commits safely with revert reset and reflog examples and commands for shared and local branches
heading: How to Revert a Git Commit Guide
body:
This tutorial teaches how to undo a Git commit using safe and destructive commands while keeping repository history understandable

  1. Choose the right method for the scenario
  2. Use git revert to undo while preserving history
  3. Use git reset for local cleanup when safe
  4. Recover lost commits with git reflog when needed
  5. Push changes with caution on shared branches

Choose the right method Decide if the branch is shared with teammates or purely local. For shared branches prefer a non destructive approach. For private work a history rewrite may be acceptable.

Safe undo with revert Use git revert < commit sha> to create a new commit that undoes the changes from a target commit. This keeps the timeline honest and avoids surprise edits on a shared branch.

Local cleanup with reset Use git reset --soft HEAD~1 to move the branch pointer but keep staged changes. Use git reset --hard HEAD~1 to drop changes entirely. Hard reset will discard work so confirm that the working tree can be sacrificed.

Recover with reflog Use git reflog to find lost commit references after a messy reset. Then restore with git checkout -b recover < sha> or git reset --hard < sha> depending on desired state.

Pushing and collaboration For shared branches avoid forced updates unless coordination exists. If a rewrite is unavoidable use git push --force-with-lease to reduce the chance of overwriting a teammate bit of work.

Recap of the approach Choose revert for safe undo on shared branches. Use reset for local history edits. Use reflog as a rescue tool when a reset goes too far and a recovery process is necessary

Tip

Prefer git revert on public branches to keep history traceable. Use a descriptive revert message so future humans can understand why a reversal happened

title: git undo commits example
description: Practical guide to undo commits in Git using reset revert and reflog with safety notes and recovery tips for shared branches.
heading: git undo commits example guide
body:
This tutorial explains how to undo commits in Git using safe and destructive commands and how to recover lost work when mistakes happen.

  1. Inspect history
  2. Undo last commit but keep changes staged
  3. Undo last commit and discard changes
  4. Undo a commit that has been pushed
  5. Recover a lost commit

Inspect history

Look at the commit list before any heroic action. Run git log --oneline to find the commit hash and to confirm which commit deserves mercy.

Undo last commit but keep changes staged

Use a soft reset to move HEAD back while preserving the index and the working tree. This is great for correcting the commit message or adding files. Command example git reset --soft HEAD~1 and then amend or create a fresh commit.

Undo last commit and discard changes

When the previous commit is garbage and the working tree can be thrown away use a hard reset. This removes the commit and rewrites the working tree. Warning do not run this on a shared branch without prior agreement. Command example git reset --hard HEAD~1

Undo a commit that has been pushed

For public history prefer git revert SHA which creates a new commit that reverses the changes. Force pushing rewritten history is an option for solo branches but expect angry teammates. Example git push --force when rewriting history after a reset.

Recover a lost commit

Git keeps a trail of HEAD movements. Use git reflog to find the lost commit hash and then recover with git reset --hard SHA or cherry pick that commit back onto the branch.

This tutorial covered how to inspect history and then undo commits with soft reset hard reset revert and how to recover using reflog. Choose safe commands for shared branches and prefer revert when collaboration matters.

Tip

Prefer git revert on branches shared with others to avoid rewriting public history. Run git log --oneline and git reflog before destructive moves so surprises do not happen.

title: Git clean up strategies
description: Practical Git clean up strategies to remove untracked files prune branches and optimize repository history for a cleaner workflow
heading: Git clean up strategies for tidy repositories
body:
This article teaches practical Git clean up strategies to remove unwanted files revive branches and keep history tidy.

  1. Inspect and stash changes
  2. Remove untracked files safely
  3. Clean up branches
  4. Rework local commits
  5. Compress repository and prune objects

Start with a quick inspection using git status and git diff to see the working tree. Use git stash push -m 'WIP' when changes should be set aside before any destructive action.

To remove untracked files run a dry run first with git clean -n -d then execute git clean -f -d when happy. The dry run shows what would be deleted so surprises are less likely.

Prune local branches that are merged into main with git branch --merged main then delete stale branches with git branch -d branch-name or force remove with git branch -D branch-name if the branch has diverged and deletion is intentional.

Rewrite local commit history carefully. Use git rebase -i HEAD~N to squash or reorder commits. Create a backup branch first with git branch backup to avoid heroic recoveries later.

Compress repository using git gc --aggressive --prune=now and prune remote refs with git remote prune origin. That reduces disk usage and speeds up operations on large repositories.

This guide covered quick inspections safe removal of untracked files pruning of local branches rewriting local history when needed and running garbage collection to keep a repository healthy and fast.

Tip

Always run dry run commands before destructive actions and create a lightweight backup branch. Scripts that run periodic git gc and prune unused refs prevent future mess and save developer time.

title: Easily rebase GitHub branches
description: Rebase GitHub branches fast and safely Learn commands to update feature branches resolve conflicts and push with confidence
heading: Easily rebase GitHub branches with git rebase
body:
This tutorial shows how to rebase a GitHub branch cleanly and safely while minimizing merge noise.

  1. Fetch and update local refs
  2. Checkout the feature branch
  3. Rebase onto the target branch
  4. Resolve conflicts and continue the rebase
  5. Push the updated branch to GitHub safely

Fetch and update local refs by running git fetch origin which brings remote changes into local refs without touching working files. Confirm that the chosen target branch such as origin main is current on the server.

Checkout the feature branch with git checkout feature-branch so that commands apply to the correct branch. Avoid rebasing a branch that other people are already basing work on unless those people enjoy surprises.

Rebase onto the target branch using git rebase origin/main to replay feature branch commits on top of the latest main branch. This produces a linear history that looks like someone used a time machine to keep history tidy.

If conflicts appear open the conflicted files resolve the problems then stage changes with git add < file> and continue with git rebase --continue Repeat until rebase finishes. If a mistake happens use git rebase --abort to return to the pre rebase state and breathe.

Push the updated branch with care using git push --force-with-lease origin feature-branch This is safer than a plain force push because the command fails if someone else pushed in the meantime. Pull request on GitHub updates automatically and shows the cleaned history without extra merge commits.

This guide covered fetching and rebasing a branch resolving conflicts and pushing with force with lease to keep pull requests tidy and history linear. Follow these steps when maintaining a clean commit graph and prefer rebase for local or short lived branches.

Tip

Prefer git push --force-with-lease over a plain force push. That option protects coworkers by refusing to overwrite new remote commits and saves awkward team messages.

title: How to Squash Git Commits
description: Step by step guide to squash Git commits for a cleaner history with safe force push tips and practical commands.
heading: How to Squash Git Commits for a Clean History
body:
This guide teaches how to squash multiple Git commits into a single tidy commit to keep a readable commit history and avoid shame during code review.

  1. Pick the commit range to squash
  2. Start an interactive rebase
  3. Choose squash or fixup for selected commits
  4. Edit the final commit message
  5. Push the rewritten history to the remote

Pick the commit range

First find the commits to combine by using git log --oneline. Decide how many commits to rewrite for the branch. For example use HEAD~3 to target the last three commits.

Start an interactive rebase

Run git rebase -i HEAD~3 to open the interactive editor. The editor shows each commit with a pick action in front.

Choose squash or fixup for selected commits

Replace pick with squash to merge commit messages or with fixup to discard the message and keep the topmost message. Save and close the editor to let Git replay the commits with the chosen actions.

Edit the final commit message

When using squash Git opens another editor prompt to combine messages. Tidy the message so the result explains the change. Use concise summary line and optional body for details.

Push the rewritten history to the remote

After a successful rebase push the branch with safety in mind using git push --force-with-lease. That command reduces the chance of stomping on a collaborator work compared to a blind force push.

Recap of this tutorial The process covered choosing a commit range running an interactive rebase marking commits as squash or fixup cleaning up the combined commit message and safely pushing the rewritten branch

Tip

Prefer fixup! Original commit message when crafting follow up commits so Git can auto fold messages during rebase. Always run git log --oneline before and after the rewrite to confirm the history looks sane and tell teammates about the rewritten branch.

title: git rebase master to branch example
description: Step by step example of rebasing master onto a feature branch using git commands and conflict handling for a clean linear history
heading: git rebase master to branch example for a clean history
body:
This guide shows how to rebase master onto a feature branch to update the branch with the latest master changes and keep history linear.

  1. Switch to feature branch
  2. Fetch latest master from remote
  3. Rebase feature branch onto master
  4. Resolve any merge conflicts
  5. Complete rebase and push updated branch

Step 1 Check out the correct branch with git checkout feature-branch. HEAD must point to the feature branch before starting a rebase.

Step 2 Fetch remote updates with git fetch origin. This brings origin/master into local view without changing local branches.

Step 3 Rebase the feature branch onto the updated master with git rebase origin/master while still on the feature branch. This rewrites the feature branch commits on top of the latest master commits for a linear history.

Step 4 If conflicts appear resolve them in the working tree then run git add for resolved files and git rebase --continue. If a mistake happens use git rebase --abort to return to the pre rebase state.

Step 5 After a successful rebase push the branch with git push --force-with-lease to update the remote without stomping over other people changes. Force with lease provides a safety net.

This short tutorial walked through updating a feature branch by rebasing onto master fetching remote updates resolving conflicts and safely pushing the rewritten branch. The goal is a clean commit history that reads like a straight line rather than a maze.

Tip

Prefer git rebase origin/master from the feature branch and use --force-with-lease when pushing. That reduces surprise and keeps collaboration less dramatic.

title: Git rebase to master example
description: Clear example showing how to rebase a feature branch onto master with commands conflict handling and safe push tips
heading: Git rebase to master example explained
body:
This tutorial shows how to rebase a feature branch onto master to keep history linear and apply the latest master changes onto the feature branch.

  1. Prepare local repository
  2. Update master
  3. Checkout feature branch
  4. Rebase feature branch onto master
  5. Resolve conflicts and continue
  6. Push updated branch

Prepare local repository Make sure the working tree is clean and stash or commit any uncommitted changes. Run git status before proceeding.

Update master Switch to master and fetch the latest from origin then fast forward with git checkout master and git pull --ff-only origin master. This ensures the base branch is current.

Checkout feature branch Switch back with git checkout feature-branch or git switch feature-branch.

Rebase feature branch onto master Run git rebase master while on the feature branch. Git will replay feature commits on top of master so history appears linear and tidy.

Resolve conflicts and continue If merge conflicts occur open conflicting files and resolve changes. Then stage fixes with git add and run git rebase --continue. Use git rebase --abort to return to the previous state if needed.

Push updated branch After a successful rebase push with git push --force-with-lease origin feature-branch. Force push is necessary because commit history changed. The use of --force-with-lease reduces risk of overwriting other peoples work.

This flow rebases a feature branch on top of master to incorporate recent master updates while producing a linear commit history. Use caution with shared branches since rewriting history can surprise collaborators and require coordination.

Tip

Consider git rebase --interactive master for squashing or editing commits during rebase. When pushing prefer --force-with-lease to protect remote changes and check with collaborators before rewriting shared history.

title: Git config file locations on Windows and Ubuntu
description: Quick guide to where Git stores system global and local config files on Windows and Ubuntu and how to view and edit each one
heading: Git config file locations on Windows and Ubuntu
body:
This short tutorial explains where Git reads configuration files on Windows and Ubuntu and how to locate and edit each file.

  1. Locate system level config files
  2. Find global user config files
  3. Inspect local repository config files
  4. Use a command to show file origins
  5. Edit safely using Git commands

Locate system level config files

System level configuration applies to every user on a machine. On Ubuntu check /etc/gitconfig. On Windows check the Program data path such as %PROGRAMDATA%/Git/config or the Git installation etc folder under Program files.

Find global user config files

The global user configuration affects one account. On Ubuntu look in ~/.gitconfig. On Windows use the profile based path %USERPROFILE%/.gitconfig. Use that file for user name email and preferred merge and push defaults.

Inspect local repository config files

Repository specific settings live inside the repo in .git/config. That file overrides global and system entries for that specific repository. Use this for repo level hooks and remotes that should not be global.

Use a command to show file origins

Run git config --list --show-origin to see every setting and the file where each value came from. That command saves guessing and prevents accidental editing of the wrong file.

Edit safely using Git commands

Prefer git config --global user.name "Your Name" and similar commands over direct file editing. Commands keep syntax safe and avoid stray formatting mistakes. For repo only changes add --local when not in a bare environment.

Knowing these locations helps predict which setting wins when conflicts happen and speeds up debugging of odd authentication or merge behavior.

Tip

If a value seems stuck run git config --list --show-origin then change the source using the matching --system or --global flag. Back up any config file before manual edits to avoid surprises.

title: Why you can't find the gitconfig file?
description: Find the missing gitconfig file learn where Git stores config and how to reveal and create global and system configuration files
heading: Why you can't find the gitconfig file explained
body:
Most of the time the gitconfig file exists but lives somewhere unexpected.

Git has three config scopes project global and system. Project config lives in the repository under .git/config. Global config typically lives in the home folder as ~/.gitconfig or under the XDG path at ~/.config/git/config. System config is maintained by the OS and can appear under system directories on Linux or under the ProgramData folder on Windows.

Missing global config often means no global setting was ever written. Running a global set operation will create a global file for the user. To find which files are actually being read run git config --list --show-origin. That command prints every setting and the file source where the setting came from. If a file name appears as command line then a temporary override comes from an environment variable or CLI flag.

To edit or create a global file use git config --global --edit. To inspect system level values use git config --system --list which may require administrator rights. On Windows check the user profile folder for .gitconfig and check the ProgramData area for system config.

Another common source of confusion is the XDG standard. If the XDG_CONFIG_HOME environment variable points somewhere unusual Git will look there instead of the home folder. That behavior explains many unexpected locations for config files.

If the goal is to make sure name and email are set use git config --global user.name 'Your Name' and git config --global user.email 'email@example.com'. After those commands the global file appears and Git stops nagging.

Tip

Use git config --list --show-origin first and stop wandering through hidden folders. That command reveals the truth faster than blind clicking.

title: How to Use the Git Config List Command Example
description: Learn how to use git config list to view and debug Git configuration across local global and system scopes with practical commands and tips
heading: How to Use the Git Config List Command Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to use the git config list command to inspect Git configuration across local global and system scopes and to debug where values come from.

  1. View all configuration entries with the list command
  2. Show the origin file for each entry
  3. Filter or fetch single keys
  4. Set or unset values in a specific scope
  5. Verify precedence among scopes

View all configuration entries Use the basic command to dump current configuration to the terminal. Example command

git config --list

The command prints key value pairs that apply to the repository or the environment. This is the first stop when a name or email looks wrong.

Show the origin file for each entry Add an option to see where each value came from. Example command

git config --list --show-origin

Because Git enjoys hiding surprises the origin flag reveals whether a value comes from system global or repository level files. That helps when a global setting overrides local expectations.

Filter or fetch single keys Use get or grep like tools to focus on a single setting. Example commands

git config user.email

git config --get-all user.email

These commands are the fast lane when only one configuration key matters during troubleshooting.

Set or unset values in a specific scope Use scope flags to control where a change lands. Examples

git config --global user.name "Jane Doe"

git config --local --unset user.name

Pick the correct scope to avoid surprising teammates with a global name change.

Verify precedence among scopes Remember that local repository configuration overrides global and system settings. Use the list and origin commands together to see the winning value and the file responsible.

Recap of the tutorial content The guide covered viewing all configuration values showing origins filtering single keys setting and unsetting values and checking scope precedence so that configuration surprises become less thrilling and more managed

Tip

Use the origin option when debugging to discover the exact file that defined a value and avoid chasing ghosts in the config files.

title: How to Remove and Delete Properties from Git Config
description: Compact guide to remove and delete properties from Git config using unset remove section and editing for local and global scopes
heading: How to Remove and Delete Properties from Git Config
body:
This tutorial shows how to remove and delete properties from Git config and when to use each command.

  1. Inspect current configuration
  2. Unset a single property
  3. Unset all values for a key
  4. Remove a whole section
  5. Edit the config file directly

Inspect current configuration

List the active values to find the exact key name before making changes. Use the command in a repo to see local values and use a global flag to see user level settings

git config --list

Unset a single property

Remove a single setting when a value needs replacement or cleanup. Specify scope to avoid surprising other repositories

git config --local --unset user.email

Unset all values for a key

When a key has multiple entries use the all option to strip every occurrence. This helps when duplicates cause unexpected behavior

git config --global --unset-all include.path

Remove a whole section

Drop an entire section when a feature or integration no longer applies. This is the nuclear option for related keys inside a section

git config --remove-section branch.feature

Edit the config file directly

Open the config in a text editor for surgical edits or to remove comments. Use the built in edit command to target global user settings or open the repository file for local changes

git config --global --edit

Practice caution and check the config after changes to avoid credential or behavior surprises. Backups are cheap and awkward rollbacks are expensive in time

Tip

Make a quick backup by copying the file before edits and prefer local scope when testing changes so user level preferences remain untouched

title: How to set the Git user.name Property in Git Config
description: Quick guide to set Git user.name with git config for global and local repos and verify commit author
heading: Set Git user.name Property in Git Config
body:
This tutorial shows how to set the Git user.name property using git config for global and local repositories and how to verify the change.

  1. Check current name
  2. Set a global name
  3. Set a local name for a single repository
  4. Verify the configured values

Step 1 Check current name with a quick query. Run git config --list to see all configured values. For a focused check run git config user.name from inside a repository to view the local value that applies to that repository.

Step 2 Set a global name that will apply across repositories by default. Run git config --global user.name 'Your Name' to write to the global config file. This is handy when human readable commit authors are desired everywhere and no per repository override is needed.

Step 3 Set a local name when a repository needs a different author. From the repository folder run git config user.name 'Repository Name' to store the name in the repository config file. This local value will take precedence over the global value for that repository.

Step 4 Verify the change. Use git config --global user.name to check the global entry and git config user.name inside a repo to check the local entry. For a fast check of commit author on the last commit run git log -1 --pretty=format %an to display the author name recorded on the latest commit.

Choosing a clear user.name prevents mystery authors and awkward blame moments. Use single quotes in the shell if the name has spaces. If the wrong author was used on a commit there are ways to rewrite history but that is a slightly different conversation that includes force pushing and consequences.

Tip

Set both user.name and user.email together to avoid anonymous commit authors. Use global for daily work and local for special projects. If privacy matters use a throwaway name and a dedicated email for public repositories.

title: How to Set the Git Email Property in Git Config
description: Quick guide to set Git user email using git config for global and local scopes and fix commit author issues on repositories
heading: How to Set the Git Email Property in Git Config
body:
This guide teaches how to set the Git email property using git config for global and local repositories so commit author information matches expectations.

  1. Check current email
  2. Set global email
  3. Set local repository email
  4. Verify configuration
  5. Fix past commits if needed

Check current email Use the configuration query command to see the address used for new commits in the current repository or across the system. Example commands are git config user.email and git config --global user.email. That output reveals whether a change is required.

Set global email The global setting applies to every repository on a given machine unless overridden by a repository level setting. Run git config --global user.email "name@example.com" replacing the example with the correct address.

Set local repository email A repository specific setting overrides the global value for that repository. Run git config user.email "name@example.com" while inside the repository folder to apply that address only to that project.

Verify configuration After changes use listing commands to confirm the new values. Use git config --global --list for global settings and git config --local --list for repository specific settings. Confirmation prevents awkward anonymous looking commits later.

Fix past commits if needed For the most recent commit run git commit --amend --author="Name " --no-edit. For many commits use an interactive rebase with git rebase -i HEAD~N or use a history rewrite tool for bulk changes. Beware history rewrites when collaborating with others.

This tutorial covered how to view current Git email values set global and local user email using git config and how to correct author data on past commits when required.

Tip

Use the same email address registered with remote hosting services so web interfaces attribute commits correctly. Use global for personal machines and local for repository specific identities to keep professional and personal commits separate.

title: How to Configure Your Global Git Config Settings
description: Quick guide to set global Git config options like user name email default editor and signing keys so every repository behaves consistently
heading: How to Configure Your Global Git Config Settings for Every Repo
body:
This tutorial teaches how to set global Git configuration options that apply to every repository on a machine.

  1. Inspect current global config
  2. Set user name and email
  3. Set editor signing key and preferences
  4. List and verify global settings
  5. Edit the global config file manually

Step 1 Inspect current global config

Run git config --global --list to see keys and values that apply globally. This helps avoid surprises from previous setup.

Step 2 Set user name and email

Set identity with commands like git config --global user.name "Your Name" and git config --global user.email "you@example.com". These values appear in commit metadata across all repositories.

Step 3 Set editor signing key and preferences

Choose a default editor with git config --global core.editor "code --wait" or pick nano for the minimalists. Configure GPG signing with git config --global user.signingkey YOURKEY and enable signing when appropriate.

Step 4 List and verify global settings

Use git config --global --list again and inspect ~/.gitconfig with git config --global --edit to confirm values. That prevents a mismatch between expected and actual behavior.

Step 5 Edit the global config file manually

Open ~/.gitconfig in a text editor to add sections or tweak formatting. Manual edits are handy for advanced keys or to copy settings to a new machine.

This guide showed how to check set and verify global Git settings so identity editor and signing preferences apply across every repository on a machine. Following these steps avoids per project surprises and keeps commit metadata consistent.

Tip

Use the same user.email across devices for public projects to avoid fragmented commit history. For private work use a different email and enable GPG signing for extra proof of authorship.

title: How to Set Your Username and Email in Git Config
description: Quick guide to set user.name and user.email in Git config for global and repository level commits and to verify or fix author information
heading: How to Set Your Username and Email in Git Config
body:
This tutorial gives a compact walkthrough for setting username and email in Git global and repository configuration so commits carry the correct author information with minimal drama.

  1. Set global username and email
  2. Set local username and email for a repository
  3. Verify configuration values
  4. Amend a recent commit author when needed

Set global username and email Use global configuration to apply name and email across all repositories on a machine. Run git config --global user.name "Your Name" and git config --global user.email "you@example.com" to set a default identity for commits.

Set local username and email To override the global identity for a specific repository run git config user.name "Project Name" and git config user.email "proj@example.com" inside the repository folder. Local values take precedence over global values which is handy for side projects or work accounts.

Verify configuration values Confirm current settings with git config --list for all values or query a single key with git config user.email to see which email will be stamped on new commits.

Amend a recent commit author If a recent commit used the wrong author correct the most recent commit with git commit --amend --author="Name < email@example.com> " and then force push if history rewriting is acceptable. For multiple commits use interactive rebase and rewrite author lines while being mindful that rewriting public history can annoy collaborators.

Summary of the steps covered includes setting global defaults configuring repository specific identity verifying active values and fixing a recent commit author. Proper configuration avoids confusing commit logs and reduces support messages about missing identity.

Tip

Use a consistent email that matches the host account to link commits to a profile. For multiple identities prefer global defaults plus repository level overrides or use conditional includes in the gitconfig to keep things tidy.

title: How to Show All Your Git Config Properties at Once
description: Quick guide to list every Git config property across local global and system scopes with commands examples and cleaning tips
heading: How to Show All Your Git Config Properties at Once
body:
This guide shows how to list all Git configuration properties across local global and system scopes using simple commands and a touch of sarcasm.

  1. Run the show origin list command
  2. Inspect scope and source
  3. Filter or search the output
  4. Edit or unset unwanted entries

Run the show origin list command

Open a terminal in a repository and run git config --list --show-origin. The command prints each configuration key with the file path that provided the value. That is the single command that saves time and dignity.

Inspect scope and source

Values come from the local repository config file global user config and system config. Pay attention to the file path shown in the output to know which file to edit when a setting misbehaves.

Filter or search the output

Use grep or the shell search on Windows to narrow results. For example run git config --list --show-origin | grep user to find name and email settings. This keeps the focus on the problem and avoids scrolling through unrelated decorations.

Edit or unset unwanted entries

To change a value use git config --global --edit for user level changes or git config --local --edit inside a repo for repo level changes. To remove a key run git config --global --unset key.name or the local equivalent. Manual editing of ~/.gitconfig is allowed for brave humans.

The commands above turn a confusing pile of settings into readable lines with file paths and values. Use the show origin flag to find duplicates and remove surprises that cause strange behavior during commits and pushes.

Tip

Run git config --list --show-origin before blaming the tool for strange behavior. The output tells the file source so removing or changing the offending entry becomes trivial.

title: git reflog example
description: Practical guide to using git reflog to recover commits inspect history and reset branches safely
heading: git reflog example explained for commit recovery and history
body:
This tutorial shows how to use git reflog to find lost commits recover branches and reset safely.

  1. View the reflog
  2. Find the commit reference
  3. Create a branch or checkout the reference
  4. Reset or restore the target branch
  5. Push recovered work and clean up

Start by listing recent movements in the repository with the command git reflog to see a history of HEAD and branch changes. The reflog shows references such as HEAD at a position which help locate lost commits.

Scan the reflog output to find the desired commit reference. Look for messages that match the lost work. The numeric reference form like HEAD at a number is handy when a raw hash is not available.

Create a safe recovery branch with git checkout -b recovered-branch HEAD@{3} using the reference found in the previous step. This preserves the recovered commit while avoiding disruption of the main branch.

To move a target branch back to a recovered commit use git reset --hard HEAD@{2} when confident that the working tree and index may be overwritten. For a less destructive approach perform a merge or cherry pick from the recovered branch.

After recovery push the new branch to the remote with git push origin recovered-branch to avoid dependence on local reflog history. Clean up any temporary branches once the recovered work lands in the desired branch.

The tutorial covered how to read the reflog identify a lost commit create a recovery branch and restore or move a branch pointer safely while preserving work.

Tip

Push recovered work to a remote as soon as possible because reflog entries expire over time. Use branches for recovery so the reflog can serve as a map without risking main branch state.

title: git log and reflog compared
description: Understand differences between git log and reflog and learn when to use each for history inspection and recovering lost commits.
heading: git log and reflog compared for history inspection and recovery
body:
The key difference between git log and reflog is that git log shows the commit history of branches while reflog records every local reference update including HEAD moves.

The two commands serve different purposes so knowing when to run each one saves time and heartache.

What git log does

git log reads the commit graph reachable from a branch or reference. Use options like --oneline or --graph to condense output. This command is what team members and CI rely on because history shown here is what gets shared and pushed.

What git reflog does

git reflog shows local reference updates including checkouts rebases resets and merges that moved HEAD. This is not a public history. Reflog is a personal safety net that records where HEAD has been even when those commits are no longer reachable from any branch.

Common recovery workflow

When a commit seems lost run git reflog to find the commit hash then bring the commit back with a checkout or reset.

Example commands

git reflog

git checkout -b recover

or

git reset --hard if the goal is to move a branch back to a found hash. Prefer creating a branch when unsure to avoid destroying work.

Important notes

Reflog entries are local and expire based on garbage collection settings so do not rely on reflog as a permanent backup. Push important branches to remote or tag commits to preserve them across machines.

Tip

When a mistaken reset or rebase happens run git reflog first then create a branch from the desired reflog hash using git checkout -b This preserves work and prevents frantic typing of commands without knowing the target commit.

title: git status command example
description: Learn how to read git status output stage changes and confirm commits with clear examples and commands for faster troubleshooting
heading: git status command example explained for beginners
body:
This guide teaches how to use the git status command to inspect repository state and decide the next steps.

  1. Run the command to view current state
  2. Understand untracked modified and staged categories
  3. Stage files for commit
  4. Commit staged changes
  5. Verify status after changes

Run the command to view current state Use git status in the repository root. The command prints branch name tracked changes and whether local history is ahead or behind the remote. This is the safest starting point before making changes.

Understand untracked modified and staged categories The output groups files into untracked modified and changes to be committed. Untracked files are new files that are not tracked by Git. Modified files are tracked but have changes in the working directory. Staged files are ready for the next commit.

Stage files for commit Use git add path/to/file to stage a single file or git add . to stage many files. Staging prepares a snapshot for the commit step. Think of staging as picking which changes deserve to live in history.

Commit staged changes Use git commit -m "short message" to record staged snapshots in the local repository. Commit messages should be concise and descriptive so future humans will thank the author.

Verify status after changes Run git status again to confirm that the staging area is clean and that the working directory has no unexpected changes. The command also reports whether pushes or pulls may be required to sync with the remote.

The tutorial showed how to run the status command interpret the three main output categories stage files commit changes and recheck status so that daily workflows cause fewer surprises.

Tip

Tip Use git status -s for a compact summary when dealing with many files and use clear commit messages to make the status output meaningful over time.

title: How the Git Working Tree Works by Example
description: Practical guide to how the Git working tree index and repository interact using clear example commands and explanations
heading: How the Git Working Tree Works by Example Explained
body:
This tutorial shows how the Git working tree the index and the repository interact using concrete commands and small examples.

  1. Initialize a repository and inspect status
  2. Create a file and observe the working tree
  3. Stage the file and inspect the index
  4. Modify the file and compare working tree and index
  5. Commit and examine the repository history

Start with a clean sandbox. Run git init then git status to see that the working tree has no tracked files yet. This step proves a repository starts empty and status will point out the lonely files.

Create a file named hello.txt and add some text. Run git status again to observe that the working tree contains an untracked file. The working tree reflects the current project files on the filesystem.

Stage the file using git add hello.txt then run git status --short or git ls-files --stage to peek into the index. The index acts as a staging area that records a snapshot ready for the next commit. Think of staging as a photo studio where files get their glamour shots taken before a public release.

Edit hello.txt and use git diff to compare the working tree with the index. Use git diff --staged to compare the index with the last commit. These commands clarify differences between the three states and prevent surprises when crafting commits.

Commit with git commit -m "add hello" and inspect history using git log --oneline. The repository holds the committed snapshots and the HEAD pointer moves with each commit. That completes the flow from working tree to index to repository.

The walkthrough demonstrated how changes travel from working tree to index to repository and how common commands reveal each state without drama or hand waving.

Tip

Use git status --porcelain for machine friendly output and git restore --staged to unstage changes without losing work.

title: git stash list example
description: Quick guide to using git stash list to view inspect and manage saved changes with practical commands and examples
heading: git stash list example how to view and manage stashes
body:
This tutorial shows how to use git stash list to inspect saved changes and manage stashes efficiently.

  1. List stashes
  2. Inspect a stash
  3. Apply or pop a stash
  4. Create a named stash
  5. Remove stashes

List stashes with a single command to see all saved work. Use git stash list to display entries like stash@{0} and the message given when the stash was created. This provides a quick index of saved changes.

Inspect a stash to understand what was saved before restoring. Run git stash show -p stash@{0} to view a full patch. That patch helps decide whether to restore specific hunks or abandon passenger changes.

Apply or pop a stash when ready to bring saved changes back into the working tree. Use git stash apply stash@{1} to reapply without removing the stash from the list. Use git stash pop to apply and remove the top stash as a single move. Pop is convenient and slightly reckless if the working tree already contains conflicts.

Create a named stash for clarity when multiple tasks are active. Use git stash push -m "WIP feature X" to attach a human friendly message. Named stashes make git stash list output far less cryptic and far more useful when backtracking.

Remove stashes to keep the stash list tidy. Use git stash drop stash@{0} to remove a specific entry. Use git stash clear to delete all stashes for dramatic cleanup. Beware of losing work with a single command.

The short workflow covered listing stashes inspecting patches choosing apply or pop creating named stashes and cleaning up obsolete entries. Follow these steps to keep saved work organized and recoverable without chaos.

Tip

When unsure apply a stash in a separate temporary branch with git checkout -b temp-restore then git stash apply stash@{0}. That approach protects main branches from accidental conflicts and makes stash inspection less stressful.

title: git stash untracked files example
description: Learn how to stash untracked files in git with clear commands and examples to keep new files safe when switching branches
heading: git stash untracked files example tutorial
body:
This tutorial gives a quick practical guide to stashing untracked files in git and recovering those files safely when switching branches.

  1. Check the working tree state
  2. Choose stash mode
  3. Create the stash with a message
  4. Inspect the stash
  5. Restore or remove the stash

Check the working tree state Use git status to see tracked changes and new untracked files. That command shows file names so no guessing while moving between branches.

Choose stash mode Use the normal stash to save tracked changes only or add the untracked flag to include new files. For new files that are not ignored use git stash push -u -m "WIP untracked". To include ignored files add --all instead of the untracked flag when the repository has global ignore rules.

Create the stash with a message A clear message prevents future head scratching. Example command git stash push -u -m "WIP untracked" stores tracked changes and untracked files together. The stash acts like a temporary branch so switching branches will be safe.

Inspect the stash Use git stash list to view available stashes. For a diff preview use git stash show -p stash@{0} to confirm that the correct files are in the stash before applying anything.

Restore or remove the stash Use git stash apply stash@{0} to reapply changes while keeping the stash entry. Use git stash pop to reapply and remove the stash entry in one go. If a stash is no longer needed remove the entry with git stash drop stash@{0}.

The steps covered how to see file status create a stash that includes untracked files inspect the stash content and restore or drop the stash when finished. This approach helps avoid lost work and ugly surprises while juggling branches with new files present.

Tip

Give stashes descriptive messages and prefer git stash push -u -m "WIP untracked" so the purpose of each stash is obvious later when the repository starts accumulating hopeful quick saves.

title: How to Use the Git Clean Command by Example
description: Practical git clean examples to safely preview and remove untracked and ignored files using dry run and force options.
heading: How to Use the Git Clean Command by Example
body:
This tutorial teaches how to preview and safely remove untracked files and directories using the git clean command.

  1. Preview what would be removed
  2. Remove untracked files
  3. Include directories in the removal
  4. Handle ignored files with care
  5. Use interactive mode when unsure

Preview what would be removed by running a dry run. Use a preview before any destructive action. Example command in a repository root shows candidates without deleting them

git clean -n or git clean -nd

Remove untracked files when previews look safe. The force flag is required to prevent accidental deletions. This clears stray files that do not belong in version control

git clean -f

Include directories when the workspace contains untracked folders. The directory flag tells the command to remove both files and directories from the working tree

git clean -fd

Handle ignored files only when explicitly desired. The lowercase x removes tracked excluded files and the uppercase X removes only ignored files. Use these flags with extreme caution when generated build files or local configs are present

git clean -fdx and git clean -fdX

Use interactive mode to pick and choose. The interactive flag opens a prompt for selective removal. This is useful when human judgment is still required

git clean -i

Extra safety notes include making a commit or a stash before running destructive commands. Backups prevent regret. Also consider adding safe patterns to .gitignore or using exclude rules for local exceptions.

Recap This guide covered how to preview and remove untracked files and directories with git clean using dry run force directory and ignored file options along with interactive mode. Preview first and protect work before running any destructive command.

Tip

Always run a dry run first and consider a quick stash or commit before using force. Use interactive mode for surgical cleanup and add safe patterns to ignore lists to avoid repeated scrub jobs.

title: How to git clean Untracked Files with the fdx Switch
description: Learn to safely remove untracked and ignored files using git clean -fdx with a dry run and easy recovery tips
heading: How to git clean Untracked Files with the fdx Switch
body:
This article shows how to use git clean with the -fdx switch to remove untracked and ignored files safely from a repository using a dry run and a cautious execution plan.

  1. Preview removal with a dry run
  2. Back up anything important
  3. Run the destructive clean
  4. Verify repository state

Run git clean -ndx from the repository root to see what would be removed. The -n flag performs a dry run so the working tree stays intact while a list of candidate files shows up for review.

Back up any file that matters before removing anything. Untracked files are not captured by commits so copy important files to a safe folder or add files to a temporary branch if version history is desired.

Execute the actual removal with git clean -fdx once comfortable with the dry run results. Flags explained as separate notes. -n shows a dry run. -f forces removal. -d removes untracked directories. -x deletes files that are normally ignored by ignore rules.

Verify cleaning results with git status and run git clean -ndx again to confirm that the working tree no longer contains unwanted untracked files.

This tutorial covered previewing untracked files with a dry run backing up important files performing the removal with -fdx and verifying repository state to avoid accidental loss while keeping the operation efficient and fast.

Tip

When unsure exclude patterns with git clean -e pattern -ndx to protect files that look disposable but are actually important. If fear runs high create a zipped backup of the working directory first.

title: Difference between HashMap and Hashtable in Java
description: Quick guide on key differences between HashMap and Hashtable in Java covering synchronization null keys performance iteration and modern alternatives
heading: Difference between HashMap and Hashtable in Java Explained
body:
The key difference between HashMap and Hashtable in Java is that HashMap is not synchronized and not thread safe while Hashtable is synchronized and thread safe.

Here are the practical differences that matter during coding

  1. Synchronization and thread safety HashMap offers no built in synchronization. Multiple threads modifying a HashMap concurrently may cause corrupted data. Hashtable synchronizes methods so access is safe across threads at the cost of performance.
  2. Null keys and values HashMap allows one null key and many null values. Hashtable rejects null keys and null values and will throw a runtime exception when one is supplied.
  3. Legacy and API Hashtable dates from early Java versions and predates the Collections framework. HashMap is part of the modern Collections framework and is preferred for new code when external synchronization is not needed.
  4. Performance HashMap is faster in single thread or externally synchronized scenarios. Hashtable pays the cost of synchronized methods on nearly every operation which slows common use cases.
