Step 3 Open a PDF viewer that UiPath can interact with and launch the Data Scraping wizard. Click the first cell of the visible table and then the second to let the wizard detect the pattern. The wizard can handle repeating rows which makes life easier.

Step 4 Set the wizard output to a DataTable variable. Name the variable something memorable like extractedTable so the workflow reads like documentation.

Step 5 Use simple cleaning actions such as Trim and Convert.ToInt32 or Parse for numeric columns. A few Assign activities or a short Invoke Code can fix most formatting quirks.

Step 6 Add an Excel Application Scope and a Write Range activity to persist the DataTable to disk. Overwrite an existing sheet during testing so multiple runs do not produce mystery files.

Step 7 Run the project and open the workbook. If column alignment looks off revisit selector accuracy or try increasing OCR accuracy for scanned sources.

The tutorial covered building a repeatable UiPath pipeline from reading PDF content to scraping structured table data and exporting a cleaned DataTable into Excel for downstream use.

Tip

Prefer Read PDF Text when source PDFs are digital for speed and precision. Use anchored selectors when tables span pages and test with several sample documents to avoid surprises.

title: How to create and build a DataTable in UiPath Example
description: Build and populate a DataTable in UiPath using Build Data Table Add Data Column and Add Data Row with clear step by step examples
heading: How to create and build a DataTable in UiPath Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to create and build a DataTable in UiPath using the Build Data Table Add Data Column and Add Data Row activities and then process or export the resulting table.

  1. Create a DataTable variable and add a Build Data Table activity
  2. Define columns with the designer or Add Data Column activity
  3. Add rows manually with Add Data Row or import from a source
  4. Process rows using For Each Row and perform desired actions
  5. Export or inspect the DataTable using Write Range or Output Data Table

Step one requires a variable of type DataTable named dt for clarity. Drag a Build Data Table activity into the workflow and use the designer to create column names and data types. The designer saves a quick schema so the rest of the workflow has something sane to work with.

Step two gives a choice. Use the Build Data Table designer to define columns up front or add columns dynamically with Add Data Column during runtime. Dynamic columns are useful when incoming data has unpredictable fields. Dynamic columns also make debugging slightly more exciting.

Step three populates the DataTable. Use Add Data Row when inserting individual rows. For bulk loads consider Read CSV or Read Range then assign to the DataTable variable. Example of a single row using an ArrayRow property is shown here

ArrayRow = { "Alice", 30 }

Step four processes each row. Use For Each Row in the DataTable and then access columns by row item name like row("Name").ToString. Use Assign activities to transform data and Write Line or Log Message to inspect values while debugging.

Step five covers output. Use Write Range to send the DataTable to Excel or use Output Data Table followed by Write Line to get a quick textual view in the console. Choose the method that matches the downstream target for the data.

After following these steps the workflow will have a well formed DataTable that can be filtered transformed and exported. The Build Data Table activity gives a fast start while Add Data Column and Add Data Row provide runtime flexibility.

Tip

Use Output Data Table during development to get a readable string of the table for logs. That makes debugging far less painful than staring at a null reference error.

title: Add Rows to DataTables in UiPath
description: Learn practical ways to add rows to UiPath DataTables using Add Data Row and VB expressions for reliable automation
heading: Add Rows to DataTables in UiPath Efficiently and Correctly
body:
This tutorial gives a compact workflow for adding rows to a UiPath DataTable using built in activities and small VB expressions

  1. Prepare the DataTable structure
  2. Use Add Data Row activity when values are simple
  3. Create a DataRow programmatically when more control is needed
  4. Populate values with correct types and column mapping
  5. Persist results by writing or merging DataTables

Prepare the DataTable by using Build Data Table for new schemas or Read Range to get structure from a sheet. Choosing the right schema prevents type mismatch errors and saves debugging time. The workflow will be happier when columns match the incoming data.

The Add Data Row activity is the fastest route when the row data is available as an array or object array. Configure ArrayRow with an array of values that match column order. This activity is perfect for simple row inserts and for designers who dislike code.

For scenarios that require per column logic create a DataRow via expression and then Add with Rows Add. Example expressions show how to create and fill a row before adding to the DataTable. This method gives full access to column names and types and avoids surprises when values need conversion.

Populate values by addressing columns by name or index. Use conversions where required such as CInt or DateTime.Parse to match column types. Mapping by name improves readability and reduces bugs when column order changes.

Persist data by writing back to Excel with Write Range or by merging with another DataTable using Merge or ImportRow when combining multiple sources. Merge preserves schema and handles duplicates more gracefully than naive appends.

The tutorial covered building or reading a DataTable adding rows by activity or code populating columns properly and writing or merging results for downstream processing

Tip

Use DataTable.Clone to copy schema only before importing rows from another source. Clone prevents silent schema mismatches and lets column types be validated early which avoids runtime surprises

title: How to Save UiPath DataTables to Excel Example
description: Step by step guide to export UiPath DataTable objects to Excel using Write Range and Excel Application Scope with examples and tips
heading: How to Save UiPath DataTables to Excel Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to save a UiPath DataTable to an Excel workbook using common activities and practical tips.

  1. Prepare DataTable
  2. Open Excel workbook
  3. Use Write Range
  4. Handle headers and append
  5. Save and verify

Prepare DataTable The DataTable object must contain desired rows and columns. Use Build Data Table or read from a source with Read Range. Validate column names before writing to avoid surprises.

Open Excel workbook Use Excel Application Scope to open or create a workbook. That session ensures proper closing and reduces file lock problems during automation.

Use Write Range Place a Write Range activity inside the scope. Set the DataTable property to the variable that holds data. Turn AddHeaders on when the first row contains column names and choose the correct sheet name.

Handle headers and append To add rows to an existing sheet use Append Range or locate the last used row and use Write Range with a starting cell. Align DataTable columns with worksheet columns to prevent column shifts.

Save and verify Close the Excel Application Scope after writing. Use Read Range or open the saved file to confirm expected data. Adding simple log messages after a successful write helps troubleshooting when workflows misbehave.

This tutorial covered how to export a DataTable to Excel using Excel Application Scope and Write Range plus handling headers and append scenarios. Following these steps will produce a reliable workbook export for RPA workflows.

Tip

Use Workbook activities when the robot runs on a machine without Excel installed. Set AddHeaders to True to preserve column names. For large DataTable objects consider writing CSV first for performance and then convert to XLSX if formatting is required.

title: How to use UiPath Append Range with Excel Example
description: Step by step guide to using UiPath Append Range with Excel to add rows without overwriting data and fix common problems
heading: How to use UiPath Append Range with Excel Example
body:
This tutorial shows at a high level how to use the UiPath Append Range activity to add rows to an Excel worksheet without overwriting existing data and how to verify and troubleshoot the result.

  1. Prepare source data
  2. Select workbook approach
  3. Configure Append Range
  4. Run and verify
  5. Troubleshoot common issues

Prepare source data Use Build Data Table or Read Range to produce a System DataTable that holds new rows. Confirm column names match target sheet headers to prevent misalignment and missing values.

Select workbook approach Use Excel Application Scope when the Excel application must be used or use Workbook activities when Excel is not available. The Workbook approach runs faster for unattended jobs and avoids COM locks.

Configure Append Range Place the Append Range activity inside the chosen scope or call the workbook activity directly. Pass the DataTable variable to the DataTable field and set the SheetName string. Leave StartingCell blank to append after the last used row and toggle AddHeaders according to whether the target sheet already has headers.

Run and verify Execute the workflow and open the workbook to confirm new rows appear below existing data. If rows do not appear check that the DataTable has rows and that the sheet name matches exactly including case if needed.

Troubleshoot common issues If the target file is locked close other processes or use Kill Process responsibly. If duplicates appear verify source data filtering or unique keys. For large volumes consider batching or using workbook activities to reduce Excel interop overhead.

This tutorial covered creating or reading a DataTable preparing the correct workbook approach configuring the Append Range activity and validating results along with practical troubleshooting tips for lock and performance problems.

Tip

Tip When appending many rows write to a temporary sheet first and then move the block to the main sheet or use workbook activities to minimize Excel application interactions and improve speed.

title: UiPath Extract PDF Text & Save to Excel Example
description: Extract text from PDFs with UiPath and export structured data to Excel in a few practical steps with tips and error handling
heading: UiPath Extract PDF Text and Save to Excel Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to extract text from PDF files using UiPath and save the results into an Excel workbook.

  1. Create a new UiPath project and add PDF and Excel packages
  2. Use Read PDF Text or Read PDF With OCR activity to capture text from PDF
  3. Parse the extracted text using string methods or regular expressions
  4. Build a DataTable and populate rows with parsed fields
  5. Use Excel Application Scope and Write Range to save the DataTable
  6. Add error handling and run tests across sample files

Start with a clean project and use Manage Packages to install UiPath.PDF.Activities and UiPath.Excel.Activities. That supplies Read PDF Text and Excel Application Scope activities that form the backbone of the workflow.

Choose Read PDF Text for native searchable PDFs. Choose Read PDF With OCR for scanned pages that look like someone glued a photocopy of a ransom note onto a scanner bed. Set the file path and test the output string to verify that the text extraction returns usable content.

Parsing strategy depends on document consistency. Use simple Split and Trim operations for fixed line formats. Use regular expressions to capture invoices dates totals and other structured fields when patterns exist. Test patterns interactively to avoid broken rows.

Create a DataTable using Build Data Table or an Assign with a new System.Data.DataTable. Add columns that match the target Excel layout and use Add Data Row to append each parsed record during a loop over files or pages.

Wrap Excel operations in Excel Application Scope then use Write Range to dump the DataTable. For a lighter approach use Write CSV when Excel formatting is not required. Keep file locks in mind when running multiple processes in parallel.

Add Try Catch blocks around PDF read and Excel write activities and log exceptions. Run tests with a mix of ideal and messy PDFs to validate resilience. Save sample files for debugging convenience.

This tutorial covered extracting text from PDF with UiPath parsing that text into structured fields and writing the result into an Excel workbook for downstream use. The steps form a repeatable pattern that replaces manual copy paste and scales to batches of documents.

Tip

When PDFs are scanned use a stronger OCR engine and fine tune scales and languages. Keep regular expressions modular and store sample files for regression testing to speed troubleshooting.

title: UiPath Invoice Processing Demo
description: Step by step demo for building UiPath invoice processing using Document Understanding OCR validation and export for faster accounts payable automation
heading: UiPath Invoice Processing Demo Guide
body:
This tutorial teaches building an end to end invoice processing workflow in UiPath using Document Understanding OCR validation and export.

  1. Prepare sample invoices and define required fields
  2. Create a UiPath project and add Document Understanding packages
  3. Configure OCR and choose an extractor model
  4. Train and test the extractor with sample documents
  5. Implement a validation station for human review
  6. Export extracted data and handle exceptions

Step 1 Gather a representative set of invoices with different layouts and required fields such as vendor name invoice date line items and total amount. A varied sample helps the model learn real world chaos.

Step 2 Start a new UiPath project and install Document Understanding and relevant OCR packages. Add workflows for ingestion processing and output so the process looks like an actual product and not a prototype from a weekend hackathon.

Step 3 Choose an OCR engine that balances accuracy and cost. Configure a machine learning extractor or use predefined templates for consistent suppliers. Use pre processing like image cleaning to boost recognition rates.

Step 4 Label training documents and run training cycles. Validate results against ground truth and iterate until field accuracy meets business needs. Keep metrics on precision recall and field level confidence to prove progress.

Step 5 Add a Validation Station for human review of low confidence fields. Route questionable records to accounts payable specialists and log reviewer corrections for retraining. Human oversight keeps the automation from becoming a chaos machine.

Step 6 Map extracted fields to target systems and export to CSV ERP or a database. Implement exception handling for unreadable pages missing totals or mismatched line items so the bot does not crash during month end.

The workflow demonstrated shows how to move from raw invoices to validated structured data using UiPath Document Understanding. Follow the steps to build a repeatable pipeline with measurable accuracy and human in the loop checks.

Tip

Track confidence scores per field and use a dynamic threshold to decide when to ask for human review. That approach reduces review volume while keeping quality high which means less fire fighting during close.

title: UiPath Set Reading Order to Inferred for Adobe
description: Quick tutorial on setting Adobe reading order to Inferred so UiPath extracts PDF text more reliably for automation and document understanding
heading: UiPath Set Reading Order to Inferred for Adobe PDF extraction
body:
This tutorial shows how to change Adobe reading order to Inferred so UiPath can extract text from PDFs more reliably during automation.

  1. Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro
  2. Open the Accessibility tools and launch the Reading Order panel
  3. Select the Inferred reading order option and apply to the document
  4. Save the modified PDF with the new reading order embedded
  5. Use the appropriate UiPath activity to read the PDF and verify results

Step 1 Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro so access to the Accessibility tools becomes available. Acrobat Reader lacks the authoring features needed here.

Step 2 Navigate to Tools then Accessibility and launch the Reading Order panel. The panel reveals visual blocks and a menu for choosing how logical flow gets determined.

Step 3 Choose the Inferred option so the document structure is guessed from layout and tags. This helps assistive technologies and improves deterministic behavior for UiPath when dealing with complex columns and floating objects.

Step 4 Save the PDF using Save or Save As so the new reading order becomes part of the file. If the original file remains unchanged UiPath will keep reading the old structure and users will curse silently.

Step 5 In UiPath use Read PDF Text for searchable documents or Read PDF With OCR for scanned images. Point the activity to the saved PDF and test extraction on sample pages before rolling to production.

Applying an inferred reading order often fixes misplaced text fragments and wrong line sequences that break downstream parsing. A quick check of a few representative pages usually reveals whether the change helped or whether manual tagging is needed.

Tip

If PDF still reads poorly try running the Make Accessible action in Acrobat to add tags then reapply the Inferred reading order. For scanned pages consider a higher quality OCR engine and vendor specific options inside UiPath for better accuracy.

title: How to Maximize Document Windows in a UiPath Sequence
description: Quick guide to maximize document windows in a UiPath sequence for more reliable selectors and predictable automation.
heading: How to Maximize Document Windows in a UiPath Sequence
body:
This tutorial shows how to maximize document windows in a UiPath sequence to improve selector reliability and create predictable automation flows.

  1. Attach to the target window
  2. Apply the Maximize Window activity
  3. Stabilize selectors for the maximized state
  4. Add waits and verify the window state
  5. Run tests and handle edge cases

Step one starts by locating the target window with Attach Window or Use Application Browser. The automation must point to the correct window so downstream activities do not click on the wrong guest star.

Step two uses the Maximize Window activity. This activity is more reliable than sending hotkeys because the activity talks to the UI framework directly and reduces mystery failures when users move monitors around.

Step three focuses on selector hygiene. Update selectors to match the maximized window structure and add wildcards for volatile attributes. Anchors and selectors based on stable attributes prevent fragile automation from breaking when a dialog sneaks onto the stage.

Step four recommends adding Wait For Element and Element Exists checks after the maximize action. These checks confirm the window reached the expected state before attempting clicks or typing. A short delay can be used as a safety net but avoid relying on blind waits for long periods.

Step five is all about testing. Run the sequence in different screen resolutions and with multiple monitors attached. Log window existence and selector outcomes so failures are easy to trace and do not feel like random gremlins.

Summary recap The tutorial covered attaching to a window using Attach Window or Use Application Browser applying the Maximize Window activity cleaning up selectors adding verification checks and testing across environments to ensure stable automation.

Tip

Use the Maximize Window activity before critical UI interactions and pair that action with Element Exists checks to catch odd window focus issues early.

title: How to use UiPath Hotkeys Example
description: Learn a compact UiPath hotkeys tutorial to send keyboard shortcuts select targets and speed up automation workflows
heading: How to use UiPath Hotkeys Example for faster automation
body:
This tutorial demonstrates how to use UiPath hotkeys to send keyboard shortcuts and control applications in automated workflows.

  1. Create a new sequence in UiPath Studio and open the target application
  2. Add a Send Hotkey activity or use Type Into when needed
  3. Select the UI element with the recorder or the Indicate on Screen tool
  4. Choose the key and modifiers such as Ctrl or Alt
  5. Adjust properties like SimulateType or SendWindowMessages for reliability
  6. Run and debug the workflow with careful logging

Step one sets up the workspace and opens the target application so the automation has a visible subject. No drama here just a sequence and an app window.

The second step picks the messaging mechanism. The Send Hotkey activity sends a single keyboard action efficiently. The Type Into activity types full strings when shortcuts are not enough.

Step three secures the correct target element. Use the Indicate on Screen action to capture a reliable selector. Poor selectors cause flaky behavior and dramatic debugging sessions.

Step four chooses the actual keys. Select standard keys like Enter or combinations like Ctrl plus C for copy. Add modifiers from the activity dropdown and avoid hard coded delays when possible.

Step five tunes reliability. SimulateType and SendWindowMessages often avoid focus problems. Use a short Delay before a hotkey when the application needs time to become active.

Step six runs the flow and watches the output panel for selector errors. Add logs around critical hotkey calls so troubleshooting does not feel like fortune telling.

This tutorial covered choosing the right activity capturing the correct UI element setting key combos and improving reliability with activity properties so keyboard shortcuts execute predictably in UiPath workflows.

Tip

Prefer Send Hotkey with SimulateType when interacting with modern applications. If selectors fail capture a slightly larger parent element and use reliable anchor attributes rather than screen coordinates.

title: How to move files between folders in UiPath Example
description: Quick guide to moving files between folders using UiPath with Move File activity variables and basic error handling
heading: How to move files between folders in UiPath Example
body:
This tutorial shows a practical UiPath workflow that moves files between folders with variable driven paths and simple error handling for reliable automation.

  1. Prepare variables and folder paths
  2. Use the Move File activity
  3. Add error handling and logging
  4. Test the workflow

Step 1 Prepare variables and folder paths

Create clear string variables such as sourcePath and destinationPath. Use absolute paths to avoid surprises. Check existence with Directory.Exists before attempting any move. This avoids the common rookie mistake of sending the robot on a wild goose file chase.

Step 2 Use the Move File activity

Drag the Move File activity into the sequence. Bind the Activity properties to the variables created earlier. For overwriting use a conditional check and a Delete activity if replacing a file is desired. The Move File activity performs the actual transfer with minimal fuss.

Step 3 Add error handling and logging

Wrap the file operations in a Try Catch block. Catch System.IO.IOException and other relevant exceptions and log meaningful messages with a Log Message activity. Logging prevents staring at the screen wondering why the robot decided to nap.

Step 4 Test the workflow

Run the workflow with sample files and edge cases such as missing folders and locked files. Observe logs and refine path checks and exception handling until behavior matches expectations. Manual testing avoids deploying a tantrum prone robot.

The workflow described moves files reliably between folders while handling the usual problems that appear when working with file systems. Following the four steps yields a maintainable approach that scales from simple tasks to larger automation chains.

Tip

Use dynamic timestamps in destination file names to avoid collisions when the source may contain duplicate names. That keeps history and prevents accidental overwrites without complicated logic.

title: How to UiPath Move Invoices to a New Directory After Process
description: Move processed invoices with UiPath using folder variables For Each Move File and basic error handling to keep invoice folders tidy and auditable
heading: How to UiPath Move Invoices to a New Directory After Processing
body:
High level overview This tutorial teaches a simple UiPath workflow to move invoices from an incoming folder to a processed folder after extraction and validation. The goal is tidy folders reliable logging and minimal manual babysitting.

  1. Prepare folders and variables
  2. Loop through invoice files
  3. Process and validate invoice data
  4. Move processed files to archive folder
  5. Handle errors and log actions

Prepare folders and variables Create two folders one for new invoices and one for processed invoices. Define clear variables such as inFolder and processedFolder and test access rights so the robot can read and write files.

Loop through invoice files Use Directory.GetFiles or UiPath activity to obtain a file list. A For Each activity provides a neat way to iterate through file names and avoid hard coded paths.

Process and validate invoice data Use the usual extraction activities or an OCR step when required. Validate key fields such as invoice number date and total before moving any file. Add logging for successful and failed validations.

Move processed files to archive folder Use the Move File activity to place processed invoices into the processed folder. Consider appending a timestamp or GUID to the file name to avoid overwrites and to aid audit trails.

Handle errors and log actions Wrap file processing in a Try Catch activity. On exception use logging and optionally move problematic files to a quarantine folder for manual review. Graceful failure beats silent loss of data.

Summary The workflow covers folder setup looping file processing moving files and basic exception handling to produce a repeatable invoice archival routine. The result keeps the incoming folder clean and creates an auditable processed archive for downstream reporting.

Tip

Use a naming convention with timestamps or transaction ids when moving files to avoid collisions and to make traceability painless for auditors and sleepy developers.

title: UiPath OCR Image Example
description: A compact guide to using UiPath OCR to extract text from images using Tesseract and Microsoft OCR for better RPA data capture
heading: UiPath OCR Image Example Extract Text from Images
body:
This tutorial shows how to use UiPath OCR activities to extract text from images using different OCR engines and simple preprocessing.

  1. Prepare project and install OCR packages
  2. Add image and choose OCR activity
  3. Configure OCR engine and options
  4. Run and inspect extracted text
  5. Post process and validate output

Prepare project and install OCR packages Install UiPath packages such as Microsoft OCR and Tesseract from Manage Packages. Set project dependencies and import namespaces so the workflow can call OCR activities without drama.

Add image and choose OCR activity Use Read Image Text or OCR Read Text and point the activity to an image file or screen region. For screenshots use Anchor Base when layout may shift.

Configure OCR engine and options Select Microsoft OCR for cloud parity and known languages. Select Tesseract for offline processing and custom training. Adjust scale and language to improve recognition from low resolution sources.

Run and inspect extracted text Execute the workflow and check the output variable in Locals or Logs. Expect garbled characters on noisy images and treat confidence scores as a reality check.

Post process and validate output Clean extracted strings with regex and trimming. Use confidence thresholds and pattern matching to route questionable results to human review or retry with different settings.

This guide covered picking an OCR engine, wiring up UiPath activities, running a test extraction and cleaning the output for reliable RPA use. Follow these steps and the results will improve faster than blaming the robot for poor scans.

Tip

Preprocess images by scaling up, increasing contrast and removing background noise to boost OCR accuracy. For repetitive documents use zones and templates and consider training Tesseract for unusual fonts.

title: How to get text from a JPEG image in UiPath Example
description: Step by step guide to extract text from a JPEG using UiPath and OCR with practical tips for accuracy cleanup and error handling
heading: How to get text from a JPEG image in UiPath Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to extract text from a JPEG image using UiPath and an OCR engine

  1. Prepare project and add OCR package
  2. Load the JPEG image into a workflow
  3. Use an OCR activity such as Tesseract or Microsoft OCR
  4. Process and clean the extracted text
  5. Test and handle errors for robust automation

Step 1 Install the UiPath OCR package from the Manage Packages window and add required dependencies. That provides the OCR activities and engines needed for image to text conversion.

Step 2 Use a Load Image activity or Read Image activity to bring the JPEG into the workflow. Make sure the image path is correct and that the image is readable with enough resolution for character recognition.

Step 3 Drop an OCR activity such as Tesseract OCR or Microsoft OCR and configure language and engine settings. Higher DPI and proper language choice improve recognition. For scanned documents try the Computer Vision activities for better layout handling.

Step 4 Take the OCR output and run cleanup routines. Use Trim to remove stray spaces and regex to pull structured fields like dates or numbers. Normalization reduces false positives and prepares the text for downstream use.

Step 5 Add Try Catch around the OCR workflow and log meaningful errors. Handle common cases such as unreadable images or missing files and include retries when the source image arrives from a flaky system.

This tutorial covered preparing a UiPath project adding OCR capabilities loading a JPEG running the OCR engine cleaning the result and adding error handling. The steps aim to get accurate text from images with minimal fuss while keeping the workflow maintainable.

Tip

For better accuracy use pre processing such as contrast adjustment and noise reduction before OCR. A quick resize to 300 DPI often helps more than chasing engine settings.

title: How to Process Scanned Image Invoices with UiPath Example
description: Step by step guide to extract data from scanned image invoices using UiPath including OCR setup data validation and output options
heading: How to Process Scanned Image Invoices with UiPath Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to extract structured data from scanned image invoices using UiPath and OCR so the workflow can turn messy pixels into usable fields.

  1. Create a UiPath project and add Document Understanding and OCR packages
  2. Preprocess scanned images to improve OCR accuracy
  3. Configure an OCR engine and read text from the image
  4. Extract fields using anchor based methods templates or regex
  5. Validate extracted data and export to Excel or a database

Step 1 Create a project using Studio. Add UiPath.DocumentUnderstanding and an OCR package such as Tesseract or Google Cloud OCR. Dependency management saves a lot of future hair pulling.

Step 2 Preprocess images by converting to grayscale resizing to 300 DPI and applying thresholding. Deskewing and noise removal dramatically improve OCR accuracy so the extractor does not invent random numbers.

Step 3 Configure the OCR engine and use Read PDF with OCR or Read Image Text activities. Choose an engine based on language and budget. Always test with a handful of representative invoices rather than gambling on a single sample.

Step 4 For extraction use Anchor Base or Document Understanding classifiers. Regex is handy for invoice numbers and totals. Example regex that avoids punctuation traps is Invoice\s+No\s*([A-Z0-9\-]+). Templates work well when vendor formats are stable.

Step 5 Use Validation Station to confirm extracted fields when accuracy is not perfect. Export a DataTable to Excel with Write Range or push records to a database for downstream processing.

The workflow in this tutorial turns scanned images into validated structured data using common UiPath building blocks. The process improves with better sample documents and iterative tuning of OCR and extraction rules.

Tip

Boost OCR accuracy by standardizing incoming scans to 300 DPI performing deskewing and limiting character sets for known fields. A small whitelist beats endless regex chain fighting random PDFs.

title: OCR with UiPath and Google Cloud Vision Example
description: Learn how to integrate UiPath with Google Cloud Vision for reliable OCR extraction from images and PDFs in a simple example workflow.
heading: OCR with UiPath and Google Cloud Vision Example
body:
This tutorial shows how to connect UiPath with Google Cloud Vision for OCR extraction from images and PDF files and how to handle results inside a UiPath workflow.

  1. Create Google Cloud project and service account
  2. Install UiPath packages and store credentials
  3. Build a UiPath workflow to call the Vision API
  4. Parse JSON response and map text fields
  5. Test and improve accuracy

Create Google Cloud project and enable the Vision API in the Google Cloud Console. Generate a service account with a JSON key file and store that file in a secure folder. Grant only the permissions required for the OCR task so no unnecessary privileges float around.

Install the UiPath.Web.Activities package or use HTTP Request activity depending on preference. Add a secure asset for the path to the JSON key file or for an environment variable that holds credentials. This keeps the credentials out of plain workflow sequences.

Build a workflow that reads images or PDF pages and sends base64 encoded content to the Vision API endpoints. Use language hints for better recognition when documents contain non English text. Use batch requests for multiple pages to save on orchestration overhead.

Parse the JSON response and map relevant fields to data tables or variables. Look for fullTextAnnotation for multi line extraction and use bounding box data for positional logic. Add basic retry and error handling for quota or transient network failures.

Test with a sample set of documents and adjust preprocessing steps like deskewing or contrast enhancement if recognition results need help. Keep an eye on quota and cost while running automated tests so surprises do not show up on the invoice.

The tutorial covered required Google Cloud setup integration choices in UiPath handling of API responses and practical tips for improving OCR accuracy during automation development.

Tip

Feed the OCR engine with clean high resolution images and use language and document type hints. Preprocess scanned pages to remove noise and use local caching during testing to save API quota.

title: Fix GitHub support for password authentication error fast
description: Fast guide to fix GitHub support for password authentication was removed error by switching to personal access tokens or SSH and updating Git settings
heading: Fix GitHub support for password authentication error fast
body:
This guide shows how to fix the GitHub 'support for password authentication was removed' error by switching to a personal access token or SSH key and updating local Git settings.

  1. Choose between personal access token or SSH key
  2. Create a personal access token on GitHub if using HTTPS
  3. Update the repository remote to use the new credential method
  4. Configure a credential helper so frequent prompts disappear
  5. Test a push and pull to confirm success

Step 1 Choose a method based on comfort level. A personal access token is quick and familiar for HTTPS workflows. SSH keys require one time setup and avoid typing credentials later.

Step 2 On GitHub open Settings then Developer settings then Personal access tokens and generate a token with repo scope. Copy the token now because GitHub will not show the token again. Use the token instead of a password when Git asks for credentials.

Step 3 Update the local repository remote. Run git remote set-url origin NEW_REMOTE where NEW_REMOTE is the URL selected from the repository page. For HTTPS use the repository HTTPS URL. For SSH use the SSH URL provided by GitHub after key setup.

Step 4 Configure a credential helper so the token does not need to be entered every time. Use git config --global credential.helper store to save credentials on disk or git config --global credential.helper cache for a temporary cache. Pick the helper that fits the level of security desired.

Step 5 Test by running git push origin main or git pull. If authentication fails check token scopes or ensure the SSH public key is added to the GitHub account.

Recap choose personal access token or SSH key then update the remote and configure a credential helper to stop the password authentication error from blocking repository operations.

Tip

Generate a token with only the minimum scopes required. Treat the token like a password and rotate tokens periodically to reduce risk and maintain sanity.

title: Maven GitHub and Eclipse How to get a Maven project
description: Step by step guide to import a Maven project from GitHub into Eclipse using Git integration and Maven build commands for a clean setup.
heading: Maven GitHub and Eclipse How to get a Maven project
body:
This tutorial shows a compact workflow to import a Maven project hosted on GitHub into Eclipse using the Git and Maven integration.

  1. Prepare local environment
  2. Clone the GitHub repository into Eclipse
  3. Import the cloned repository as a Maven project
  4. Refresh Maven dependencies
  5. Configure Java runtime and build
  6. Run and push changes back to GitHub

Prepare local environment by confirming that Eclipse has EGit and M2E plugins installed and that Java and Maven are available on the development machine. Missing plugins cause awkward errors and slow coffee breaks.

Clone the GitHub repository using Eclipse menu File > Import > Git > Projects from Git > Clone URI or use a local clone and then point Eclipse to the repository folder. The repository remains the canonical source of truth so avoid random local branches without a purpose.

Import the cloned repository as an existing Maven project via File > Import > Maven > Existing Maven Projects. Eclipse reads the pom.xml and builds the project model that powers dependency resolution and run configurations.

Refresh Maven dependencies by right clicking the project and selecting Maven > Update Project or running a command like mvn clean install from a terminal. The Maven lifecycle will download missing libraries and compile the source code.

Configure the Java runtime by checking Project Properties > Java Build Path and verify the installed JRE or JDK matches the project source and target levels. Wrong Java version is the usual source of mysterious compile failures.

Run tests and application using the Run menu or Maven goals. Commit changes with EGit and push to GitHub using Team > Commit and Push or the repository view. Commit messages that explain why are appreciated by future self and teammates.

This tutorial covered preparation of the environment cloning the repository importing as a Maven project resolving dependencies configuring Java and performing a build and push to GitHub for a working development loop.

Tip

If dependency problems persist delete the local Maven repository folder for the problematic artifacts and run mvn clean install again to force fresh downloads. That trick fixes many dependency gremlins.

title: Git Branch Create Command Examples
description: Examples of creating Git branches with commands and best practices for local and remote branches
heading: Git Branch Create Command Examples Guide
body:
This tutorial teaches how to create branches in Git using common commands and best practices to avoid merge trouble.

  1. Create and switch to a new branch locally
  2. Create a branch without switching
  3. Create a branch from a specific commit or tag
  4. Publish a new branch to a remote and set upstream
  5. Verify branches and cleanup when finished

Create and switch

Use the shortcut command to make a new branch and start working on the branch in one move. Example command

git checkout -b feature-name

The command makes the branch and moves HEAD to the branch so the working tree reflects the new branch. That approach saves a step and keeps workflow snappy.

Create without switching

When stage setup needs a branch created but the current working directory must remain unchanged run

git branch feature-name

The command only records the new branch reference without touching HEAD.

Create from commit or tag

To branch from an older commit or a release tag specify the target reference after the branch name. Example

git branch hotfix v1.2.0

The branch will start from the chosen commit or tag instead of the current commit.

Publish and set upstream

After local work push the branch to the remote and tell Git where to track changes by using

git push -u origin feature-name

That makes future pulls and pushes concise because the branch remembers the remote counterpart.

Verify and cleanup

List branches with the branch command and delete stale branches with safe delete. Example list command

git branch --all

To remove a fully merged branch use

git branch -d old-branch

Recap of the tutorial The guide showed quick ways to create branches locally from current HEAD or specific commits and how to publish branches to a remote for collaboration. The examples keep the focus on practical commands that integrate with normal workflows.

Tip

Prefer descriptive branch names and create small focused branches. That habit makes reviews faster and reduces merge conflicts.

title: Git Branch Create and Checkout in one Command Example
description: Quick guide to create and checkout a Git branch in one command with examples and safe workflow tips
heading: Git Branch Create and Checkout in One Command Example
body:
This tutorial teaches how to create a new Git branch and check out that branch using a single command.

  1. Prepare the repository
  2. Create and switch in one command
  3. Verify branch and push to remote

Prepare the repository. Ensure working tree is clean and branch point is current. Run git status and git pull to update the local copy before creating a new branch.

Create and switch in one command. Use the classic command git checkout -b feature/name or the newer explicit command git switch -c feature/name. Both commands create a branch and move the working directory to that branch in a single step which saves a keystroke and a tiny amount of dignity.

Verify branch and push to remote. Confirm current branch with git branch or git status. To share the branch run git push -u origin feature/name which sets an upstream so future pushes are painless.

Quick recap of the flow. Update local copy then create and switch with one command then push when ready. Using git switch -c provides clearer intent while git checkout -b remains familiar to many. Less typing means more time for meaningful code and less time spent apologizing for forgotten branches.

Tip

Name branches with a clear prefix such as feature/ or fix/ and always start from an updated main branch. That habit prevents surprises and keeps pull requests focused.

title: Git Create New Branch with Local Changes
description: Create a new Git branch when local changes exist and preserve work during branch switch and reapply changes safely
heading: Git Create New Branch with Local Changes Guide
body:
This guide shows how to create a new Git branch when local changes exist while keeping local work safe and recoverable.

  1. Save current work in a stash or make a local commit
  2. Create the new branch
  3. Bring saved work into the new branch
  4. Resolve any merge conflicts and continue developing

Save current work in a stash or make a local commit

If the working tree contains half finished changes use git stash push -m "WIP" to tuck work away without cluttering history. For those who prefer a record make a quick local commit with git add . && git commit -m "WIP". Both approaches keep the workspace safe while switching branches.

Create the new branch

Create the branch where the new feature or fix belongs. Use git checkout -b new-branch or the newer command git switch -c new-branch. That command sets HEAD to the new branch and prepares the repo for new work.

Bring saved work into the new branch

If a stash was used run git stash pop to apply changes to the new branch and drop the stash. If a local commit was used run git cherry-pick COMMIT_HASH or reset and apply as desired. This step moves the actual work into the correct branch context.

Resolve any merge conflicts and continue developing

Conflicts may appear when applying saved changes. Use standard conflict resolution tools then finish with git add and git commit to complete the merge. Now the new branch has the local work and the repo is clean enough for pushing or further commits.

Practice these steps for a smooth branch workflow and fewer panicked moments during development. This process preserves local effort while enabling branch organization and collaboration.

Tip

Prefer descriptive stash messages and small WIP commits. That makes recovery painless and avoids guessing what a stash or commit contains later on.

title: Quickly Fix Git fatal no upstream branch error
description: Fix Git fatal The current branch has no upstream branch error fast Learn push and set upstream commands to sync a local branch with remote
heading: Quickly Fix Git fatal no upstream branch error
body:
This tutorial shows how to fix the Git fatal The current branch has no upstream branch error and push a local branch to a remote.

  1. Check the current branch name
  2. Push and set upstream in one step
  3. Set a tracking branch manually if preferred
  4. Push changes and verify the remote

Check the current branch name

Run git branch --show-current or git status to confirm the branch name. Knowing the branch name prevents accidental pushes to the wrong branch and avoids mild panic.

Push and set upstream in one step

Use git push -u origin my-branch replacing my-branch with the name found earlier. This command creates a remote branch if missing and makes the local branch track the remote for future pushes and pulls.

Set a tracking branch manually if preferred

If there is a need to set tracking without pushing use git branch --set-upstream-to=origin/my-branch my-branch. That command tells the local branch which remote branch to follow. Helpful when push is not desired yet.

Push changes and verify the remote

After upstream is set run git push to send changes. Confirm remote branches with git branch -r and check that the local branch shows a remote tracking branch in git status. If no remote named origin exists add one with git remote add origin your remote url.

The steps above resolve the fatal The current branch has no upstream branch error by assigning a remote tracking branch and then pushing changes. Use the push and set upstream command for the fastest fix and the manual tracking command when more control is desired.

Tip

Use git push -u origin my-branch once per new branch. Future pushes need only git push. That saves keystrokes and prevents future complaints from the repository.

title: Push a Local Git Branch to a Remote GitHub repo
description: Quick guide to push a local Git branch to a remote GitHub repo with commands for adding remote and setting upstream.
heading: Push a Local Git Branch to a Remote GitHub repo
body:
This guide shows how to push a local Git branch to a remote GitHub repo using a few simple commands and minimal drama.

  1. Create or switch to a branch
  2. Stage and commit changes
  3. Add a remote if missing
  4. Push the branch and set upstream

Create or switch to a branch Use git checkout -b my-branch to create and switch in one step or git checkout my-branch to switch to an existing branch. The branch name should reflect the purpose of the work unless naming chaos is desired.

Stage and commit changes Add changes with git add . or select files with git add path/to/file. Commit with git commit -m "Describe the change briefly". Clear commit messages make future humans grateful.

Add a remote if missing If the local repository has no remote configured use git remote add origin < remote-url> . Replace the placeholder with the repository URL from GitHub. Confirm remote setup with git remote -v.

Push the branch and set upstream Push a branch with git push -u origin my-branch. The -u option sets upstream so future pushes and pulls use the same remote branch with only git push or git pull. If GitHub rejects a push because of missing permissions authenticate with a GitHub token or SSH key according to personal preference.

The sequence above takes local work and publishes the branch to a remote GitHub repository so collaboration can begin. Use descriptive branch names and clear commit messages to keep repository history useful rather than cryptic.

Tip

Use git status before pushing to review staged files and current branch. When a force push becomes tempting consider a safer alternative like rebasing locally and pushing a fresh branch to avoid surprising collaborators.

title: Push a New Local Branch to a Remote GitLab Repository
description: Step by step guide to push a new local branch to a GitLab remote and set upstream for simple future pushes.
heading: Push a New Local Branch to Remote GitLab Repository
body:
This tutorial teaches how to push a new local branch to a remote GitLab repository and set an upstream branch so future pushes are painless.

  1. Create the new local branch
  2. Stage and commit changes
  3. Push the branch to GitLab and set upstream
  4. Verify the branch on the remote

Create the new local branch Use a clear branch name that describes the work. Run git checkout -b feature/name or git switch -c feature/name to create and switch to the branch in one move.

Stage and commit changes Add updated files to the index with git add . or list specific files. Then record changes with git commit -m "Add feature description". Commit messages that explain why a change exists make future humans happier.

Push the branch to GitLab and set upstream Send the new branch to the remote and set the upstream so future pushes do not need the full target. Use git push -u origin feature/name. The -u flag associates the local branch with the remote branch for simple git push later.

Verify the branch on the remote Confirm presence on the GitLab web interface or run git fetch then git branch -r to list remote branches. Merge requests can be opened from the GitLab UI once the branch is visible.

Recap The process covers creating a branch locally staging and committing work pushing the new branch to GitLab with upstream and verifying the branch on the remote. Follow these steps and future pushes become the boring part of development which is exactly the goal.

Tip

Use readable branch names such as feature/auth or fix/login and enable signed commits or a push default like current to reduce typing and avoid accidental pushes to the wrong branch.

title: Git Branch Delete Local Example
description: Learn how to safely delete local Git branches with commands checks and common gotchas explained in a short practical guide
heading: Git Branch Delete Local Example Guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to safely delete local Git branches and avoid common mistakes.

  1. Check current branch
  2. List local branches
  3. Delete branch safely
  4. Force delete when necessary

Check current branch Use git status or git branch to confirm the current branch is not the target for removal. Deleting a checked out branch will either fail or produce awkward surprises.

List local branches Run git branch to see local branch names. Confirm the exact name to avoid typo driven calamity and to verify merge status.

Delete branch safely Use git branch -d feature-name to remove a branch that has already been merged into the current branch or upstream. This is Git being polite and preventing data loss.

Force delete when necessary Use git branch -D feature-name to forcibly remove a branch that is not merged. Use this only when sure that local commits are expendable or already backed up elsewhere.

The tutorial covered how to verify branch context list local branches and remove branches using the safe delete flag and the force delete flag. These commands act quickly so a moment of caution pays off more than a long ceremony.

Tip

When unsure create a backup branch before deletion by running git branch backup/feature-name feature-name This gives an easy restore point and saves grief if history turns out to still be useful

title: Git Delete Remote Branch Example
description: Learn safe commands to remove a remote Git branch and confirm removal on origin with simple steps for GitHub GitLab and other remotes
heading: Git Delete Remote Branch Example Guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to delete a branch on a remote Git repository and how to confirm that removal from origin

  1. Fetch and prune remote state
  2. Delete the local branch when safe
  3. Delete the branch from the remote
  4. Verify remote branch removal

Fetch and prune remote state

Refresh the local view of remote branches to avoid surprises. Use a fetch that also prunes deleted references. Example command

git fetch --prune

Delete the local branch when safe

Remove the local branch only after merging or confirming no work will be lost. Use a safe delete or a force delete if absolutely necessary. Commands

git branch -d feature/name

git branch -D feature/name

Delete the branch from the remote

Push a deletion request to the remote. The modern and explicit command removes the named branch on origin. Example

git push origin --delete feature/name

Verify remote branch removal

Check remote references and list branches on origin to confirm removal. Use one of these commands

git branch -r

git ls-remote --heads origin

Deleting a remote branch is mostly a single push command surrounded by a little housekeeping. Fetch first to avoid surprises. Delete local branches when work is merged or discarded. Push the delete and then verify that origin no longer lists the branch.

Tip

Use descriptive branch naming and open a pull or merge request before deleting. That makes audits painless and avoids the sad git blame stories that start with forgotten branches.

title: Git Rename Branch Example
description: Step by step guide to rename a Git branch locally and on remote with safe commands and cleanup tips for teams
heading: Git Rename Branch Example guide for local and remote
body:
This tutorial shows how to rename a Git branch locally and on the remote while preserving commit history.

  1. Switch to the branch to rename
  2. Rename the local branch
  3. Push the new branch and set upstream
  4. Remove the old branch name from the remote
  5. Tell teammates how to update their clones

Switch to the branch using a modern command like git switch old-branch or the classic git checkout old-branch. This ensures the branch context is correct before any rename action.

Rename the local branch with git branch -m old-branch new-branch. If the current working branch is the one being renamed then git branch -m new-branch works too. Commit history and references on the local clone remain intact.

Publish the new branch name and attach an upstream with git push origin -u new-branch. That command pushes the branch to the remote and sets tracking so future pushes and pulls are straightforward.

Remove the old name from the remote using git push origin --delete old-branch. After that run git fetch --prune to clean up stale remote tracking branches in the local clone.

Ask teammates to update local references by running git fetch origin then either rename local copies with git branch -m old-branch new-branch or checkout the new branch with git checkout new-branch and remove the obsolete local name with git branch -d old-branch. Communication saves time and merge headaches.

This flow renames a branch locally pushes the new name removes the old remote reference and keeps commit history intact while guiding collaborators to stay in sync.

Tip

Create a temporary backup branch like backup/old-branch before deleting the remote name when unsure. That provides a fast rollback path and peace of mind for the team.

title: Remove Git Branches from GitLab
description: Learn how to remove local and remote branches from a GitLab repository using commands and the web UI for a cleaner repo.
heading: Remove Git Branches from GitLab
body:
This tutorial shows how to remove local and remote branches from a GitLab repository and keep history tidy.

  1. Confirm branch and state
  2. Delete local branch
  3. Delete remote branch
  4. Use GitLab UI for bulk cleanup
  5. Handle protected branches and permissions

Check current branches with git branch or git branch -a to see local and remote names. Verify that work has been merged or backed up before removing a branch name from the repository.

Switch off a feature branch by checking out the mainline branch with git checkout main or a project default. Remove a merged branch from the local clone with git branch -d my-branch. Force delete when absolutely sure with git branch -D my-branch but try not to be reckless.

Remove a branch from the remote GitLab repository with git push origin --delete my-branch. The web interface also offers a Delete button on the Repository Branches page for single branch removal and for those who prefer two clicks over a command line.

For bulk cleanup use the GitLab Repository Branches list to filter merged branches and delete many entries. Enable the option to remove the source branch on merge so leftover branches do not multiply like a bad pattern in the commit history.

Protected branches require higher privileges. Unprotect a branch in Project Settings under Repository Protected Branches before attempting deletion or ask a maintainer with proper permissions to perform the removal.

Following these steps keeps a repository tidy and reduces confusion from stale branch names. Use commands for quick precise removal and the web UI for review and bulk operations.

Tip

Enable the remove source branch option on merge requests and set branch protection rules wisely. This spares future developers from cleaning up a branch graveyard and prevents accidental deletion of important branches.

title: How to Tag an Older Git Commit
description: Quick guide to tagging an older Git commit find the hash create a tag push and verify without rewriting history
heading: How to Tag an Older Git Commit Step by Step
body:
This guide shows how to add a tag to an older Git commit without rewriting history or causing chaos.

  1. Locate the commit hash
  2. Create an annotated tag or lightweight tag
  3. Push the tag to the remote
  4. Verify the tag

Locate the commit hash

Use a compact log to find the target commit hash for the commit that requires tagging. For example run git log --oneline and copy the short hash. Graphical tools like gitk help when history looks like a bowl of spaghetti.

Create the tag

Annotated tags are preferred for releases because the tag stores a message author and date. Create an annotated tag with git tag -a v1.2 abc123 -m "release v1.2" where v1.2 is the tag name and abc123 is the commit hash. For a lightweight tag use git tag v1.2 abc123. No need to rewrite history or perform circus tricks.

Push the tag to the remote

Tags do not always travel with branch pushes. Push a single tag with git push origin v1.2 or push all tags with git push --tags. Use the single tag push when caution and teamwork matter.

Verify the tag

Confirm that the tag points to the intended commit with git show v1.2 or list tags with git tag -n. Match the shown hash against the original commit hash to avoid awkward surprises later.

Quick recap The steps covered locating a commit creating an annotated or lightweight tag pushing the tag and confirming the result. This keeps history intact and collaborators less likely to send passive aggressive messages.

Tip

Prefer annotated tags for releases and include meaningful messages. Avoid force pushing tagged branches and teach the team how to fetch tags with git fetch --tags so everyone sees the new release.

title: How to list and switch between GitLab branches
description: Quick guide to list and switch GitLab branches using git commands and the web UI plus safe workflow tips for branch switching
heading: How to list and switch between GitLab branches
body:
This tutorial shows how to list and switch branches in a GitLab repository using local git commands and the GitLab web interface.

  1. Update remote references
  2. List available branches
  3. Switch to an existing branch
  4. Create and track a new branch
  5. Push branch and set upstream

Update remote references

Start by syncing the local repository with remote refs so the branch list is accurate. Run git fetch --all to download updates from origin. This avoids surprises when a developer claims that a branch exists on the server but not locally.

List available branches

Show local branches with git branch and remote branches with git branch -r. For everything together use git branch -a. The output highlights the current branch with a star because the CLI does love tiny visual cues.

Switch to an existing branch

Use modern commands for clarity. Run git switch branch-name to move the working tree to that branch. If the branch exists only on origin use git switch --track origin/branch-name to create a local tracking branch.

Create and track a new branch

To start a new feature branch use git switch -c new-branch-name. That creates the local branch and checks out the branch in one pleasant step. When ready to share run the push step described next.

Push branch and set upstream

Share the branch with the remote using git push -u origin new-branch-name. The -u option sets an upstream so future pulls and pushes do not require explicit remote and branch names. That saves typing and reduces the number of keyboard tantrums.

This guide covered fetching remote updates listing branches switching between branches creating a new branch and pushing with upstream setup. These steps work well on the command line and can be mirrored in the GitLab web UI when creating merge requests or browsing branches.

Tip

Tip Keep the working tree clean before switching branches. Stash uncommitted changes with git stash push -m message or commit to a temporary branch to avoid accidental conflicts and lost work.

title: How to List, Switch and Checkout Git Branches
description: Quick guide to list switch and checkout Git branches with examples for git branch git switch and git checkout
heading: How to List Switch and Checkout Git Branches
body:
This tutorial gives a compact overview of how to list existing branches switch between branches create new branches and checkout files from other branches using common git commands. Expect practical commands and a tiny amount of sarcasm.

  1. List branches git branch and git branch -a and git branch -r
  2. Switch branches git switch feature-branch or git checkout feature-branch
  3. Create and checkout a new branch git switch -c new-branch or git checkout -b new-branch
  4. Go back to previous branch git switch - or git checkout -
  5. Restore a file from another branch git checkout main -- path/to/file or use git restore --source=main path/to/file on newer versions

List branches shows local branch names by default. Add the flag for all to include remote references. This helps when the repository is cluttered and curiosity kicks in.

Switching changes the working tree and the HEAD pointer. Prefer the modern git switch command for branch changes since command intent reads like plain English. The classic git checkout still works and must be tolerated in legacy scripts.

Creating a branch and immediately checking out saves time. Use the -c or -b flag to create while moving HEAD. Naming branches clearly will prevent future awkward conversations with future self.

Switching back to the last branch is shockingly simple with the dash shortcut. Useful when jumping between a bugfix and a feature and pretend multitasking is productive.

Restoring a single file from another branch is lifesaving when a change broke something and only a tiny piece must be recovered. Use the path after the double dash to avoid surprising the working tree.

This guide covered how to list existing branches switch between branches create and checkout new branches and restore files across branches using practical git commands.

Tip

Prefer git switch and git restore on modern Git versions to make intent clear. Always run git status before switching to avoid losing uncommitted work.

title: The GitHub Branch Explained and Demystified
description: Clear guide to GitHub branches why branching matters and how to use branches for safer code changes and cleaner workflows
heading: The GitHub Branch Explained and Demystified for Developers
body:
A branch is a movable pointer to a commit in a Git repository that represents an independent line of development.

Branches let developers work on features fixes or experiments without disrupting the main history. A branch is cheap and fast because Git stores commits once and attaches names to those commits. The main branch usually holds deployable code while feature branches host changes.

Common commands are git branch to list or create a branch git switch or git checkout to move between branches git merge to combine work git rebase to rewrite a branch onto another commit and git push to publish a branch to a remote. Remote tracking branches keep local names linked to GitHub copies for collaboration.

Branching workflows vary. A trunk based approach favors short lived branches and frequent integration. A feature branch approach isolates work for review before merging. Pull requests on GitHub provide a social and technical gate for code review testing and discussion. Yes reviews can be awkward but that is the point.

When merging choose between a regular merge for a clear history or a rebase for a linear history and expect some conflict solving during rebases. Use small focused commits and descriptive branch names such as feature/login-rate-limit or fix/user-avatar-css.

Common mistakes include long lived diverging branches that cause huge conflict storms and pushing unfinished code to main without review. The branch concept exists to reduce fear not to create more drama so use branching as a tool not a fortress.

Tip

Prefer short lived branches and push often to remote to get feedback early. Use descriptive names and close branches after merge to keep the repository tidy and to avoid confusing future archaeologists.

title: A Git Branch Remove Example
description: Learn how to safely delete local and remote Git branches with clear commands and precautions to avoid losing work
heading: A Git Branch Remove Example tutorial
body:
This tutorial shows how to remove local and remote Git branches safely while avoiding accidental data loss.

  1. Inspect branches and current branch
  2. Delete a local branch safely
  3. Force delete an unmerged local branch
  4. Delete a remote branch
  5. Prune stale remote refs
  6. Verify removal

Inspect branches before making changes with commands such as git branch --all and git status. Confirm the current branch and switch away from the branch targeted for deletion using git switch main or git checkout main. Do not attempt deletion while the repository is on the branch scheduled for removal.

To delete a local branch that has been merged use git branch -d feature-branch. This command refuses removal when merge history is missing and acts as a safety net.

When the branch contains unmerged work and that work is no longer needed use force removal with git branch -D feature-branch. This command discards commits from the branch so double check that no important work will be lost before running the command. Yes that includes the experimental miracle that did not pan out.

To remove a branch from a remote repository push a delete request with git push origin --delete feature-branch. That asks the remote to drop the named branch. Some hosting providers also offer branch protection so remote removal may be blocked by policy.

Prune local references to removed remote branches with git fetch --prune or git remote prune origin. This cleans up stale refs and makes the branch listing truthful again.

Verify the cleanup with git branch -a and confirm absence of the target branch locally and remotely. A quick glance prevents awkward surprises during the next merge or deployment.

Recap of the workflow includes inspection before action safe local deletion force removal when intentional remote deletion and final pruning and verification. Follow the commands in order and treat forced removal as a point of no return for branch history.

Tip

Before force deleting tag the branch head as a safety bookmark using git tag backup/feature-branch feature-branch That provides a simple recovery point without cluttering branch lists

title: Git Branch Change Name Example
description: Learn how to rename a Git branch locally and on remote safely with clear commands and a short checklist for clean history.
heading: Git Branch Change Name Example Guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to rename a Git branch locally and on a remote repository using safe commands and simple checks.

  1. Verify current branch and working tree
  2. Rename local branch
  3. Push new branch and set upstream
  4. Delete old remote branch
  5. Inform collaborators and update CI

Verify current branch and working tree

Run git status and git branch to confirm the active branch and that there are no uncommitted changes. A clean working tree avoids surprises when rewriting branch pointers.

Rename local branch

Use git branch -m old-name new-name while on the branch or from another branch use git branch -m old-name new-name as well. This changes the local branch name without altering commit history.

Push new branch and set upstream

Push the renamed branch with git push origin new-name then set tracking with git push -u origin new-name if needed. Setting upstream makes future pushes and pulls behave normally.

Delete old remote branch

Remove the stale branch from remote with git push origin --delete old-name or use the hosting provider web UI for safety. Deleting remote history pointer cleans up branch lists and avoids confusion.

Inform collaborators and update CI

Tell team members to fetch and prune with git fetch --prune or run a manual delete and checkout of the new branch. Update continuous integration configuration and any open pull requests that reference the old name.

Renaming a branch is a small surgery on repository metadata while leaving commit history intact. Follow the checklist above to keep workflows smooth and avoid leftover references to the old name.

Tip

Prefer creating the new branch name and pushing before deleting the old remote branch. That prevents accidental loss of a branch when a push fails or when permissions block a new branch creation.

title: How to Change GitHub Branch Names Example
description: Learn a quick practical way to rename a Git branch locally and on GitHub while preserving history and updating the remote.
heading: How to Change GitHub Branch Names Example step by step guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to rename a Git branch locally and update the remote on GitHub while keeping history and avoiding broken pull requests.

  1. Rename the local branch
  2. Push the new branch to the remote
  3. Change the default branch on GitHub if needed
  4. Delete the old remote branch
  5. Update local tracking and cleanup

Rename the local branch

Switch to the branch that needs renaming or stay on another branch and run the rename command. Example command for a current branch is git branch -m new-branch-name. For renaming a different branch use git branch -m old-branch-name new-branch-name. That preserves commit history under the new name.

Push the new branch to the remote

Publish the new branch name to GitHub with a standard push. Use git push origin new-branch-name. Add upstream tracking with git push -u origin new-branch-name so future pulls and pushes are simpler.

Change the default branch on GitHub if needed

If the old branch served as the default branch update the repository settings on GitHub. Go to the repository settings and select the new default branch. That step avoids surprise failures for collaborators and automation that expects a specific default.

Delete the old remote branch

Remove the obsolete branch name from the remote using the delete command. Use git push origin --delete old-branch-name. Confirm that open pull requests were updated or recreated under the new branch name.

Update local tracking and cleanup

After remote deletion prune stale references and set tracking if required. Run git remote prune origin and verify local branches with git branch -vv. If a local branch still tracks the old remote point the branch at the new upstream with git branch -u origin/new-branch-name.

This covers the core steps required to rename a branch while keeping history intact and avoiding broken workflows. The process handles local rename push default branch update remote deletion and local cleanup so the repository stays tidy.

Tip

Before deleting the old remote branch leave a redirect or note in the old branch or in team chat. That saves a few minutes of detective work for colleagues and prevents accidental data loss.

title: How to Create a Git Branch from a Tag
description: Quick guide to create a Git branch from a tag Learn commands to branch locally and push the branch to remote
heading: How to Create a Git Branch from a Tag Step by Step
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a new Git branch from an existing tag and why that can be handy when hotfixes or experiments need a stable starting point.

  1. Find the tag name
  2. Create the branch from the tag locally
  3. Push the branch to the remote
  4. Avoid detached HEAD and confirm tracking

Find the tag name Run git tag to list local tags. If the central server has tags that are missing run git fetch --tags. Pick a tag name such as v1.2.3 that points to the desired commit.

Create the branch from the tag locally Use git checkout -b new-branch tagname to create a branch starting at the tagged commit and switch to that branch in one move. On newer Git versions the alternative command is git switch -c new-branch tagname. This ensures work starts from the exact snapshot that the tag marks.

Push the branch to the remote Share the new branch using git push origin new-branch. To set upstream in one step use git push -u origin new-branch. Collaborators can now fetch and collaborate on the branch just like any other branch.

Avoid detached HEAD and confirm tracking Checking out a tag without creating a branch places the repository in a detached HEAD state which makes new commits transient unless a branch is created. Creating a branch prevents that confusion and provides a proper tracking reference on the central server.

Recap This guide covered listing tags creating a branch from a tag and pushing the branch to the remote. Branching from a tag gives a stable starting point for patches hotfixes or experimental work based on a known release snapshot.

Tip

Use annotated tags for releases and include a clear branch prefix such as hotfix or patch. Verify the tag commit SHA before branching when working across forks or CI pipelines.

title: How to Create a Git branch from a Commit Example
description: Quick guide to create a Git branch from a specific commit with commands for finding the hash creating the branch checking out and pushing
heading: How to Create a Git branch from a Commit Example
body:
This tutorial teaches how to create a Git branch from a specific commit and why that trick is useful.

  1. Find the commit hash
  2. Create a new branch pointing at the commit
  3. Check out the new branch locally
  4. Push the new branch to remote if desired

Find the commit hash Use git log --oneline or a GUI to locate the desired commit hash. Copy the short hash such as 1a2b3c4 for the next step.

Create the branch Run git branch new-branch 1a2b3c4 to create a branch that points at that commit. Another option is to create and switch in one command with git checkout -b new-branch 1a2b3c4. This avoids extra steps when a fast switch is preferred.

Switch to the branch Use git checkout new-branch if the branch was created without switching. The working tree and index will reflect the chosen commit state and allow development from that historical snapshot.

Push to remote Publish the branch with git push -u origin new-branch so collaborators can see the branch and continue work. Use a descriptive branch name to avoid future confusion.

This guide showed how to create a branch from a commit using commands to find commit hash create branch checkout and push. That approach lets developers recover or branch from historical points without rewriting history.

Tip

When targeting a very old commit choose a branch name that notes reason or date. That makes future searches less painful than guessing which commit produced a mysterious fix.

title: How to Create a Git Branch From Master
description: Quick guide to create a Git branch from master with commands to switch update create and push a branch plus safe branching tips
heading: How to Create a Git Branch From Master Step by Step
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a new Git branch from master and push that branch to a remote repository so development can proceed safely.

  1. Switch to master
  2. Update master from remote
  3. Create a new branch from master
  4. Push the new branch to origin
  5. Start work and open a pull request

Switch to master Use a local command to check out the main line of development. Run git checkout master to move the working directory to the master branch. If the repository uses main replace master with main in commands.

Update master from remote Make sure the master branch reflects the latest remote changes. Fetch and merge using git pull origin master or run fetch then merge if a cleaner history is desired. This avoids creating a branch from stale code and later surprises.

Create a new branch from master Create a feature branch with a clear name by using git checkout -b feature-name. This command creates the branch and switches the working directory to that branch in one go. Choose a name that conveys purpose and scope.

Push the new branch to origin Share the new branch with collaborators by running git push -u origin feature-name. The -u flag sets the upstream so future pushes are simpler. Remote presence enables continuous integration and code review tools to kick in.
