Run the test suite or linters before pushing because broken master makes everyone sad. Make small follow up commits when required and include descriptive messages in commits.

Push merged master to remote

Once local master is clean and tests pass push to the shared remote so teammates can see the new code

git push origin master

Pull requests remain an excellent code review mechanism so consider merging using a pull request on hosting platform when reviews are desired. Branch names that describe purpose reduce confusion and make history readable.

This tutorial covered how to prepare master update from remote merge a feature branch handle conflicts and push the final merged master. Follow the commands and habits above for smoother merges and fewer surprise fires.

Tip

Rebase the feature branch onto the latest master before merging when history clarity matters. Run tests after rebasing and before pushing to avoid surprise failures on the shared branch.

title: What is a Git Merge Conflict?
description: Simple explanation of Git merge conflicts with clear steps to detect and resolve overlapping changes in a repository
heading: What is a Git Merge Conflict Explained
body:
A Git merge conflict is when two branches modify the same part of a file and Git cannot automatically choose which change to keep.

Conflicts happen during a merge or a rebase when overlapping edits exist. Git will pause the operation and mark conflicting files with conflict markers for a human to decide. The markers look like this

< < < < < < < HEAD your changes ======= their changes > > > > > > > branch-name

Detecting a conflict is boring but simple. Run git status to see files marked as unmerged. Open the file and look for the markers. The top block shows the current branch changes and the bottom block shows the incoming branch changes.

Resolving the conflict requires deciding which code belongs in the final file. Options include keeping one version taking parts from both or rewriting the section for clarity. After editing remove the markers then stage the file with git add and complete the operation with git commit or continue the rebase with git rebase --continue.

  1. Check status with git status to find conflicting files
  2. Edit the conflicting files and remove the conflict markers
  3. Stage resolved files with git add and finish the merge or rebase

Sometimes a manual merge is too tedious. Use a visual merge tool if preferences lean toward less keyboard punishment. If confident use git checkout --ours or git checkout --theirs for speedy resolution but beware of blindly discarding useful work.

Merge conflicts are not mysterious curses. Conflicts are signals that two developers made meaningful changes in the same area. Treat the conflict as a conversation and reconcile the best parts of both contributions.

Tip

Keep changes small and frequent. Smaller changes reduce overlap and make conflicts less dramatic. When conflicts occur run git diff to compare versions before deciding which lines to keep.

title: How to resolve Git merge conflicts
description: Step by step guide to find and fix Git merge conflicts with common commands and best practices for clean merges
heading: How to resolve Git merge conflicts fast and safely
body:
This tutorial teaches how to identify and resolve Git merge conflicts safely using common commands and the editor conflict markers.

  1. Update branches
  2. Attempt the merge
  3. Inspect conflicts
  4. Edit files to resolve conflicts
  5. Stage and commit
  6. Push and inform team

Update branches Start by fetching remote changes with git fetch then switch to the feature branch with git checkout feature and pull latest changes from origin using git pull. Keeping local branches current reduces surprise conflicts.

Attempt the merge Run the merge command such as git merge main to bring main branch changes into the feature branch. If Git reports a merge conflict Git pauses the merge and lists files that need attention.

Inspect conflicts Use git status to see files marked as both modified. Open each file and look for conflict markers that start with <<<<<<< and end with >>>>>>>. Those markers show differing chunks and the current branch section labeled HEAD.

Edit files to resolve conflicts Choose which code to keep or combine changes manually using the editor or a merge tool. Remove all conflict markers after resolving each section. Avoid leaving marker remnants in source files.

Stage and commit After resolving save changes and stage files with git add filename or git add . Then finish the merge with git commit -m Resolve merge conflicts or continue if a merge tool handled commits automatically.

Push and inform team Push the resolved branch with git push and notify teammates of any manual decisions that affect shared code. Communication prevents repeated rework.

Summary This guide covered how to update branches attempt a merge inspect conflict markers edit files to remove conflicts stage and commit the resolution and then push and communicate changes. Following these steps keeps history clean and avoids awkward surprises during reviews.

Tip

Use a graphical merge tool or the VS Code merge editor for visual context and fewer mistakes. If the merge is too messy abort with git merge --abort then rebase or prepare a smaller focused merge.

title: How to Cancel the Git Merge Process
description: Quick guide to abort or recover from a Git merge gone wrong Learn safe commands to cancel or finish a merge
heading: How to Cancel the Git Merge Process Safely
body:
This tutorial shows how to cancel a Git merge that is in progress and how to recover from a bad merge.

  1. Check current repository state
  2. Abort the merge before a commit
  3. Undo a merge that was already committed
  4. Finish the merge when keeping changes

Check current repository state Use status checks to see whether a merge is active and what files are conflicted. Run git status to spot conflict markers and git log --oneline -n 5 to view recent commits and confirm whether a merge commit exists.

Abort the merge before a commit If a merge started and conflicts appeared but there is no merge commit yet use git merge --abort to return to the pre merge state. Older Git versions accept git reset --merge for the same goal. This will discard changes introduced by the merge in the working tree so be careful with any uncommitted work.

Undo a merge that was already committed When a merge commit already landed use a hard reset to go back to the previous commit. A common command is git reset --hard ORIG_HEAD where ORIG_HEAD points to the state before the merge. Another option is git reset --hard HEAD~1 to drop the last commit. These commands erase local changes and staged files so back up any needed work first.

Finish the merge when keeping changes If the goal is to resolve conflicts and keep merged content then inspect each conflicted file fix conflict markers then stage resolved files with git add and complete the process with git commit. Use git status often to confirm progress.

Recap of the lesson The key actions are check status then choose abort or reset when rollback is desired or resolve and commit when merge content should be kept. Use caution to avoid accidental loss of local work.

Tip

Before attempting risky merges create a snapshot branch or stash changes. Example commands git branch wip backup or git stash push -m "wip" to preserve work and provide an easy recovery path.

title: Resolve GitHub Merge Conflicts
description: Step by step guide to identify and fix GitHub merge conflicts using command line and GitHub tools for clean merges and fewer headaches
heading: Resolve GitHub Merge Conflicts Fast and Clean
body:
This tutorial shows how to identify and resolve merge conflicts on GitHub using the command line and GitHub interface for a clean history.

  1. Sync branches
  2. Attempt the merge locally
  3. Open and fix conflict markers
  4. Stage and commit the resolution
  5. Push and update the pull request

Step 1 Sync branches Make sure the feature branch and the main branch are up to date. Run git fetch origin then git checkout feature and git pull origin feature. Then switch to the target branch and pull recent changes from origin. This avoids surprises from stale history.

Step 2 Attempt the merge locally From the feature branch run git merge main or run git rebase main if that is the workflow. Git will stop and list conflicted files when a true disagreement exists.

Step 3 Open and fix conflict markers Open each conflicted file in an editor. Look for markers like < < < < < < < and > > > > > > > and decide which code to keep. Combine changes with care and remove the markers after resolving the logic.

Step 4 Stage and commit the resolution After editing run git add path/to/file for every resolved file. Then run git commit to record the resolution. If using rebase run git rebase --continue instead of a plain commit.

Step 5 Push and update the pull request Push the branch back to origin with git push. If the branch was rebased use a force push with care. Refresh the pull request on GitHub and verify that the conflict status cleared and tests pass.

This short guide walked through syncing branches attempting the merge handling conflict markers staging commits and pushing changes so the pull request returns to a clean state. A few minutes of careful edits now saves a frantic late night merge later.

Tip

When unsure make a temporary branch before resolving conflicts. That gives a safe place to try different resolutions and keeps the original branch clean in case a rollback is needed.

title: How to Abort Git Merge Conflicts
description: Quick guide to abort a messy Git merge and restore a clean working tree fast and safely
heading: How to Abort Git Merge Conflicts Safely and Fast
body:
This guide shows how to abort a Git merge that produced conflicts and return the repository to a clean state.

  1. Check merge status
  2. Abort the merge
  3. Preserve or stash local changes
  4. Reset if the index or working tree is confused
  5. Prepare branches and retry the merge

Check merge status Use git status to see which files are conflicted and which files are staged. The status output tells which branch is merging and lists conflicted paths in plain English. This saves guesswork and dramatic scrolling.

Abort the merge If the merge is unwanted or desperate then run git merge --abort. This command attempts to roll back to the state before the merge started and restores the index and the working tree. The abort command works when the merge recorded a merge head.

Preserve or stash local changes If local edits need saving use git stash push -m "WIP before abort" or stage important files with git add then stash. Stashing prevents data loss and keeps the working tree clean for the abort command.

Reset if the index or working tree is confused When git merge --abort fails consider git reset --hard HEAD to force the working tree back to the last commit. Only use the hard reset when sure about discarding unstashed edits.

Prepare branches and retry the merge Update both branches with git fetch and consider rebasing feature work with git rebase origin/main before merging. Cleaner history reduces future conflict carnage.

Recap The steps covered how to inspect a merge, run the abort command, stash local work, and use reset when necessary so recovery is predictable and safe.

Tip

Keep frequent small commits and use git stash for ephemeral work. Smaller changes mean fewer conflicts and less drama when abortion becomes necessary.

title: How to Merge Git Commits
description: Quick guide to merging Git commits using interactive rebase squash amend and safe force push for a tidy commit history
heading: How to Merge Git Commits Step by Step
body:
This tutorial shows how to combine Git commits for a cleaner history using interactive rebase squash and careful pushing.

  1. Inspect the commit history
  2. Create a backup branch
  3. Run an interactive rebase to squash or fixup commits
  4. Amend messages and resolve conflicts
  5. Push changes safely to the remote

Use git log --oneline to see recent commits and decide which commits belong together. Think of the branch history as a public record that deserves neat handwriting.

Create a snapshot with git branch backup or git checkout -b backup before rewriting history. This step prevents a small mistake from turning into a dramatic git therapy session.

Start an interactive rebase with a range such as git rebase -i HEAD~3. In the editor change pick lines to squash or fixup for the commits that should merge into one. Squash combines messages followed by an opportunity to edit while fixup skips message edits and silently merges.

If conflicts appear run git status to see affected files then stage fixes with git add and continue using git rebase --continue. To adjust the final commit message use git commit --amend after the rebase completes.

After the branch history looks tidy push with care. Use git push --force-with-lease when rewriting a branch that others might have checked out. This option reduces the chance of accidentally overwriting teammate work.

Recap The process covers inspecting history creating a backup performing an interactive rebase to squash or fixup commits resolving conflicts amending the final message and pushing safely. The goal is a concise and readable commit history that does not embarrass future maintainers.

Tip

Prefer small frequent commits during development then squash before merging to main. Communicate rewrites to teammates and use --force-with-lease not plain force to avoid surprise lost work.

title: How to Git merge one branch into another
description: Step by step guide to merging one Git branch into another safely with commands conflict tips and best practices for clean history
heading: How to Git merge one branch into another safely
body:
This tutorial shows how to merge one Git branch into another using command line steps and conflict handling.

  1. Prepare the repository
  2. Switch to the target branch
  3. Merge the source branch
  4. Resolve conflicts
  5. Push the merged branch

Prepare the repository by fetching latest changes from remote. Run git fetch origin and verify the working tree with git status or inspect history with git log --oneline --graph --decorate. This reduces surprises during a merge.

Switch to the branch that should receive changes. Use git checkout target-branch or the modern git switch target-branch. Confirm a clean working directory before proceeding.

Merge the source branch into the current branch with git merge source-branch. To preserve a non linear history prefer git merge --no-ff source-branch. For cases where a simple fast forward is fine run the basic merge.

If conflicts appear Git will mark files with conflict markers. Open conflicting files and resolve differences manually. After fixing run git add on updated files and complete the merge with git commit or git merge --continue if using an interactive flow. Run tests and a quick build to verify the merge result.

Share the merged branch with remote using git push origin target-branch. If the remote rejects the push due to history changes prefer creating a pull request or coordinate with teammates before forcing any history rewrite.

This covers the core workflow needed to merge one branch into another with minimal drama. Follow the prepare switch merge resolve push pattern and adopt pull requests and code review for safer collaboration.

Tip

Use git log --graph --oneline --decorate to inspect branch topology before merging and consider git merge --no-ff when wanting a clear merge commit for future debugging.

title: How Git no-ff Merges Work
description: Learn how Git no-ff merges preserve history create merge commits and affect rebasing and workflow in a compact technical guide
heading: How Git no-ff Merges Work Explained
body:
A Git no-ff merge is a merge operation that always creates a merge commit even when a fast forward would be possible.

Normally when the main branch has no new commits since branch divergence Git advances the main pointer to the feature tip for a fast forward and no merge commit appears. The no-ff option forces a merge commit that records the feature branch as a single logical unit.

Run git merge --no-ff feature to force a merge commit. This leaves a clear join point in the commit graph and documents the work as a group.

Benefits include clearer history for review and easier reversion of a whole feature. Teams using release branches or Git Flow often prefer this because the merge commit names the feature and shows the merge time. Downsides include extra commits that may clutter history for small trivial changes.

How this plays with rebase. If the feature branch is rebased onto the latest main then a normal merge may fast forward and no merge commit will be created. Using --no-ff after a rebase still forces a merge commit so the feature history remains grouped.

When to choose a no ff merge. Prefer a no ff merge for long lived feature branches or any work that should be grouped for auditing or rollback. Prefer a fast forward for tiny typo fixes or trivial refactors when a linear history is desired and the commit narrative is already obvious.

Commands that help. Use git log --graph --oneline --decorate to inspect the graph. Use git merge --no-ff --no-commit feature to stage the merge and review before finalizing. Remember that merge messages can be edited to explain the rationale.

Tip

For consistent history pick a team policy and enforce with pull request checks. If merge commits are required use a branch naming convention and a short merge message template to keep the graph useful rather than noisy.

title: What is a Fast Forward Merge in Git?
description: Quick guide to fast forward merges in Git Learn how Git moves branch tips when no divergent commits exist and when to avoid linear history
heading: What is a Fast Forward Merge in Git?
body:
A fast forward merge in Git moves the target branch tip forward to match the feature branch when no divergent commits exist.

When a feature branch is strictly ahead of the target branch without any intervening commits Git advances the target branch pointer to the feature branch tip. That produces a linear history and no merge commit is created.

Run the following commands to perform a normal fast forward merge Make sure the target branch has no new commits since the feature branch split

git checkout main then git merge feature

To force a merge commit and preserve a record of the branch use git merge --no-ff feature. That tells Git to create a merge commit even when a fast forward would be possible.

Pros of a fast forward merge include a tidy linear history and simpler log output. Cons include loss of explicit grouping for the feature branch which can make future auditing or revert work less pleasant. If branch context matters prefer a merge commit or use a pull request workflow that enforces merge commits.

Common workflow guidance Use fast forward merges for trivial or single commit updates. Use non fast forward merges when feature branches represent a unit of work that should remain visible in history. Choose a team convention and stick to that convention so history does not become a surprise maze.

This companion guide explained what a fast forward merge does how to run one and when to prefer or avoid this merge style.

Tip

Require a merge commit for pull requests when branch level history matters Use git merge --no-ff so the feature branch remains visible even after the merge. That keeps traceability neat and makes future reverts less dramatic.

title: Remove and Revert Uncommitted Git Changes & Files
description: Quick guide to discard uncommitted Git changes and remove untracked files safely using git restore git reset and git clean
heading: Remove and Revert Uncommitted Git Changes and Files for Git users
body:
This tutorial shows how to discard uncommitted changes and remove untracked files in Git using safe commands and clear steps.

  1. Revert tracked file changes use git restore < file> or older git checkout -- < file>
  2. Unstage changes use git restore --staged < file> or git reset HEAD < file>
  3. Remove untracked files use git clean -f with caution
  4. Remove untracked directories use git clean -fd
  5. Reset working tree to last commit use git reset --hard HEAD

Revert tracked file changes when local edits are unwanted. The git restore < file> command discards working tree modifications for a tracked path. For older Git versions use the git checkout -- < file> form. This action loses local edits unless a stash or commit exists.

Unstage changes when staging area contains files that should stay uncommitted. Use git restore --staged < file> or git reset HEAD < file> to move changes back to the working tree. The working tree keeps modifications so the code can be edited further.

Remove untracked files when junk files clutter the repository. Run git clean -f after a dry run with git clean -n to preview deletions. A dry run prevents accidental loss of valuable files.

Remove untracked directories when generated folders need clearing. Use git clean -fd with care. Consider adding safe paths to .gitignore to avoid repeated cleanup commands.

Reset working tree to last commit when a full rollback is required. The command git reset --hard HEAD resets index and working tree to match the last commit. This command is powerful and destructive so confirm that no important changes will be lost before executing.

This tutorial covered commands to discard tracked file edits to unstage changes to remove untracked files and to reset the working tree to the last commit. Use dry runs and stashes for safety when unsure and adopt a cautious habit before running destructive commands.

Tip

Run git status before any destructive command and use git stash to save a snapshot if there is any doubt. Dry run git clean -n to preview deletions and avoid surprises.

title: Discard local changes and untracked files in Git repo
description: Quick guide to discard local changes and remove untracked files in a Git repo using git reset git clean and safe previews.
heading: Discard local changes and untracked files in Git repo
body:
This tutorial shows how to discard all local changes and remove untracked files in a Git repository safely and quickly.

  1. Inspect repository state
  2. Discard tracked changes
  3. Remove untracked files
  4. Optionally remove ignored files
  5. Verify a clean working tree

Inspect repository state. Run git status to see modified tracked files and a list of untracked files. This step avoids the classic facepalm moment that follows losing work that mattered.

Discard tracked changes. Use git reset --hard HEAD to reset the index and the working tree to the last commit. This command forces the removal of all modifications to tracked files in the working tree.

Remove untracked files. Preview the cleanup with git clean -n to show files that would be deleted. When satisfied run git clean -fd to delete untracked files and directories from the working tree.

Optionally remove ignored files. When the repository contains generated files that need nuking use git clean -fdx after a careful preview with git clean -nx. This removes ignored files as well so double check before running the destructive command.

Verify a clean working tree. Run git status one more time. The output should report a clean working tree and no untracked files. If the output does not match expectations consult stashes or backups before trying more drastic measures.

Summary of the process. Inspect the repository first then reset tracked changes next remove untracked files and finally verify the working tree is clean. These steps provide a fast route to a known state without guessing.

Tip

When unsure stash changes with git stash push -m "wip" before running destructive commands. The stash acts as a safety net and prevents future teeth gnashing.

title: Introduction to Lambda Expressions in Java
description: Learn Java lambda expressions with clear syntax examples and best practices for functional interfaces and streams
heading: Introduction to Lambda Expressions in Java Guide
body:
This tutorial covers Java lambda expressions with practical examples and best practices for functional interfaces and streams.

  1. Understand functional interfaces
  2. Learn lambda syntax
  3. Apply lambdas with collections and streams
  4. Handle type inference and common errors
  5. Practice with short examples

1 Functional interfaces Functional interfaces define a single abstract method that accepts parameters and returns a result. Annotate with @FunctionalInterface for clarity. Example interface form looks like interface Adder { int add(int a, int b) }

2 Lambda syntax A basic lambda expression looks like (a, b) -> a + b Single parameter form looks like x -> x * x Types can be declared explicitly when needed using (int a, int b) -> a + b

3 Apply lambdas with collections and streams Common usage is in stream pipelines for filtering mapping and terminal actions. Example usage looks like list.stream().filter(x -> x % 2 == 0).map(x -> x * 2).forEach(x -> System.out.println(x)) This pattern reduces boilerplate that anonymous classes would bring

4 Type inference and common errors Java performs target typing to infer parameter types. Overloaded methods and complex generics can confuse type inference. When compilation fails provide explicit parameter types or add a cast for the lambda expression

5 Practice examples Compare strings by length using (s1, s2) -> s1.length() - s2.length() Create a runnable using () -> System.out.println("Hello") Try converting common anonymous classes to lambdas for faster feedback during learning

This guide covered how to read and write lambda expressions how functional interfaces form a target type and how to use lambdas with streams and collections for cleaner code and less ceremony

Tip

Prefer short clear lambda bodies. When a lambda grows beyond a single expression extract a named method for readability and easier debugging

title: Tomcat vs Apache What's the difference?
description: Compare Apache HTTP Server and Apache Tomcat roles performance and when to use each for Java web applications
heading: Tomcat vs Apache What's the difference
body:
The key difference between Apache HTTP Server and Apache Tomcat is that Apache HTTP Server focuses on serving static content and proxying while Apache Tomcat implements the Java servlet and JSP specifications to run Java web applications.

Apache HTTP Server plays the role of a general purpose web server capable of delivering HTML CSS and images with many modules for TLS compression and URL rewriting. Apache Tomcat acts as a servlet container that loads web applications packaged as WAR files and executes Java servlets and JSP pages.

Typical use cases split cleanly. Use Apache HTTP Server when the workload is mostly static assets or when a hardened frontend is needed for TLS termination and caching. Use Apache Tomcat when Java code must run on the server side and when servlet APIs are required.

An architecture pattern that grown up professionals keep using places Apache HTTP Server in front as a reverse proxy while Tomcat sits behind to handle dynamic Java work. That setup leverages strengths from both projects and gives a neat separation of concerns.

Performance wise expect Apache HTTP Server to be more efficient at serving large numbers of small static requests while Apache Tomcat requires JVM tuning and proper thread pool configuration for high concurrency. Monitoring thread usage and garbage collection metrics matters far more for Tomcat than for a plain web server.

Configuration approaches differ so do not ask the two projects to be twins. Apache HTTP Server configuration lives in text files that load modules. Apache Tomcat configuration uses XML based server and web descriptors plus application specific deployment descriptors.

Deciding factor often comes down to application language and deployment complexity. If the web application uses Java servlets or JSP then choose Tomcat either alone or behind a proxy. If the need is hosting static content or proxying many backend services then Apache HTTP Server will shine.

Tip

When using both have Apache HTTP Server handle TLS caching and static files and proxy dynamic requests to Tomcat. Tune connector threads on Tomcat and use keep alive on the frontend to avoid thread exhaustion and surprise outages.

title: Jenkins Tomcat WAR Deployment
description: Step by step guide to configure Jenkins to build a WAR and deploy to Tomcat using pipeline and common plugins
heading: Jenkins Tomcat WAR Deployment Guide
body:
This tutorial walks through using Jenkins to build a WAR file and deploy that artifact to an Apache Tomcat server using a pipeline and common plugins

  1. Prepare Tomcat and Jenkins
  2. Create a Jenkins job or pipeline
  3. Build the WAR using Maven or Gradle
  4. Archive and deploy the WAR to Tomcat
  5. Verify deployment and enable rollback

Prepare Tomcat and Jenkins by ensuring Tomcat runs on a reachable host and that the Tomcat manager credentials are available in Jenkins credentials store. Install the Deploy to Container plugin when a GUI approach is preferred or prepare a script for a remote copy when automation feels more honest.

Create a Jenkins job or pipeline that checks out source from version control. For a pipeline use a simple Jenkinsfile that runs build steps and exposes the WAR as a pipeline artifact. For freestyle jobs configure build steps and post build actions to archive the artifact.

Build the WAR using a build tool. For Maven run the package goal using a build agent that has Java and Maven installed. For Gradle run the build task and confirm the WAR appears in the expected target or build libs folder.

Archive and deploy the WAR by using the archive artifacts step followed by either the Deploy to Container post build action or a script that uses curl and the Tomcat manager API to upload the WAR. Use credentials stored in Jenkins credentials and avoid hard coded passwords unless living dangerously is a goal.

Verify deployment by requesting the application context in a browser or using a simple curl health check. To enable rollback keep previous WAR versions in a stable repository or use a scripted pipeline step to copy the prior WAR back to the Tomcat webapps folder when a deployment fails.

This guide covered preparing servers and credentials creating a Jenkins job building a WAR archiving the artifact deploying to Tomcat and verifying and handling rollback. Follow these steps and expect fewer surprises than when guessing where a missing dependency hid itself

Tip

Use Jenkins pipeline declarative stages and store Tomcat credentials in the credentials store. Add a quick health check stage that fails the pipeline when the application does not respond to avoid promoting broken deployments

title: How to Resolve Git Stash Pop Conflicts
description: Fix Git stash pop conflicts step by step and recover changes safely with merge tools stash branches and recovery commands
heading: How to Resolve Git Stash Pop Conflicts and Recover Changes
body:
This guide shows how to resolve Git stash pop conflicts and restore a clean working tree while preserving stashed changes.

  1. Run stash pop and inspect status
  2. Open and resolve conflicted files
  3. Stage resolved files
  4. Commit or keep stash as needed
  5. Use a stash branch to avoid pain
  6. Recover lost work from reflog or fsck

Step 1 Run git stash pop to apply the top stash. If a conflict happens run git status to see which files need attention.

Step 2 Open each conflicted file and remove merge markers while choosing the correct lines from local work or incoming stash. Use git mergetool if a visual helper is preferred.

Step 3 After editing stage resolved files with git add < file> and confirm a clean index with git status.

Step 4 Finish by creating a commit with git commit to record the resolution. If preserving the stash is desired use git stash apply to test without removing the stash and drop the stash later with git stash drop.

Step 5 To avoid manual merging create a branch from the stash with git stash branch fix-stash then merge or rebase as required. That keeps the main branch safe while resolving conflicts.

Step 6 If stash pop failed and some changes seem missing inspect git reflog and run git fsck --lost-found to locate dangling commits or blobs. Recovery chances are often better than expected.

This tutorial covered applying a stash and walking through conflict resolution using status checks merge tools staging commits stash apply and stash branch strategies. Follow the steps to preserve changes and keep the repository tidy while dealing with dramatic Git behavior.

Tip

Use git stash push -m "describe change" to label stashes for later. Use git stash apply to test without removing stash and create a branch from stash when unsure. That workflow keeps work safe and reduces surprise drama.

title: Deploy WARs to Tomcat from Eclipse
description: Quick guide to build export and deploy WAR files from Eclipse to Tomcat with practical steps for setup deployment and testing
heading: Deploy WARs to Tomcat from Eclipse guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to build export and deploy a WAR from Eclipse to a Tomcat server with clear practical steps for developers who prefer less mystery and more results.

  1. Prepare Tomcat and Eclipse
  2. Create or export the WAR file
  3. Configure Tomcat inside Eclipse
  4. Deploy the WAR to the server
  5. Start server and test the webapp

Prepare Tomcat and Eclipse

Download a matching Tomcat binary and point Eclipse at a JDK rather than a JRE. Add the Tomcat installation to the Servers view so the IDE knows where the runtime lives. Ensure the Eclipse Web Tools Platform is available for the smoothest experience.

Create or export the WAR file

For a Dynamic Web Project use the Export Web Archive option. For a Maven project run the package goal to produce target slash projectname dot war. Confirm the WAR contains the correct web xml or servlet annotations before moving on.

Configure Tomcat inside Eclipse

Open the Servers view and create a new Server choosing the correct Tomcat version. Point the runtime to the Tomcat installation directory and associate the project with the server using Add and Remove projects.

Deploy the WAR to the server

Drag the web project onto the Tomcat server in the Servers view or use the Add and Remove dialog. Use Publish to push the WAR into the server runtime. If faster feedback is wanted enable automatic publishing or deploy an exploded webapp folder.

Start server and test the webapp

Start the Tomcat server from the Servers view and open a browser to localhost on port 8080 using the webapp context path to verify pages and servlets respond as expected. Check logs in the Console and in logs for stack traces should errors appear.

This guide covered how to prepare environment build a WAR configure Tomcat inside Eclipse deploy the web archive and run basic verification steps. Following these steps removes most of the guesswork and keeps deployments predictable while getting more time back for actual coding.

Tip

For rapid development use an exploded webapp and enable automatic publishing in Eclipse to avoid repeated WAR exports. Clean the Tomcat work directory when classloading oddities appear.

title: Developer vs DevOps Engineer What's the difference?
description: Compact guide comparing developer and DevOps engineer roles responsibilities tools skills and career paths for engineers and managers.
heading: Developer vs DevOps Engineer What's the difference?
body:
The key difference between a developer and a DevOps engineer is focus of responsibility and scope of work.

The developer builds application features writes code and solves product problems. The DevOps engineer builds and maintains delivery pipelines infrastructure and operational practices that keep applications running smoothly.

  1. Primary focus

    Developers focus on application logic user experience and code quality. DevOps engineers focus on deployment automation reliability monitoring and scalability.

  2. Typical tools

    Developers often use language specific frameworks local testing tools and debuggers. DevOps engineers use CI CD systems container tools orchestration platforms cloud services and observability stacks.

  3. Goals

    Developers aim for feature delivery and maintainable code. DevOps engineers aim for fast safe releases predictable environments and reduced toil.

  4. Skills

    Developers need strong programming skills testing practice and design thinking. DevOps engineers need scripting system administration networking automation and an understanding of production behavior.

  5. Workflow and collaboration

    Developers and DevOps engineers must collaborate closely. Developers can benefit from writing code with deployability in mind while DevOps engineers gain from understanding application architecture. Shared responsibility avoids blame and reduces late night pager duty surprises.

Career paths often overlap. A developer may move toward platform focused roles or take on operational ownership. A DevOps engineer may grow into platform engineering site reliability or cloud architecture roles. Hiring managers want candidates who can bridge gaps between feature creation and delivery pipelines.

There is no mystical boundary. Teams that align goals metrics and incentives get faster delivery and fewer outages. If enthusiasm for automation and a dash of patience for monitoring logs exists then cross training pays off handsomely.

Tip

Learn basic Linux and a CI CD tool first. Automate repetitive tasks and add monitoring to every service. That approach shows value to both product teams and operations teams.

title: Tomcat vs JBoss Which Application Server to Choose?
description: Compare Tomcat and JBoss for Java deployment Learn differences in features performance architecture and when to choose each server
heading: Tomcat vs JBoss Which Application Server to Choose
body:
The key difference between Tomcat and JBoss is scope and features

Tomcat serves as a lightweight servlet container focused on HTTP and servlet processing. Tomcat works great for web apps that rely on servlets JSP and Spring Boot style deployments. JBoss also known as WildFly is a full fledged Java application server that includes enterprise services like EJB JMS transactions and clustering.

Think of Tomcat as a streamlined sports car that gets around fast and cheap with minimal baggage. Consider JBoss as a full size SUV loaded with creature comforts and enterprise wiring that teams sometimes secretly enjoy configuring.

Key trade offs

  1. Feature set
  2. Footprint and memory
  3. Operational complexity
  4. Use case fit

Feature set explained

Tomcat offers servlet container features and optional add ons for session management and security. JBoss bundles full enterprise APIs plus management console and built in clustering.

Footprint and memory explained

Tomcat usually consumes far less memory and boots faster. JBoss demands more RAM and longer startup time thanks to many services enabled by default.

Operational complexity explained

Tomcat requires fewer moving parts so deployment is simpler for basic web apps. JBoss brings powerful features that require more configuration and operational knowledge when using advanced capabilities.

Use case fit explained

Choose Tomcat for microservices simple web front ends and dense containerized deployments that prioritize resource efficiency. Choose JBoss for legacy Java EE apps complex transactional systems and when built in enterprise services reduce development work.

Performance note

Raw servlet performance often favors Tomcat for simple workloads while JBoss shines when enterprise features are required under load. Benchmark with representative workloads before choosing.

Tip

If unsure start with Tomcat for speed and simplicity then move to JBoss WildFly only when specific enterprise APIs or integrated services are required

title: How to use the JDK's javap command by example
description: Practical guide to using the JDK javap command with examples to inspect class files methods and bytecode for debugging and learning
heading: How to use the JDK's javap command by example for class and bytecode inspection
body:
A compact tutorial showing how to use the JDK javap command to inspect class files methods and bytecode.

  1. Compile Java source
  2. Run javap with basic flags
  3. Read disassembled bytecode
  4. Use verbose and private details for deep inspection

Step 1 compile source using the standard compiler example command javac MyClass.java This produces MyClass.class which is the target for analysis

Step 2 run basic listings with commands such as javap MyClass to see public signatures and javap -p MyClass to include private members Use javap -c MyClass to show disassembled bytecode

Step 3 inspect bytecode to understand method behavior Look for opcodes like aload_0 invokespecial and return Method descriptors describe parameter and return types which helps map source level code to generated instructions

Step 4 enable deep inspection with javap -v MyClass This reveals the constant pool and detailed attributes and can be noisy Use javap -l -c MyClass to include line number tables which help match bytecode to source lines

For classes inside jars provide a classpath argument such as javap -classpath lib.jar com.example.MyClass The command works well for quick debugging verifying compile outputs and learning how the compiler transforms source

The tutorial covered compiling a class running javap with common flags reading opcode output and using verbose details to dig deeper The goal is to make class file inspection part of a regular debugging and learning workflow without magic

Tip

When confused use a decompiler alongside javap The decompiler gives readable source and javap shows exact bytecode and constant pool This combo makes surprising compiler behavior less mysterious

title: How to use JarSigner to Sign Java JAR files digitally
description: Learn how to sign Java JARs with JarSigner and keytool for code integrity trust with concise commands to create keystore sign and verify
heading: How to use JarSigner to Sign Java JAR files digitally
body:
This tutorial shows how to sign a Java JAR file using keytool and jarsigner to provide integrity and trust.

  1. Create a keystore and keypair
  2. Sign the JAR with jarsigner
  3. Verify the signed JAR
  4. Optional timestamping and distribution

Create a keystore and keypair

Generate a signing key using keytool so the keystore holds a private key and public certificate. Example command

keytool -genkeypair -alias mykey -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 -keystore mykeystore.jks -storepass changeit -keypass changeit -dname "CN=Dev"

Sign the JAR

Apply a digital signature to the JAR using jarsigner. The signature binds the code to the signer and helps users and systems trust the binary.

jarsigner -keystore mykeystore.jks -storepass changeit -keypass changeit myapp.jar mykey

Verify the signed JAR

Always verify after signing to confirm the signature is valid and certificates chain correctly. Use verbose mode for details.

jarsigner -verify -verbose -certs myapp.jar

Optional timestamping and distribution

Add a timestamp using the -tsa option with a timestamp server URL so the signature stays valid after key expiry. Use separate signing keys for development and release builds to keep things tidy.

Signing a JAR is not magic just a few commands that prove provenance and protect integrity. Keep passwords and private keys secure and automate signing in build pipelines to avoid human error.

Tip

Store signing keys in a secure location such as a hardware token or CI secret store. Test verification on a clean machine to catch missing cert chain issues before distribution.

title: scrumbut
description: Quick guide to scrumbut signs causes and fixes for teams claiming to follow Scrum while bending rules and skipping ceremonies
heading: scrumbut explained how to fix Scrum problems
body:
Scrumbut is the practice of claiming to follow Scrum while omitting or changing core Scrum rules to suit convenience.

Common warning signs include phrases such as we do Scrum but no retros we do Scrum but no timebox and we do Scrum but no product owner. Those phrases are the bureaucratic equivalent of rearranging deck chairs and calling that Agile.

Consequences are lower predictability poor feedback loops and diluted team accountability. Promises to stakeholders become vague and long term planning suffers. Teams lose the benefits that motivated adoption of Scrum in the first place.

Practical steps to fix scrumbut follow this short plan

  1. Admit current practice
  2. Choose one core ceremony to restore
  3. Give authority to the product owner role
  4. Enforce timeboxes
  5. Inspect adapt regularly

Admit current practice means a frank team conversation where reality gets named without blame. That clears confusion and opens the door to change.

Choosing one ceremony to restore keeps change manageable. Start with the most impactful meeting for the team and commit to trying for a sprint.

Giving authority to the product owner reduces scope creep and aligns priorities. A named decision maker beats a committee every time.

Enforcing timeboxes protects focus and forces trade offs. Short deadlines reveal blockers faster than gentle requests.

Inspect and adapt regularly through retrospectives that actually produce action items. Measure small improvements and celebrate wins that came from intentional change.

Tip

Run a single sprint with one restored practice and a clear metric. If metrics improve keep going. If no change then try a different practice. Small experiments beat grand declarations.

title: Top 5 Reasons Why You'll Love the Jakarta Servlet 6.0 API Re
description: A compact guide to why developers should care about Jakarta Servlet 6.0 API improvements for modern Java web apps and cloud deployments
heading: Top 5 Reasons Why You'll Love the Jakarta Servlet 6.0 API Release
body:
Jakarta Servlet 6.0 modernizes server side Java with cleaner APIs and tighter alignment to modern Jakarta EE practices.

  1. API cleanup and clearer names Less ceremony and more predictable APIs make maintenance less painful.
  2. Improved asynchronous processing Non blocking request handling scales better under load and works with reactive frameworks.
  3. Enhanced HTTP handling More flexible request and response features reduce manual parsing and fragile glue code.
  4. Cloud friendly performance Faster startup and smaller runtime footprint help with container scaling and cold starts.
  5. Developer ergonomics Better error messages and helpful convenience methods speed debugging and routine tasks.

The API cleanup focuses on removing legacy surprises and promoting a consistent package design that feels modern rather than archaeological.

Asynchronous enhancements give developers more control over threads and callbacks which improves throughput for high concurrency scenarios and keeps thread pools happier.

HTTP handling improvements reduce common boilerplate for header parsing multipart processing and response streaming so less code means fewer bugs.

Performance tweaks and a smaller memory profile mean cloud deployments use fewer resources which translates to lower cost and faster scaling.

Developer friendly improvements include clearer exceptions and handy helpers that remove tedious guard code and let teams move from debugging to building faster.

If the goal is a smoother upgrade path and fewer surprises during deployment then this release delivers practical wins rather than flashy changes.

Tip

When upgrading start with tests around filters and session behavior and run a quick performance smoke test. Focus on compatibility gates first then pursue optimizations. A staged rollout makes the whole process far less dramatic.

title: s3 bucket temp
description: Quick guide to create temporary S3 access using presigned URLs and short lived credentials for secure file sharing and testing
heading: s3 bucket temp quick guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to create temporary access to an S3 bucket using presigned URLs and temporary credentials for secure short lived file sharing.

  1. Prepare bucket and apply minimal policy
  2. Create a presigned URL for single file upload or download
  3. Use STS to generate temporary credentials for broader short lived access
  4. Test access with a real file transfer
  5. Revoke or let credentials expire then clean up

Step 1 set a bucket policy that allows only the required actions and only from known principals. Do not leave public read or write enabled unless the project aims for a data breach demo. Minimal permissions reduce blast radius.

Step 2 generate a presigned URL for one time upload or download. Presigned URLs grant a short lived signed link that clients can use without AWS credentials. Example pseudo command in case a quick copy helps

aws s3 presign bucket key --expires-in 3600

Step 3 for cases needing more than one object or programmatic access generate temporary credentials via STS and role assumption. This allows scoped policies and short lifetimes so long lived keys do not wander off.

Step 4 test access by using a curl or SDK call with the presigned URL or by configuring an AWS SDK with the temporary credentials and performing the desired operation. Testing prevents surprises when production runs.

Step 5 remove any test objects and revoke roles if manual revocation is supported. Otherwise wait for automatic expiration and then rotate any long lived keys used during testing. Cleaning up avoids noisy logs and accidental leaks.

Recap This guide covered preparing a secure bucket policy generating presigned URLs creating temporary credentials testing real file transfers and cleaning up to avoid exposure. The process lets developers share files without handing over permanent keys and keeps security teams mildly amused rather than furious.

Tip

Prefer short lifetimes for presigned URLs and roles. Shorter lifetimes mean less risk and fewer late night incident calls from monitoring teams.

title: install nginx ubuntu
description: Quick guide to install Nginx on Ubuntu with commands to start the web server and confirm a working default page
heading: Install Nginx on Ubuntu Step by Step
body:
This tutorial shows how to install Nginx on Ubuntu start the service adjust firewall rules and verify a default web page

  1. Update package index
  2. Install Nginx package
  3. Start and enable the Nginx service
  4. Allow HTTP traffic through the firewall
  5. Verify the web server is serving the default page

Update package index

Refresh the Ubuntu package index so the latest Nginx version is available.

sudo apt update

Install Nginx package

Install the web server using the package manager. This will pull in required dependencies.

sudo apt install nginx -y

Start and enable the Nginx service

Start service right away and enable automatic start on boot so the server survives a reboot.

sudo systemctl start nginx

sudo systemctl enable nginx

Allow HTTP traffic through the firewall

If the Ubuntu system uses UFW open the standard HTTP profile so visitors can reach the server.

sudo ufw allow "Nginx HTTP"

Verify the web server is serving the default page

Use a browser or a simple command line request to confirm the default Nginx page loads. Replace localhost with server IP when testing remotely.

curl -I http //localhost

This should return a 200 OK header and the classic Nginx welcome page will be available at the server root. If the header shows a different status check the service status and the Nginx configuration folder for errors.

Troubleshooting quick checks include viewing the service status

sudo systemctl status nginx

and scanning error logs in the Nginx log directory for clues. Adjusting firewall rules or correcting a malformed config file often resolves common failures.

The guide covered updating packages installing Nginx starting and enabling the service allowing HTTP traffic and verifying the default page so a working web server runs on Ubuntu

Tip

Use sudo nginx -t before reloading the service to check for configuration errors that would break the web server when reloaded

title: filezilla ftp nginx
description: Quick guide to connect FileZilla to an Nginx hosted site for FTP or SFTP transfers with permissions and security tips
heading: filezilla ftp nginx setup guide
body:
This guide teaches how to connect FileZilla to an Nginx hosted site for file uploads and secure deployment

  1. Prepare server and choose FTP or SFTP
  2. Configure Nginx document root and permissions
  3. Create or configure FTP user and chroot
  4. Configure Site Manager in FileZilla and connect
  5. Test upload and lock down the connection

Prepare server Install OpenSSH for SFTP or vsftpd for FTP on the server. SFTP uses SSH and avoids extra FTP daemons. Use the distro package manager to install the chosen service.

Configure Nginx document root and permissions Point Nginx root to the folder meant for uploads. Set ownership to the web server user like www-data or nginx and set permissions so the web server can read files while preventing unwanted writes from other accounts.

Create or configure FTP user and chroot Add a deploy user with a home folder inside the deploy or web folder and apply chroot to restrict access. For SFTP create an SSH user with restricted shell or use internal-sftp for jailed sessions. Avoid anonymous accounts unless chaos is desired.

Configure Site Manager in FileZilla and connect Open FileZilla Site Manager and add a new site. Choose SFTP for encrypted transfers and prefer key based authentication. For plain FTP use the correct port and set transfer mode to match server expectations. Save the profile for repeat deploys.

Test upload and lock down the connection Upload a small HTML test file and request the URL in a browser to confirm Nginx serves the file. Fix ownership and chmod if the web server cannot read the file. Turn off unused FTP features and enforce strong passwords or keys to avoid surprises.

This compact walkthrough covered preparing the server, aligning Nginx permissions, creating a secure FTP or SFTP user, connecting with FileZilla, and validating uploads. Follow these steps to move files to a live Nginx site with minimal drama

Tip

Prefer SFTP over FTP for encryption. Use SSH keys for automated deploys and set umask so new files receive safe permissions

title: How to create and run a script in Ubuntu
description: Step by step guide to write and execute shell scripts on Ubuntu including permissions shebang and common pitfalls
heading: How to create and run a script in Ubuntu step by step
body:
This tutorial shows how to create a simple shell script and run the script on Ubuntu with minimal fuss and a hint of sarcasm.

  1. Create a new file for the script
  2. Add a shebang and commands
  3. Make the file executable
  4. Run the script from the terminal
  5. Fix common permission and path problems

Step 1 Create a file

Open a terminal and create a file with a text editor. Example command nano hello.sh. Choose a name that does not conflict with system commands and press save when done.

Step 2 Add a shebang and commands

Start the file with a shebang so the shell knows which interpreter to use. Example first line #!/bin/bash. Add a simple command such as echo Hello World on the next line.

Step 3 Make the file executable

Grant execute permission so the kernel will allow running the file. Use chmod +x hello.sh. This sets the execute bit and prevents mysterious permission errors later.

Step 4 Run the script from the terminal

Run the script with a relative path if the current folder contains the file. Example ./hello.sh. Avoid typing the file name alone unless the folder is in the PATH variable.

Step 5 Fix common permission and path problems

If the shell refuses to run the file check ownership and execute bit with ls -l hello.sh. If the wrong interpreter runs adjust the shebang or invoke the desired interpreter directly like bash hello.sh.

Following these steps delivers a working script that runs from the terminal without drama. New scripts can be added to a bin folder on the home directory and the PATH variable can be updated for easy access across sessions.

Tip

Use #!/usr/bin/env bash as the shebang for better portability across distributions and avoid hardcoding a path that may differ between systems.

title: Configure GitHub SSH Keys
description: Learn how to generate add and test SSH keys for GitHub so secure password free pushes happen from your machine.
heading: Configure GitHub SSH Keys for secure git access
body:
This guide shows how to create add and register SSH keys for GitHub so secure password free pushes work from a local machine.

  1. Generate a new SSH key
  2. Start the SSH agent and add the key
  3. Copy the public key to the clipboard
  4. Add the key to GitHub account settings
  5. Test the SSH connection and update repository remote if needed

Generate a new SSH key

Run a modern algorithm to create a key pair. RSA is old news so pick ed25519 for speed and security.

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C your_email@example.com

Start the SSH agent and add the key

Spawn the agent and add the private key so the system can use the key without retyping a passphrase every time.

eval $(ssh-agent -s)

ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Copy the public key to the clipboard

The public key is the file with .pub at the end. Copy that content exactly and do not paste extra newlines.

cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

Add the key to GitHub account settings

Open the SSH and GPG keys section in the GitHub web interface and paste the public key. Give a descriptive title so later confusion is reduced.

Test the SSH connection and update repository remote if needed

Run a quick check to verify that GitHub accepts the key. If a repository uses HTTPS switch to the SSH URL to avoid repeated credential prompts.

ssh -T git@github.com

git remote set-url origin git@github.com username/repo.git

Recap of the workflow Generate a key start the agent add the private key copy the public key add the public key at GitHub and test the connection. After testing pushing and pulling should use the SSH channel and skip password prompts

Tip

Use a passphrase for the private key and rely on the agent for convenience. A short memorable passphrase plus agent use gives both security and sanity.

title: Create and Configure GitLab SSH Keys
description: Learn how to generate SSH keys add a public key to GitLab and configure local SSH for secure passwordless Git access
heading: Create and Configure GitLab SSH Keys for secure Git access
body:
This tutorial shows how to generate an SSH key pair add the public key to a GitLab account configure local SSH and test passwordless Git access on clone push and fetch commands.

  1. Generate a key pair on the local machine
  2. Add the public key to GitLab
  3. Configure the local SSH client for GitLab
  4. Test the SSH connection and use the key

Generate a key pair on the local machine

Run a modern key generation command for better security. Example command is ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@example.com" Follow the prompts to save the key to the default location or choose a custom path. Protect the private key with a passphrase or use an SSH agent for convenience.

Add the public key to GitLab

Open the GitLab profile settings and select SSH Keys. Copy the public key file usually found at ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub and paste the entire contents into the key field. Give a memorable title like the machine name and save the key. No black magic required just paste and save.

Configure the local SSH client for GitLab

Edit the SSH config file at ~/.ssh/config to add a host entry. Example lines are Host gitlab.com User git HostName gitlab.com IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519 This avoids supplying a key path on every Git command and makes multiple accounts manageable.

Test the SSH connection and use the key

Confirm authentication with ssh -T git@gitlab.com A successful message from GitLab confirms the key is accepted. Then clone push and fetch using the SSH repo URL such as git@gitlab.com group/project.git Adjust file permissions if SSH complains by running chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

This guide covered generating a secure key pair adding the public key to a GitLab account configuring the local SSH client and verifying the connection for passwordless Git operations. Following these steps reduces friction and improves security for developers who use GitLab daily.

Tip

Prefer ed25519 keys for smaller size and better security. Use an SSH agent to avoid repeated passphrase prompts and add an expiry or named key per machine for easier key management.

title: Create and Configure BitBucket SSH keys for Git
description: Quick guide to generate add and test BitBucket SSH keys for seamless Git pushes and pulls without passwords
heading: Create and Configure BitBucket SSH keys for Git the easy way
body:
This tutorial shows how to create and configure BitBucket SSH keys for Git so secure password free pushes and pulls can happen.

  1. Generate an SSH key pair
  2. Start the SSH agent and add a private key
  3. Copy the public key into a Bitbucket account
  4. Test the SSH connection
  5. Configure Git to use the SSH clone link

Generate an SSH key pair Use a modern key type with a comment for identification. Run ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@example.com" and follow prompts. Choose a passphrase unless the automation fairy showed up at the door.

Start the SSH agent and add a private key Start background agent with eval "$(ssh-agent -s)" then add a key with ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519. Agent keeps the private key unlocked for the session so repeated pushes do not demand a password.

Copy the public key into a Bitbucket account Display the public key with cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub then paste the full key into Bitbucket under Personal settings then SSH keys. That grants repository access without username and password drama.

Test the SSH connection Verify access using ssh -T git@bitbucket.org Expect a friendly welcome message that confirms authentication succeeded.

Configure Git to use the SSH clone link In a local repository update the remote using the SSH clone link from Bitbucket. For example run git remote set-url origin [SSH clone link from Bitbucket] Then perform a git fetch or git push to confirm the remote uses SSH.

Recap of the process Generate a secure key pair add the private key to an agent add the public key to Bitbucket test the connection and point local Git to the SSH clone link. That yields password free Git operations with proper authentication and fewer login nags.

Tip

Store multiple keys cleanly by adding a small config file at ~/.ssh/config with a Host entry for bitbucket.org that sets IdentityFile and IdentitiesOnly yes. Add a passphrase and rely on the agent for convenience and security at the same time.

title: Generate Git SSH Keys That Work Everywhere
description: Generate Git SSH keys that work across machines and services with secure steps agent setup and SSH config tips for cross machine use
heading: Generate Git SSH Keys That Work Everywhere
body:
This tutorial shows how to generate Git SSH keys that work across machines and services and how to configure SSH agents and provider settings for smooth access.

  1. Generate a key pair
  2. Protect the key with a passphrase and meaningful comment
  3. Add the private key to the SSH agent
  4. Register the public key with Git providers
  5. Use SSH config to manage multiple keys and hosts

Step 1 Generate a key pair

Use a modern key type for strong security. The example below creates an ed25519 key with a comment that helps identify the key later.

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your@email.com"

Step 2 Protect the key with a passphrase and meaningful comment

Choose a passphrase that can be remembered or use a password manager. The comment field makes key management less painful when dozens of keys accumulate.

Step 3 Add the private key to the SSH agent

Start the agent and load the private key so the agent can provide credentials to Git operations. That avoids repeated passphrase prompts.

eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"

ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Step 4 Register the public key with Git providers

Copy the public key and paste into each provider account under SSH keys. Many providers label the area SSH and GPG keys. After adding the key push and fetch should authenticate without passwords.

Step 5 Use SSH config to manage multiple keys and hosts

Create a simple SSH config file to tie private keys to host names and to enable agent forwarding when connecting via jump hosts. That prevents accidental key leaks and makes the correct key load automatically.

Host github.com HostName github.com User git IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Summary This tutorial covered generating an ed25519 key pair protecting the private key with a passphrase loading the key into the SSH agent adding the public key to Git providers and using an SSH config to map keys to hosts. Follow these steps for consistent access across laptops servers and CI systems without suffering through password prompts and key confusion.

Tip

Prefer ed25519 keys for new keys and consider hardware tokens for high value accounts. Use host specific entries in the SSH config to keep multiple keys organized and to avoid accidental key use on the wrong host.

title: Fix Git's SSH Permission Denied (PublicKey) Error on GitHub
description: Quick guide to fix Git SSH Permission Denied PublicKey errors on GitHub by creating keys adding to agent uploading the public key and testing the connectio
heading: Fix Git's SSH Permission Denied (PublicKey) Error on GitHub
body:
This tutorial shows how to fix Git SSH Permission Denied PublicKey errors on GitHub by creating a key adding the key to an SSH agent uploading the public key to GitHub and testing the connection.

  1. Check for existing SSH key
  2. Generate a new SSH key if needed
  3. Add the key to an SSH agent
  4. Upload the public key to GitHub
  5. Verify repository remote URL and file permissions
  6. Test the SSH connection and debug

Check for existing SSH key

Look in the user home directory for SSH keys. Typical locations include ~/.ssh/id_rsa and ~/.ssh/id_ed25519. If a key already exists skip generation and proceed to add the key to an agent.

Generate a new SSH key

Use a modern algorithm when possible. Example command for an Ed25519 key

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

Add the key to an SSH agent

Start the agent and add the private key so Git can use the credential. Example commands for Unix like systems

eval "$(ssh-agent -s)" then ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Upload the public key to GitHub

Copy the public key file such as ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub and paste into GitHub profile settings under SSH and GPG keys. Give the key a clear name so future humans do not cry.

Verify repository remote URL and file permissions

Confirm the Git remote uses SSH for example git@github.com user/repo.git. Ensure SSH folder and files have strict permissions for security and to avoid silent failures. Typical permissions include chmod 700 ~/.ssh and chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.

Test the SSH connection and debug

Run a test command with verbose output to see what goes wrong

ssh -T -v git@github.com

Read the debug messages to find missing keys agent problems or permission issues and correct accordingly.

Recap of the process includes checking for existing keys generating a modern key when needed adding the private key to an SSH agent uploading the public key to the GitHub account verifying remote settings and file permissions then testing with an SSH connection command to confirm success.

Tip

If multiple SSH keys exist create an SSH config entry for GitHub with a specific IdentityFile and HostName. That prevents the wrong key from being offered and saves future hair loss.

title: Find GitHub's SSH URL & Git Cloning!
description: Find the SSH URL on GitHub add SSH keys test the link and clone a repository using simple commands and clear steps.
heading: Find GitHub SSH URL and Git Cloning Guide
body:
This tutorial shows how to find a GitHub SSH URL and clone a repository using SSH keys and the command line in a few quick steps.

  1. Open the repository page on GitHub
  2. Click the Code button and pick SSH
  3. Copy the SSH link shown
  4. Generate or add a local SSH key pair
  5. Test the SSH connection to GitHub
  6. Run the clone command using the SSH link

Step 1 Navigate to the repository page on GitHub where source files live. No treasure hunt required. A repo home page holds the Code button near the top right area of the file list.

Step 2 Press the Code button and choose the SSH option. That selection changes the link to the secure form for authentication with a private key instead of username and password juggling.

Step 3 Copy the SSH link shown in the field. The example form looks like git at github dot com slash username slash repo dot git written out to avoid messy punctuation here. Replace username and repo with real values when running commands.

Step 4 If a local machine lacks an SSH key pair run a generator. For modern keys use a command such as ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@example.com" then add the public key to GitHub via Settings and SSH and GPG keys.

Step 5 Test the connection to confirm access. Run ssh -T git@github.com and observe a friendly greeting from GitHub if authentication works. If prompted accept the host key and unblock the path.

Step 6 Clone the repository with the SSH link. An example command using the written form looks like git clone git at github dot com slash username slash repo dot git which maps to the real SSH URL format on the clipboard.

This guide covered locating the SSH URL on GitHub copying that link adding a local SSH key testing the connection and cloning a repository. Follow the steps and the next clone will behave like magic rather than chaos.

Tip

Use ed25519 keys for better security and add the private key to an ssh agent for seamless pushes and pulls. If a push fails check the public key on GitHub and confirm the remote URL uses SSH rather than HTTPS.

title: jdbc
description: Learn core JDBC concepts and setup for Java database access and query execution for reliable relational data handling
heading: jdbc guide for Java database connectivity
body:
JDBC is a Java API for connecting to and executing SQL statements on relational databases.

JDBC provides a standard set of interfaces that let Java programs talk to relational databases with minimal drama. Key players include DriverManager or a DataSource implementation, Connection, Statement, PreparedStatement and ResultSet.

Common workflow follows a few clear steps

  1. Load or obtain a driver
  2. Open a connection
  3. Create a statement or prepared statement
  4. Execute SQL and fetch a result set
  5. Close resources and handle transactions

Load or obtain a driver by adding the vendor driver jar to the classpath or by using a container provided DataSource. Modern Java versions often auto detect drivers so manual loading is rare.

Open a connection using a driver manager or a pooled DataSource. Connection objects represent a session with a database and manage transaction boundaries.

Create a Statement for simple ad hoc SQL or prefer PreparedStatement for repeated queries and parameter binding. PreparedStatement shines for performance and security because parameter binding prevents SQL injection and allows query plan reuse.

Execute SQL with executeQuery for select operations and executeUpdate for insert update and delete operations. Process the ResultSet row by row and map columns to domain values with care for null handling and type conversions.

Always close ResultSet Statement and Connection in a finally block or use try with resources to avoid resource leaks. Manage transactions explicitly by using commit and rollback on Connection so database state stays predictable when errors occur.

Despite a few tedious steps JDBC remains a reliable foundation for Java database access and pairs nicely with higher level libraries when more abstraction is desired.

Tip

Prefer PreparedStatement over plain Statement for any query that accepts external input and consider a connection pool for production to avoid the performance cost of frequent session creation.

title: networking lab
description: Hands on networking lab guide for building virtual routers switches and hosts to practice routing VLANs and troubleshooting
heading: networking lab tutorial for hands on practice
body:
This tutorial shows how to build a basic networking lab using virtual routers switches and hosts for routing VLANs and troubleshooting.

  1. Plan topology
  2. Choose virtualization tools
  3. Create devices and links
  4. Configure addressing and routing
  5. Test traffic and troubleshoot
  6. Document and snapshot

Plan topology by sketching a simple network that includes at least two routers a switch and two hosts. Keep scenarios small so debugging stays sane and coffee consumption stays moderate.

Choose virtualization tools based on hardware and learning goals. Use GNS3 or EVE NG for realistic router images and use Packet Tracer for lighter labs with a friendlier learning curve.

Create devices and links by adding virtual routers switches and hosts then connect interfaces according to the sketch. Name interfaces clearly because guessing will waste time and dignity.

Configure addressing and routing on each device. Assign IP addresses configure routing protocols or static routes and set up VLANs on the switch. Verify adjacency and route propagation before moving on.

Test traffic and troubleshoot with ping traceroute and packet captures. Simulate failures by shutting down interfaces or changing routes and observe how the network reacts. Use logs to track stubborn problems instead of random guessing.

Document and snapshot configurations to preserve a known good state. Store config files in a repository and take snapshots of virtual machines so rollback becomes a quick magic trick instead of a stressful quest.

This guide covered planning building configuring and testing a basic networking lab that supports hands on practice for routing VLANs and troubleshooting. The goal is to build confidence by practicing realistic scenarios and learning from controlled failures.

Tip

Use snapshots before major changes and keep configuration snippets in a versioned file. That makes experiments reversible and keeps embarrassment to a minimum.

title: Performance
description: Practical guide to measuring and improving web performance with profiling caching code splitting and monitoring for faster user experiences
heading: Performance Optimization Guide
body:
Performance is how quickly and reliably a system serves users under realistic load.

Good performance matters because users leave when pages feel slow and conversions drop when the page feels sluggish. The goal is to measure real behavior then apply surgical fixes that matter most to users.

  1. Measure

    Collect lab metrics and field data. Use synthetic tests for repeatable baselines and field metrics for real user experience. Key metrics include load time, time to first byte, first contentful paint and largest contentful paint.

  2. Profile

    Find hotspots with profilers and browser dev tools. Look for long tasks CPU spikes and expensive paints. Server side profiling shows slow database queries and blocking operations.

  3. Optimize critical path

    Reduce the amount of work required to render the first meaningful view. Prioritize above the fold resources and defer nonessential scripts. Inline tiny critical CSS and lazy load below the fold content.

  4. Cache and compress

    Use browser caching CDNs and HTTP compression to reduce latency. Cache where responses are stable and invalidate carefully when content changes.

  5. Monitor and iterate

    Set up real user monitoring and alerts for regressions. Run performance budgets and bake tests into the CI pipeline so regressions are caught before reaching users.

Small wins add up. A few targeted changes often beat a full rewrite. Focus on user facing metrics and measure every change under real conditions. Avoid guessing and let metrics guide optimization priorities.

Tip

When faced with a vague slow complaint gather a flame chart and a field histogram first. That data points to the component causing the slowdown and prevents chasing the wrong problem.

title: threads
description: Clear practical guide to threads in programming covering concurrency race conditions synchronization and performance tips for developers
heading: threads explained for developers
body:
A thread is a single sequence of programmed instructions that the operating system can schedule.

Threads allow concurrent work inside a process while sharing memory and resources. That sharing saves memory and enables fast communication and also introduces race conditions data corruption and delightful deadlocks when developers get experimental.

Why use threads

  1. Improve responsiveness by moving blocking work away from the main flow
  2. Speed up CPU bound tasks by using multiple cores where available
  3. Manage lots of small tasks with a thread pool to avoid constant creation overhead

Common hazards

  1. Race conditions when multiple threads modify shared state without coordination
  2. Deadlocks when locks are acquired in conflicting order
  3. Excessive context switching when too many threads are active

Basic remedies

  1. Prefer immutable data and local state where possible
  2. Use fine grained locking or lock free primitives like atomics for hot paths
  3. Adopt higher level abstractions such as tasks futures or actor style message passing to reduce manual locking

Minimal example in pseudo code

function workTask(data) { process data } main() { thread t = spawn workTask with data t.join() }

Debugging tips include reproducing race conditions with stress tests using increased concurrency and adding diagnostic logging that includes thread ids and timestamps. Performance tuning should start with measurement because blind optimism about concurrency often makes code slower.

Tip

Favor message passing when scaling across cores and services and reserve shared memory plus locks for performance critical hotspots. Use thread pools and tasks to avoid thrashing from constant thread creation and to keep resource usage predictable.

title: Apache Reverse Proxy Configuration Example
description: Step by step guide to set up Apache as a reverse proxy using mod proxy and SSL for backend servers with concise sample directives
heading: Apache Reverse Proxy Configuration Example Guide
body:
High level overview This tutorial teaches how to configure Apache as a reverse proxy to forward requests to backend servers and to handle headers and TLS.

  1. Enable required modules
  2. Create a proxy VirtualHost
  3. Preserve host and pass headers
  4. Enable TLS for front end
  5. Test and reload the server

Enable required modules

Activate proxy related modules on Debian based servers with this command shown as a single line

sudo a2enmod proxy proxy_http proxy_balancer ssl headers

That command loads the pieces that allow forwarding of HTTP and handling of TLS and headers

Create a proxy VirtualHost
